PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:

`Observe the United Nations Convention of the Rights of the Child and grant all children social justice and equity in relation to a pre school developmental program which will provide the foundation for a quality education and future employability, by removing the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care based on parents marital and employment status'
Your Petitioners ask/request that the Senate should:
`remove the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care children based on parents marital and employment status'

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licences despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and
exclude from licences, woodchip derived from old growth forests and wilderness.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of Nuclear Testing. Therefore we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing,
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support the Government's efforts to assist nations with the clearing of land mines and also support world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give priority to expanding Australia's support for mine clearance in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to give greater support to mine clearance efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4 of this bill allows a carer pensioner to accompany the person they are caring for overseas for up to three months in any one calendar year and continue to receive their pension. This is certainly a step forward because until now, except in limited circumstances, carers have lost their pensions as soon as they leave the country. It remains the case, however, that the portability of the carees pension is much greater—12 months in most cases, and occasionally longer. In other words, under the government's proposal, carers will lose their pension much earlier than the person they are caring for.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats believe that the carer pension should be portable for up to 12 months, and this is what my first amendment seeks to put in place. I remind the chamber that the department gave evidence to the community affairs committee that the cost of this amendment would be very small. The amendment has the support of the Carers Association of Australia. I commend the amendments to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Woodley points out, the Australian Democrats are seeking these amendments to the provision dealing with the portability of the carer pension. The government's bill provides that a carer pensioner would be able to accompany their carer overseas, without loss of qualification, provided the period of absence does not exceed three months in a calendar year.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats propose that this three-month period be extended to 12 months in line with the current wife pension and that other provisions relating to the portability of both pensions be brought into line. The justification is that the Department of Social Security has stated to the committee that there will be a small number of people involved, and hence the costs will be small. The inquiry is seeking information that cost implications have not confirmed this assertion.

In view of the fact that the wife's pension is being phased out as at 1 July 1995 and some of these claimants will take up a carers pension, the number of claimants is unknown and the cost cannot be estimated at this stage. The coalition will therefore not be supporting the Democrats, principally because of the unknown budget implications that may result from the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —What these amendments are about has been clearly explained by both Senator Woodley and Senator Patterson. The government is opposing these amendments. The argument has been put that one of the reasons for these amendments is that when carers were overseas it was actually during the carer's respite period and a carer would not be treated as in respite if the carer was, in fact, caring for the caree on the trip overseas.

PARA.TAB: The amendments introduced in the bill would address the unintended consequence by allowing the payment of the carers pension for up to three months while the carer accompanies the caree on a temporary absence from Australia. The government opposes the extension of this to 12 months. It considers the amendments are appropriate and any further extension of continued qualification whilst the carer is overseas would make it difficult for the department whether the carers are, as a matter of fact, continuing to care for the caree, and that is an essential qualification for the criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sole parent pension is payable to people who are members of a couple if they are living separately and apart from their partners. The government's original amendment in the bill was designed to ensure that this provision was not abused in situations where claims are made where separations are of a temporary nature, such as where a partner goes overseas for a holiday, works away from home, has study commitments, or during a short-term domestic dispute.

PARA.TAB: The coalition had serious concerns that there was no protection for the persons with children, usually women, who were attempting to leave a violent domestic situation and applied for the sole parent pension. The original framing of the bill would have had the effect of excluding such persons from qualification. I have forgotten how long ago that was. I asked someone how long ago we started this bill and they said, `Ages.' As I said yesterday, I have changed staff since we started this bill.

The coalition indicated that it would move an amendment to ensure that claimants with violent partners were not forced to return to a dangerous home situation because the department considered the separation to be short term and thus denied payment to the claimant. There were also concerns about intrusive inquiries into the lives of prospective claimants and their partners. As a result of the pressure from the coalition, the government responded and has agreed to substitute this amendment.

I thought it absolutely necessary to put on the record here that it was the coalition who addressed this issue. I should have thought that the government would have thought about it beforehand and, had they paid more attention to the development of these bills beforehand, we would not have all these amendments. But I believe that this amendment is an appropriate one and is a result of the coalition's pressure on the government. Therefore, the coalition will be supporting the government's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is moving this amendment to omit division 6 of the bill and insert a new division to make sure that the sole parent pension is paid to a separated member of a couple only if the separation is permanent or indefinite and not strictly temporary. The initiative will now be achieved primarily by amending the definition of a member of a couple. It will put beyond doubt that the same criteria are applied in determining whether a marriage like relationship exists between two people who are not legally married as are applied in determining whether two people who are legally married are living separately and apart. Each determination is necessary to establish whether a person is a member of a couple. This in turn determines whether a person qualifies for the sole parent pension.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses provide that the training supplement, which assists unemployed people with expenses they might incur in undertaking training, will only be paid if the person has individual approval to undertake an approved training course. In other words, not only must the course be an approved one but to be eligible for the training supplement the person must obtain individual approval to undertake that course. As the Victorian Social Justice Council pointed out to me, around 50 per cent of successful job search is done independently of the CES. As such, the Democrats believe we should be rewarding people's initiatives rather than enforcing dependence on the CES. The Democrats will be opposing these clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The jobsearch and newstart supplement provisions in this bill reform the entitlement to a jobsearch or newstart training supplement until the employment secretary has approved the person's participation in a vocational training course or labour market program. This clause, if enacted, would include in the list of non-reviewable decisions at section 1250 of the Social Security Act 1991 a decision by the employment secretary not to approve a person's participation in a specified vocational training course for the purpose of payment of the jobsearch and newstart training supplement. The danger is that case managers will be able to make decisions about whether or not someone is eligible to go on a training course without giving the job seeker the option of having his or her case reviewed.

PARA.TAB: It is unreasonable to have these decisions non-reviewable. The coalition has a generalised concern regarding the expansion of non-reviewable decisions in this legislation. The coalition believes that the parliament should exercise reticence in considering any widening of the range of non-reviewable decisions affecting clients under legislation as complex as the Social Security Act. For that reason, we will be opposing clause 26. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills made the following observation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . draws the Senators' attention to the provisions, as it may be considered to make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent on non-reviewable decisions . . . (or) . . . sufficiently defined administrative powers . . . (or) . . . to make the exercise of legislative power insufficiently subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

The government had indicated that it would provide in writing confirmation that these decisions would be reviewable by the ombudsman and the AAT. In the end, the coalition was not convinced that the minister's letter provided such a guarantee so the coalition will be opposing clause 26 of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said when addressing the previous clauses, the Democrats believe we should be rewarding people's initiatives rather than enforcing dependence on the CES. At the very least, we believe that where a person is refused a training supplement surely they should be able to appeal that decision. For those reasons we oppose clause 26.

—I rise to indicate that the Greens also stand with the opposition and the Democrats in opposing this clause, for very similar reasons. I put on the record that we do support all the Democrats' amendments and commend them for the work they have put into it.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the argument for opposing this clause is the limited funds. The rationale the government is arguing is that the pool of funds is not unlimited and so such decisions have to be made. Our belief is that the reverse argument is that limited funds do not guarantee good decision making and that people should have access to a review of an unfavourable decision, particularly as their income may depend on that decision.
Clause negatived.
Clauses 27 to 34—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 35 to 36—by leave—taken together.
Amendment (by Senator Crowley) proposed:
Division 14 of Part 2, page 16, line 31 to 38, and page 17, lines 1 to 7, omit the Division.

TALK.START.PARA: —Legislative provisions exist to protect information about social security customers and provide for its release only in limited circumstances such as to the secretary to a Commonwealth department or the head of a Commonwealth authority for the purpose of that department or authority. The original amendment in this bill would have allowed the secretary to disclose information not only to the secretary or head of a department or authority but also to the staff. It would also have removed the statutory prohibition, which currently prevents the secretary from delegating his disclosure power to enable officers of the department to disclose information in place of the secretary—that is, it would have allowed the secretary to delegate his disclosure power.

PARA.TAB: It is essential that the integrity of the kind of information held by departments such as social security be upheld and strengthened rather than weakened. The government has obviously realised the danger in the original amendment and the threat to privacy and confidentiality that it poses as it is moving to remove division 14 entirely. The coalition will support the government's amendment to remove division 14, clauses 35 and 36, of this bill because it will return the situation to the status quo.
Clauses negatived.
Clause 37 agreed to.
Clauses 38 and 39—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses relate to decisions of the minister to disregard certain money held for loans given by a person for the purposes of the income test. The bill seeks to ensure that these determinations are not subject to internal review or review by the SSAT. The government has said that review of these ministerial decisions by a review officer or by the SSAT would be inappropriate. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, however, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Fairness demands where an individual seeks the favourable exercise of what is so obviously a discretion that review on the merits be available.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggested that these decisions could be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal along the lines of the former jurisdiction with respect to certain migration appeals. The Democrats will not be supporting clauses 38 and 39.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment clarifies that a decision by the minister not to approve an application for exemption from deeming provisions is a non-reviewable decision for the purposes of section 1239 of the act. It is not reviewable either internally or by the SSAT.

PARA.TAB: As stated already, the coalition has a generalised concern regarding the expansion of non-reviewable decisions in this legislation. This arises in the context of the decision by the minister not to approve applications for exemption from deeming provisions, and also decisions by the employment secretary not to approve participation by a person in a specified vocational training course or labour market program.

The department's argument that the clause avoids the possibility of the minister being reviewed by a member of his own department does not outweigh the fact that personal rights and liberties become too dependent upon non-reviewable decisions. The coalition believes that the parliament should exercise reticence in considering any widening of the range of non-reviewable decisions affecting clients under legislation as complex as this act, and for that reason we will be opposing clauses 38 and 39.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues have said, clauses 38 and 39 of the bill contain provisions which, if enacted, are intended to put beyond doubt the position that decisions by the minister under section 1099E and section 1099L of the Social Security Act 1991 are exempt from review. Recent legal advice has raised a question about the basis for that position. The amendments seek to put the issue beyond doubt.

PARA.TAB: Decisions under the relevant sections are not made very often; they are made by the minister personally and not by a delegate. This being the case, it would be inappropriate for decisions of the minister to be reviewed under the normal procedures set out under the Social Security Act; that is, by the department, an authorised review officer and by the SSAT.

In its Alert Digest No. 1 of 1995 the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills accepted that this was inappropriate but suggested that, instead, the decision should be reviewable by the AAT without first being reviewed by an authorised review officer and the SSAT. The minister has considered this suggestion and has decided that such a review is not necessary. When the minister makes a decision under the relevant provisions in relation to an individual—and there would be very few of them—that decision would be as a result of policy considerations of a similar nature to those applying to a decision in relation to a class of persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put on the record that the Greens (WA) support the position put by the government in this instance. We believe that the minister should have the capacity to make those decisions. Often particular decisions made by the minister referred to in the relevant sections of the act would be in favour of the client and not to the client's disadvantage. The minister is accountable to the people. In this case it may well be that we are allowing the responsibility to rest where it belongs rather than with the bureaucracy and with administrative principles.

PARA.TAB: Clauses negatived.
Clause 40 agreed to.
Clauses 41 to 75—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —To save the committee's time I am going to speak to clauses 41 to 75, but also make comments about clause 137, which applies. Clauses 41 to 137 of the bill relate to the distinction between when a person ceases to qualify for a payment and when that person's payability ceases.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats believe that safeguards provided in the current system need to be maintained. We would agree with the Welfare Rights Centre when they said that `a person's assessment should always be subject to a determination by a DSS officer who weighs up the evidence and applies intelligence to a complex matter'.

We believe that passing these provisions would be putting the onus on DSS clients not only to inform the department of any changes in their circumstances but also to ensure that the department acts on the information in a timely fashion. So the Democrats will not be supporting these clauses. I simply indicate that we will move an amendment to insert an additional clause after clause 76.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to clauses 41 to 75, I indicate that the opposition will be opposing all of those clauses.

PARA.TAB: Clauses negatived.
Proposed new clause 76A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Before clause 76, page 28, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "76A. Section 408BA of the Principal Act is amended:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)by omitting `50' in paragraph (1)(b) and substituting `40';
(b)by omitting `50' in paragraph (2)(b) and substituting `40'.".

Honourable senators will remember that in November last year we debated the legislation introducing the widow allowance for women who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 50. In the course of that debate I moved an amendment which would have made the widow allowance more widely available; in particular it would have allowed women who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 40 to claim the allowance after they turned 50, provided that they had not had any recent work force experience.

PARA.TAB: It is a very minor amendment and certainly does not go anywhere near as far as I would like to go but, if one cannot take the giant leaps which are required, then one takes smaller steps in the hope that others will follow. As I said at that stage, the practical effect of my amendment would have been that a woman who lost her husband when she was, say, 45 years old would have had five years to test the job market and, if she could not get a job in that time, she would have had the option of changing from the jobsearch allowance to the widow allowance. These two payments are made at the same rate, but the great advantage for older women is that there is no requirement under the widow allowance for women to look for work.

The government, however, voted against my amendment and I recall that the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security gave absolutely no reason for the government's position. The Liberal-National coalition also voted against the amendment on the grounds that—and I quote Senator Patterson's words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it does not answer the sort of concerns we have had raised in relation to this payment.

Senators may be aware that, over the last few months, I have tabled petitions containing over 15,000 signatures calling for, amongst other things, precisely this change to be made to the widows allowance. That petition was not widely distributed but, even with the limited distribution it had, we got 15,000 signatures. That certainly indicates to me that, in the mind of the community, there is an injustice occurring, an injustice that this parliament alone has the power to correct. As such, I feel it is important for me to re-present the amendment that I moved last year to give the opposition and the government yet another opportunity to at least provide this very small concession.

PARA.TAB: I believe the position of widows in society needs to be the subject of far greater government attention. But at this stage I feel it is important for us to provide some immediate relief to a significant number of women who find themselves in a very difficult position. I want to read from a letter that I recently received. It goes with the hundreds of letters that I have received, but it just gives an illustration of the kind of distress that I am trying to address here. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Woodley,

PARA.TAB: I read with interest the enclosed article and it seems an answer to at least one of the pressures I feel.

On the 16th September 1994 my husband lost his six week fight to stay alive after suffering a stroke. I was at the time 49 1/2 years old. I returned to work in November 1994. Apart from my absolute desolate grief, my time is absorbed with my husband's estate . . . It is no surprise I found myself unemployed in February 1995.

Although I make valiant attempts to look for work, I now suffer the indignity of being told "I'm over the hill", "past in", "too many younger people out of work". As I approach the first anniversary of my beloved Fred's death, the depression I am suffering is doubled because of the pressure of having to look for work and the officials don't care—"you'll look for work or else lose your job search."

Senator Woodley, I have worked since I was 14 1/2. I am not afraid of hard work, and maybe much later, I will renew my vigour to be employed, because I don't consider myself, "over the hill". Although I have been only unemployed for six months, I applaud your efforts and with all my heart wish you all the good luck in the world in getting this change through parliament. I want my self-esteem and dignity back. If other women feel the same way I do, I'm not surprised you have 16,000 signatures.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to remember that the women we are talking about did not choose to be in the circumstances they are in. They may have spent 25 or even 30 years out of the formal work force while they raised their family. The government, with the home child-care allowance, is providing some long overdue recognition of the valuable role of child rearing but, at the same time, it is abandoning women who may have already spent 30 years raising their families. I do urge the government and the opposition to support my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are moving an amendment to the widows allowance to reduce the qualifying age from 50 to 40 years. The coalition has been critical of the government's removal of the widow B allowance in its implementation of the widow allowance. But, having said that, the coalition will not be supporting the Democrats' amendment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley, if you were to move that to 40 years of age, equally somebody could come into this chamber and read exactly the same sort of letter from someone who at 39 1/2 years had lost their spouse. I think the government needs to address more fully the implications of this because there are other permutations and combinations. But we happen not to be the government. I believe it behoves the government to address this issue of those women in the cohort between 45 and 50 years who may not have had the same experience in work that younger women have had and, therefore, are more likely to be able to go back to employment. It is on the government's head to address this issue.

The coalition believes that 40 is not an appropriate age. Therefore, we will not be supporting the Democrats' amendment but ask the government to look more carefully at the issue, in particular of those women in the older end of that cohort between 40 and 50 years, and to come up with some creative solution which address some of the issues that Senator Woodley has outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens WA support Senator Woodley's amendment, not because of its kind of partial nature but because of its symbolic importance as a statement which I hope will be heard by both the government and the opposition. It is the proper role of government to care for those who are vulnerable in our society. Widows are widows and should be treated as that, not according to some kind of formula. There is increasing pressure of economic arguments being placed on women in particular, and in this instance we are thinking about women who are suffering the grief of widowhood. The pressure of economic arguments is forcing the government to reduce its responsibility in this area, and it is something that we do not agree with. We are not necessarily convinced, as Senator Woodley has said, that this is the best measure. We think the best measure is a review but, in the absence of that, it seems this would be a way of ameliorating some of the harm and distress caused to people who are feeling increasingly squeezed out in the care and regard that they should be receiving from the government in the situation that they face.

—I want to place some comments on the record. Widow allowance was introduced on 1 January 1995 to provide an income support option for older women who have lost the support of a partner later in life and who have no recent work force experience. These women made career and life choices under more traditional expectations of their labour market participation and are now particularly disadvantaged in facing the labour market for the first time because they spent long periods out of the work force caring for their family.

PARA.TAB: Although it is increasing, the work force participation rate for women over 55 remains significantly lower than for those aged between 45 and 54. The age restriction on widow allowance avoids the problem that existed with the old widow B pension, where a woman could become widowed or separated at age 40, for example, work between 40 and 50 and then retire, claiming a pension at age 50. There is no reason why this particular group of women should be able to retire earlier than the rest of the community.

The government considers that women who lose the support of a partner at a younger age will generally be more able to participate in the work force and would benefit most from other measures designed to assist and encourage work force participation. I am interested in the letter that Senator Woodley read out. In that woman's case, she went back to work. She has recent work force participation. She has not been out of the work force for many years. Far be it from me to be diagnosing across the chamber, but the grief seemed to be a significant part of that person's problem, not an absence from work.

It is now very much the case that many more women have not had very long periods out of the work force by the time they are 40. An increasing number of women have had work force experience to that time. It is also true, in the government's view, that jobsearch allowance remains a better option than either widow allowance or partner allowance because it provides access to a full range of labour market programs, including the job compact. One of the significant changes the government has introduced with its labour market changes is that people are not forgotten or ignored. It is not a case of just taking your money and off you go. Under those programs, not only is information and access to courses and other programs available; there is also the opportunity that your name and information are available so that you are not forgotten and left alone to drift. We have been told by a lot of long-term unemployed people that that has been the case.

The government is committed to encouraging and supporting women to participate in the paid work force to best ensure their financial security. The government considers that long-term dependency on any form of income support is not something the community should support or can afford to encourage. Long-term dependency can also be isolating for people. If a woman widowed at an earlier age has been unemployed for at least 12 months at age 50, the requirements to report efforts to look for work are considerably relaxed, compared to normal requirements imposed on younger unemployed people. In fact, for those women the general requirements for continued receipt of newstart allowance are only marginally more than those applying for widow allowance. I think this is also very important, and I hope Senator Woodley's letter-writing people are aware of those sorts of important differences.

Older women who do not qualify for widow allowance may also qualify for other forms of assistance, such as disability support pension or sickness allowance if there is some medical reason why they are not able to look for work. It is important to say that these changes are not a matter of a heartless government, but a government that is trying to be exactly the opposite, trying to remain encouraging and supportive of people continuing to feel part of the community and participate in it, rather than effectively being given a ticket to retire at a very early age.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for her answer. In the minister's case and probably in the government's case I understand that they are trying to do the right thing and we commended the government when it introduced the widow allowance last year. But I need to say to the minister—I want to ask a question in a moment but I will make these remarks—that all of the great hopes that she has for these particular women we are talking about are not shared by those same women. I am not talking about just a handful; I am talking about thousands of women, certainly hundreds who have contacted me by letter and by phone. They are aware of the complexity of the issue. Some of these women have become very well informed throughout the whole process, particularly in Rockhampton in Queensland where a group of them are very active. They are now a resource for the Department of Social Security in that place.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, there are still issues. One of the problems, minister, is the fact that, although the government puts in place what it hopes will be policy amendments that will help people, these do not always percolate down through the system. For instance, the very good initiative by the government to allow women over 50 to report only every 12 weeks has now been interfered with by the whole issue of case management. Many of the case managers go to women who have a 12-week reporting period and tell them that that is not so. The women are told that they have to be under the control of the case manager, often someone who is many years younger than them, and have to do this, that and something else. So the practice often is not following what the government hopes might be the case. There is a real issue there and I hope the government will take account of that.

We do not believe that our amendment will solve all the problems. In a sense it is a little like what Senator Chamarette is saying. We are wanting by this amendment to signal that there are still many problems and we intend to press the amendment for that reason. But I have a question for you, minister. Let me not get too eloquent at this point. The question is this: minister, I understand there is to be a major revaluation of the phasing out of the widow B pension to be undertaken next year. I know that many of the women who have contacted my office are keen to let the government know of the difficulties they often encounter. Could you inform me as to whether or not there will be an opportunity for members of the public to provide input into that evaluation?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Senator Woodley, may I say that eloquence in this place ought to be encouraged. It would be a significant improvement on a lot of what goes on in here.
—Do you have a penchant for it?

—Senator, I am terribly sorry you said that because I have not known this to be much in your character, but that level of behaviour, the puerile attacking of people in this place, is one of the reasons why I would turn to eloquence. I thought, actually, that that was amazing. Even people in the kindergartens of this country are not that nasty. Correcting people for mispronunciations of language, or words, as you understand them, senator, does not do anything for you. It is not a very edifying spectacle.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley, as I say, a case for eloquence is reinforced by the minute. Can I say, senator, about your point that people only have to go back every 12 weeks to check, if that is being contradicted by the information that people are getting through the office, then that is a matter of concern. I will make sure that that report from you is passed through to the minister's office so that he can follow that up.

As to the opportunity for people—particularly the Rockhampton group, but others as well—to be able to put in information, if you like, so as to be part of the consultation process regarding evaluation, I do not have that information. I am not able to give that assurance to you, but again I will certainly make sure that I will pass that on to the minister to see whether there is anything further that I can bring back to you. On the face of it, it would certainly seem, as you say, that these people have a lot of information, so it would seem reasonable to hear from them about the proposed changes.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Woodley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clauses 76 to 137—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate that the Democrats will be opposing these clauses for the reasons I gave before.

—We are now debating clauses 76 to 137, but the same arguments hold for clauses 41 to 75, which we have already discussed. I did not take the opportunity to speak in detail on clauses 41 to 75 and left it for the debate on clauses 76 to 137. But the reasons are the same for our opposition to clauses 41 to 75. They refer to the cancellation and debt creation provisions.

PARA.TAB: This bill provides that once a client ceases to qualify for a pension or benefit, that person ceases to be entitled to receive any further payments and any payments received after loss of qualification are debts and are subject to the normal recovery method available under the Social Security Act.

This situation arises because the provision dispenses with the need for a department decision as to whether the client is payable or not. The coalition has grave concerns that these clauses will increase the potential for maladministration and are contrary to the AAT decision that a person is payable until the department makes a positive determination to the contrary.

The department has stated that if the department makes an error leading to the raising of a debt, it will not pursue the debt. This is a statement of intention by the department but there is no safety mechanism in the act to ensure that this is how they will treat such cases. For these reasons the coalition will oppose these clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Division 18 of the bill contains a provision that seeks to effect two separate objectives. The first is to provide that, subject to the existing provisions in the act, once qualification is lost, the pension, benefit or allowance—as the case may be—ceases to be payable. You can check that in section 71AB, a new section inserted by clause 42. The second is to provide a period of grace for those social security customers who incur a maximum payment rate debt but who have complied with their notification of obligations.

PARA.TAB: The simple principle underlying the qualification amendments is that a social security payment should not be payable once qualification for the payment is lost. Most people would expect this to be the case. It is important not to confuse these amendments with provisions dealing with recovery of debts to the Commonwealth. These amendments will make any payment made after qualification ceases a debt. They do not affect customers' rights of appeal.

The amendments do not preclude waiver of the resulting debt if it was due to administrative error by the department; and they do not mean recovery will be pursued against the customer if that would cause financial hardship. The amendments provide for greater accountability. They ensure that the department takes prompt action by requiring it to record and report on debts that arise in situations where payments continue beyond qualification. On the other hand, the view expressed by the Welfare Rights Centre, if followed, would allow the department to rest on its laurels because the centre says there is no debt, no matter how long the department takes to act.

Division 18 also contains amendments to benefit customers by creating a period of grace for maximum payment rate debts. These amendments will provide that if a customer incurs a maximum payment rate debt—that is, if the client is paid more than he or she was, in fact, entitled to but has notified the department of the relevant change of circumstances as required—then no debt arises in the notification period. An example is section 73B inserted by clause 45.

The public's confidence in the welfare system will be undermined if the Australian Democrats are successful in preventing amendments that seek to give legal force to the commonsense notion that welfare payments should not be paid to people who are not qualified for them and should be recoverable if they are paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to draw the attention of the committee to a particular case. It is one that is of great concern to the National Brain Injury Foundation. It is about a woman who has been struggling to support herself and her two teenage children for four years since her husband sustained a severe brain injury.

PARA.TAB: After a valiant battle to survive, the husband is now permanently and inappropriately accommodated in a geriatric nursing home, despite the fact that he is relatively young. I hasten to add that the nursing home is of the highest standard in every respect.

The person concerned initially had a superannuation payout of $30,000, which is managed by the Public Trustee. The wife works full time to provide for her children. She also provides her husband's clothing and other items relevant to his comfort and care at the weekends. Because she is earning a modest salary which must meet all expenses—rent, household expenditure, food, education, clothing, et cetera—her husband is denied his full pension and, therefore, his pension does not meet his nursing home costs.

I raise this now because the Minister for Social Security, Peter Baldwin, has been written to about this matter but to no avail. In addition, the mother's carer's pension has been cut due to the fact that she earns a salary. The amount held by the Public Trustee continues to reduce their ability to meet the balance of the nursing home costs.

One solution put to her was to pay approximately $180 per fortnight towards his nursing home costs—money she simply does not have. An alternative suggestion put to her was to divorce her husband, which would then mean his nursing home costs would be covered—an unthinkable act for her and her children to consider. She is, however, being pressured into this course of action because of financial circumstances. What a suggestion to make! What is wrong with our social security system if it says to these people that they should get divorced and then the whole thing will be covered? That is an unthinkable thing for this person and her children to do.

The family do not live in their own home. The National Brain Injury Foundation was able to assist in obtaining housing trust accommodation, but the house is so small—no built-ins—that what little furniture they did own is being minded, was sold for a pittance or was given away in the desperation of leaving, with little notice once the housing trust house became available, the home they had all shared prior to the husband's accident.

Their only assets are a motor vehicle in his name, the most meagre of household possessions and the remains of the superannuation held by the Public Trustee, to which the wife has no access. There are weeks when she has a nil balance in her account while struggling to meet rental, living and schooling costs. The National Brain Injury Foundation says that it is personally aware of these details—and I will not go into that.

The wife and her children are trying to cope with the unrelenting grief that comes with the loss of a loved one through brain injury, where the person is still alive but different and unable to function in the `normal community'. However, he has certain functions and is being cared for. The National Brain Injury Foundation is very concerned about the wife's state of health and that of both children. They were once quite comfortable, but now they must battle with these endless practicalities and also with the loss of the husband and father they once knew, who is now in a nursing home.

In recent weeks the following has happened to add unbelievable strain to this family. The wife received a letter from Social Security advising that between March 1992 and September 1993—and this is where the relevance of these particular amendments comes in—the wife had been overpaid $3,139.90. This is at a time when the family was in shock. She had no recollection of how this could have happened, nor any proof that it in fact did. At the time of the accident she had been working part time and, to manage financially, took an offer to work longer hours. However, she believed Social Security was always kept in the picture.

The letter stated that she was required to pay this amount of $3,139.90 as quickly as possible and preferably before 22 July 1995—a week following the receipt of the letter from the Department of Social Security. She contacted Social Security and spoke with a particular person whose christian name is mentioned here—I will not say it in the parliament—a very caring member of staff and, as best she could, she explained this very complicated and heart-breaking position. It was agreed that papers would be sent for her to negotiate the payment of $10 per fortnight.

The person concerned then received a letter dated 10 August stating that her pension of $123.80 per fortnight had been cut to $1 per fortnight—$1 per fortnight! As she had given approval for Social Security to request any information from her employer at the time, she believed that she may have suddenly earned an amount over the threshold and thus these payments had been cut. This proved not to be the case and the stopping of the payment was related to the stated overpayment of $3,139.90. Worse was to come as her pension was also cut but later reinstated—and there is more of that to come.

The letter that I have indicates that the National Brain Injury Foundation understands that an agreement has now been made to repay $10 per fortnight, but not before the stress of all this has had the most detrimental effect on this woman's health and the health of her family at a time when her daughter was suffering the prospect and then the effect of surgery.

Approximately one month ago she went to the family chemist where an account is operated for her husband which is paid by the Public Trustee. Their daughter was about to enter hospital for fairly major surgery and she therefore asked to add to the account a toothbrush, toothpaste, a wet-pack bag and some ointment for her skin allergy. She had added similar creams and ointment items for skin treatment on approximately three occasions and, at her husband's request, some aftershave for his son's birthday. It should be noted that the wife is, of course, his sole guardian.

She was grossly embarrassed when the chemist said she was not able to provide anything on the account. She was humiliated beyond imagination in front of other customers and was told that the Public Trustee had contacted the chemist on two occasions and had said that she could not add anything to the account other than the items specifically for her husband. Although the Public Trustee had contacted the chemist, he had not contacted the wife with the information he had given to the chemist.

I do not want to go much further because much of this relates to the Public Trustee. But I do want to raise this question because it does show the great concern that many people have and the effect that the interpretation of the legislation has on a particular individual about whom the National Brain Injury Foundation has written to the minister.
As I have said, I do not think the Minister for Social Security has responded to those letters. The National Brain Injury Foundation stated in its letter:

SPEECH.PARA: People in her position are exhausted by the medical system which denies their loved ones rehabilitation, by the legal system which is a mystery to them, by the constant hospital and nursing home visits, by the need to be mother and father and carer 24 hours of every day, and by the constant financial battle. As one person who knows this battlefield well has so aptly stated—"They are set up to fail".
We have asked the Minister to provide every consideration as a matter of urgency to resolve this case—to reinstate the pension and to waive the $3139.90. As pointed out to him,

This courageous, hard working, gentle, loving woman deserves the chance to continue to devote her life and her love to her family without being constantly plagued by the financial ghosts now haunting her.
We have thought of suggesting voluntary bankruptcy but would need to seek advice about this so far as it relates to Social Security . . .

I point out to the chamber the disgraceful state of affairs that a courageous person like this has been told that the government can do nothing and nothing can be done through the inflexible social security system. She has been told that if she divorces her husband, who is about 40 years of age and who is being cared for in a geriatric home, all the payments will be met by the government.

PARA.TAB: What sort of situation have we arrived at? Is this government, through its social security legislation, fair dinkum about supporting families? I apologise to the minister, but I have been at another meeting and thought when I came into the chamber that, because this issue is relevant in broad terms to the issue of the repayment of loans and so on which we are discussing at the moment, I should raise it with you. I ask the minister to please take this on board. I know you get a lot of difficult cases, but this appears to me to be one that you would be personally interested in. I apologise for not giving you advance notice but you do know the person who brought this to my attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you say, Senator Harradine, there is a remote thread of relevance. You would understand that there is no way I can make any comments about this case without knowing the details of it. I will make sure that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) is advised of this situation. The minister has made it absolutely clear on a number of occasions—and I reiterate the advice—that there is no intention on his part or on the part of the department to encourage people to get divorced.

PARA.TAB: If this is being said, again I think it is something about which we need to remind the minister. I can understand that people might sometimes say, `If you were divorced, this is how it would go' and people have taken that as encouragement to get a divorce. I suppose you could see it as sometimes providing full information. If people understand that to mean they are being encouraged to get divorced, the minister must make it absolutely clear to all his officers that that is not what he meant. If it is still happening in the offices, he must make it clear that that is not the intention of this government.

I do not want to go through the case that you have mentioned, Senator Harradine, but it does not take too much imagination to know that this pretty heroic woman, who is trying to cope with a fairly dreadful series of challenges in her life, is not at all assisted by being told, `If you get divorced from this man you have a marriage with, or a commitment to, you will be better off.' If that is the best we are providing by way of information, it is heartless in the extreme and contrary to this government's intentions under the legislation.

I will certainly make sure that the minister is again reminded and see whether there is anything he would further want to do in establishing whether or not such advice is given but, even more importantly, make it clear that that is not what this government intends under this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have all appreciated the case example that has been put because it makes very real the kind of legislation we are debating. While the relationship of Senator Harradine's query to the part of the bill we are discussing has been called tenuous—and I think he has even acknowledged that fact to a certain degree—I think it is relevant. I would like to build on the relevance of it.

PARA.TAB: The section of the bill we are debating is basically one where the department is raising the capacity to provide for the raising of a debt to the Commonwealth under certain circumstances in which people are paid amounts of money to which they are not entitled. It has been pointed out that this can be a highly difficult proposition for some people who have been in the position of the woman who was being discussed earlier, and who should be a symbol of what we are trying to do in being more fair with our social security legislation.

It was actually the Welfare Rights Centre that pointed out the inequity of raising a debt action against a person when the miscalculation was the fault of the Department of Social Security either by way of not processing client provided information or miscalculating rates of payment. Clearly, such a situation cannot stand.

To be fair to the Department of Social Security, it has pointed out that where a person in good faith continues to receive a payment to which they are not entitled and does not inform the Department of Social Security of relevant changes there is no mechanism to raise a debt under the act as it now stands. However, under the act, as it would be amended as we are discussing today, raising a debt administratively and pursuing recovery would be two separate steps of the process. Where the client has acted in good faith and the fault lies with the Department of Social Security, debt recovery would not be pursued.

It is this whole basis of putting people into an indebted situation that leads to the kinds of concerns generated by people in the position that Senator Harradine has cited. That is the point I really want to make the connection with because, while there is a difference between the actual amendment and the position that is being presented here and that of debt recovery, the minute people get into an indebted situation they fall into the same dilemma that has been vividly illustrated.

In the case where a client has provided information which has not been acted on, the new provisions would allow that the debt would start accumulating at the end of the notification period during which the change of circumstances occurred, not on the day after the change occurred. This is provided as some sort of incentive for people to report changes. Once again, the Welfare Rights Centre points out that not only would it be unjust for the Department of Social Security to be able to raise a debt against a person when the mistake has been made by the Department of Social Security, but such a provision could also lead to a slackening of the DSS internal controls if raising a debt becomes so much easier and holds no backlash for the officer raising the debt.

The DSS has been arguing that in a situation where the client does not notify the changes—which would now result in a debt being raised—this provision will provide an incentive for DSS to be more diligent because the means of recovery would be available. It is using a structural and system based approach. I believe that we need to look at it from the client perspective. We ought to be considering the situation in which we are assisting the department to have a technical capacity to make people indebted. Even though we are not considering the recovery process—and we have some guarantees from the department that, where it is at fault, it will not pursue the matter—the very principle that we are instituting is one of indebtedness to people who may not deserve to have the debt placed against them. For this reason the Greens will be opposing this measure.

PARA.TAB: I wish to correct something I said during the second reading debate. But I do not apologise for the fact that they should have addressed the issue. It is an issue in which the coalition considers that there needs to be safeguards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 140 allows the DSS secretary to waive recovery of debts of a particular class that is specified by the minister by notice published in the Gazette: for example, small debts which are deemed to be not worth chasing. The opposition amendment would make the minister's notice a disallowable instrument to provide some parliamentary scrutiny—this is very important—over which types of debt the department is writing off. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment.

—The government proposes to introduce a data-matching program that will match the income records of people in non-PAYE employment with the Department of Social Security records. Any matches that reveal evidence of a possible debt because of a failure to notify receipt of income, for example, will be investigated and, where appropriate, the department will take action to recover the debt and to reduce or cancel the social security payment.

PARA.TAB: Before the data-matching program begins, the government will offer an amnesty, known as a special arrangement, to those people affected or likely to be affected by the program. The amnesty is proposed to offer people who have failed to advise the Department of Social Security about their income from employment the opportunity to inform the department of their true circumstances without fear of prosecution or debt recovery action. Any information provided to the department throughout the duration of the amnesty period, which will probably be about three months, will be assessed to reduce or cancel the social security payment being received if necessary.

If the amendment as proposed by the opposition is passed, it will mean that the parliament may decide to disallow the notice under proposed subsection 1237AB(1) of the Social Security Act 1991. TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are drawing a very long bow there. TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995 contains several separate provisions. There are, in fact, five main provisions, each of them different from the others. The first one deals with amendments to detention procedures; the second with the migration agents registration scheme; the third with passenger entry cards; the fourth with the repeal of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992; and the fifth with amendments to the Immigration (Education) Act 1971. The coalition will not be opposing the migration bills. We support most of the provisions in the bills, but there are some comments I want to make about certain aspects along the way.

PARA.TAB: So far as the first of the issues is concerned—that is, amendments to detention procedures—the Senate will recall that in February 1994 the Joint Standing Committee on Migration tabled its report entitled Asylum, Border Control and Detention. Two of the main recommendations of that report were recommendations 10 and 11. Recommendation 10 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: unauthorised border arrivals who claim refugee status be held in detention during the determination of their status, including during administrative processing, administrative review and any legal appeals, but that there be a capacity to consider release where the period of detention exceeds six months.
Recommendation 11 reads:

in cases where unauthorised border arrivals who claim refugee status have been held in detention for more than six months, and the continued detention has been brought about by a lack of action or administrative error by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in accordance with the Minister's powers under the Migration Reform Act 1992, give consideration to including such detained asylum seekers in a prescribed class of detention non-citizens eligible for the grant of a bridging visa, which secures release from detention.
The recommendation went on to say:
In considering whether to include in the prescribed class all or any such detainees, the Minister have regard to the following factors:
.whether the applicant has a special need based on age, health, or previous experiences of torture and trauma;
.whether the applicant has satisfied appropriate health, character and security checks;
.the likelihood that the applicant would abscond if granted a bridging visa;
.whether there is a reasonable basis for the applicant's claim to refugee status;
.the timeliness of the lodgement of the application for refugee status;
.the extent to which the applicant co-operated with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the provision of information relevant to the applicant's claim;
.whether there will be adequate support arrangements if the applicant is released into the community; and
.Australia's international obligations.

This part of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) now before the Senate seeks to implement recommendations 10 and 11 by providing the minister with a non-delegatable, non-compellable discretion to declare a person eligible for release if certain conditions are met. The provisions of the bill will ensure that only those illegal entrants who have been detained for more than six months due to the failure of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to process their applications or determine their status in that time, will be eligible for release.

PARA.TAB: Another aspect of these amendments to the detention procedures which I think is not unimportant, is that those unlawful non-citizens who remain in detention after their cases have been fully determined by the department and by the other processes that are available because they seek judicial review, will not be part of the release provisions. That is an aspect with which the coalition agrees. In respect of these provisions of the bill, the coalition has no difficulties.

The second part of the bill relates to the migration agents registration scheme, commonly known as MARS. The bill seeks to extend by one year, until September 1996, the operation of the present provisions to allow the government time to consider and respond to another report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and to provide time for the passage of any relevant legislation.

The other report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration covered the inquiry into the operation of the migration agents registration scheme. That inquiry was conducted earlier this year. I think the report was tabled in the Senate in May or June. The committee recommended in the report that the scheme be extended for a three-year period so that its operation could be further examined. The registration scheme has only been in operation since 1992. It was subject to High Court challenge for most of that period. It is only relatively recently that that challenge has been removed in the sense of the High Court's decision to throw out the challenge to the validity of the scheme.

The scheme has been operating freely without challenge on a small time scale. It was the view of the committee and certainly the strong view of the coalition that the jury is still out in many respects on the operation of the migration agents registration scheme. More time is required to assess how worthwhile it is and how appropriate it is. The committee recommended an additional three years of operation because it did not think there had been sufficient time to judge whether the scheme, as a long-term proposition, was the most desirable to meet the necessary objective of achieving a competent and efficient migration agents system within which the professionalism and integrity of the participants is of the highest order. I think there is total agreement on that objective. The question is how best to get there and whether the scheme, as it presently operates, is the most desirable.

Under the existing legislation, the scheme is due to end in September. Therefore, if it is to continue, it is necessary to have an extension. The government is going for a one-year extension. From the way the legislation is drafted and from what the minister has said in relation to the reasons for extension, it intimates that a decision is still to be taken by the government as to what might happen beyond September 1996. It would certainly be the case with a coalition government by that time that we would want to carefully look at all aspects of the scheme before deciding what, if anything, to do about it in the future.

The third aspect of the bill before us relates to passenger cards. The bill seeks to add more flexibility to the required questions on the passenger card. If the bill is passed, in future the questions will not be limited to topics stipulated in the Migration Act. At present, the Migration Act states that questions regarding a non-citizen's health, criminal record, purpose of visit and the like, including any unpaid debts to Australia and any previous deportations or removals from Australia or another country, are exclusively required to be asked. Questions outside that range cannot be asked. The government is seeking more flexibility in relation to the possible questions that it may ask and, according to the department, that is necessary. We have had discussions with the department and we accept the proposition at this stage that this provision is an acceptable one—in other words, one which will add more flexibility.

The passenger card is one of the security measures used to protect our borders. It is filled out by inbound non-citizens and collected for use at immigration clearance at the port of entry. Many changes are occurring in the whole processing of the entry of non-citizens to Australia. I am sure that there will be many more changes in the future. Elements of that, including the whole question of our universal visa system, are being examined at the moment by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and, I am sure, by the government. I am sure that we will be seeing more changes of this nature in future. It is something that we need to keep a close watch on so that we enable the necessary flexibility to be built into the system whilst, at the same time, having a system which enables us to have confidence in the integrity of our border entry provisions.

The fourth item in the bill is the repeal of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992. With the implementation of the provisions of the Migration Reform Act 1992 on 1 September 1994, the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 also came into effect. The tax imposed under this act was intended to serve as an incentive for visa overstayers to come forward at an early stage to regularise their status. The tax act imposes a tax on an application for a visa made by an unlawful non-citizen who has been unlawfully present in Australia for a period or periods adding up to at least 12 months. The minimum amount of tax imposed is $3,000 a year for each year that the person has been unlawful at the time of the application for a visa.

The department and the minister claim that it has subsequently become apparent since the introduction of the act which, as I say, only took effect from 1 September 1994, that this intention may not have been achieved through the act and that in some cases the tax may even act as a deterrent to illegals coming forward. I would have thought that that was blindingly obvious to anyone.

In the explanatory memorandum to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995 it was stated that this objective was better achieved through other legislative and procedural mechanisms. So the bill seeks to repeal the tax act and if any tax has already been collected it will be refunded to the taxpayer, but the advice I have received is that no-one has as yet paid the tax.

The coalition does not oppose this provision. However, I think it is yet another example of legislative incompetence by the minister and by his department. The act has only been operating since 1 September 1994. The bill that we are now debating came into the House of Representatives in March of this year, so within a period of six months or less the government decided that the act is inappropriate and needed repealing. If such a short period was required to make that judgment, then there was obviously something wrong with the whole process in the first place.

Finally, the fifth element of the bill before us is amendments to the Immigration (Education) Act 1971. Due to what is described as an unintended oversight, certain visa classes created on 1 November 1993 may have been given a statutory entitlement to 510 hours of free English language tuition. The bill intends to remove this entitlement prospectively upon enactment. However, I understand approximately 100 people have already accessed such classes and will have such access revoked but not be required to refund the cost of the course.

The government states that this was an unintentional oversight. That may well be the case. However, it is difficult to understand why the applicants under the 818 or 816 categories needed English training at all, given that one of the requirements for the granting of an 818 or 816 visa was the passing of an English test. So, whilst we do not disagree with the proposal, again it does seem an act of incompetence on the part of the department and the minister that this is necessary at all. It also raises the question of the appropriateness of the entry criteria which have been required of some of the special visa groups, in particular 816 and 818. Having said those things, I reiterate that the coalition will be supporting the bill before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995. The bill has a number of purposes. One of the main ones is to allow the release from detention of people whose migration status has not been promptly dealt with. The bill will amend the Migration Act 1958 to enable a person who has been held in detention for more than six months following a visa application to be declared, at the minister's discretion, an `eligible non-citizen' so that he or she may be released from detention. I note that the WA Greens intend to move an amendment to reverse that onus, to in fact make the release automatic unless the minister objects to it as a matter of public interest. I believe that approach has a lot of merit.

PARA.TAB: The bill also limits the circumstances in which people will be entitled to free English language tuition. It seeks to amend the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 to make it clear that the Commonwealth is not obliged to provide such tuition to certain visa applicants who already enjoy a high proficiency in the English language. I would put on record the Australian Democrats' view that this is eminently sensible but, if that in any way provides some resources which would otherwise have been used in this area, then there seems to me a good case for increasing the number of hours of tuition being provided to people who have not got that particular proficiency. The Australian Democrats certainly believe that recent restrictions that have been introduced in this area are ill advised, and we would call on the government to increase the provision of English language tuition and reduce the cost to people who have not got the proficiency in the language.

The bill also provides for the retrospective repeal of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications Tax) Act 1992 from 1 September 1994. This was a tax on the visa applications of people who had remained in Australia unlawfully for more than a 12-month period. However, given its lack of use, the tax is being repealed, and the Democrats have no problems with it.

The bill makes other technical amendments with respect to assent and proclamation of certain legislation, and alters the commencement dates of other bills currently before parliament. These changes reflect the slow passage of migration bills in recent sitting periods, and I make no further comments on these provisions. Apart from the points I have raised, the Australian Democrats will be supporting this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated earlier to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) that I should probably come off this list of speakers. I apologise if I have caused any inconvenience. I am in quite a degree of puzzlement as to which number bill we are referring to.

—Yes, I know. And the reason my name appears on this list is that there was an error; we thought that it was No. 5 of 1994. I will not use my speaking rights at this point; I will speak to the later bill for which I am prepared, and in the committee stage, if necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
