TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for creating a precedent in respect to his position on these bills, but I would like to suggest that I have been verballed to some extent as well.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 1, page 3, item 5, omit proposed paragraph 72(2)(c).
2.Schedule 1, page 3, item 5, after proposed subsection 72(2), insert the following subsection:

"(2A) Where paragraphs (2)(a), (b) and (d) apply to a non-citizen, the Minister must make a determination under paragraph (1)(c) that the non-citizen is an eligible non-citizen if the non-citizen has been in immigration detention for a period of 6 months or more after the application for a protection visa was made, unless the Minister thinks that the determination would be contrary to the public interest.".
3.Schedule 1, page 4, item 5, after proposed subsection 72(4), insert the following subsection:
"(4A) If the Minister does not make a determination under subsection (2A), he or she is to cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a statement that:

TAB.TAB: (a)sets out that the determination has not been made; and
(b)sets out the Minister's reasons for thinking that the determination would be contrary to the public interest.".

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Schedule 1, page 4, item 5, proposed subsection 72(6), after "subsection (4)", insert "or subsection (4A)".
5.Schedule 1, page 4, item 5, omit proposed subsection 72(7).

All these amendments relate to the central principle of the determination that a person is an `eligible non-citizen'. This relates back to the recommendations of the committee to which Senator Short referred earlier. As Senator Short and the chairman would be aware, at the time the decision was made that there would be mandatory detention for non-citizens who were not considered to be eligible for bridging visas I made very clear in a dissenting report that I considered that the mandatory period of six months was far too long and that it should be a much shorter period of time.

PARA.TAB: The particular change that has been made in this bill is that, after that six-month period has expired, the minister should have the discretion to be able to make that person into an eligible non-citizen, that is, a person who may be able to make an application for a protection visa. The purpose of the amendments already foreshadowed by Senator Spindler is to reverse the onus or burden of proof of that. We are asking the minister to make that determination in cases where he thinks the person should not have release and to have the principle of automatic release for everybody else after that six months. I have not got any illusions about the degree of support that change can expect in this chamber, but I would be very encouraged if it did receive more support than I understand it will gain.

Basically, what I am saying on behalf of the Greens is we understand that there are some reasons for detaining people who arrive as asylum seekers and refugees on our shores, to make certain of their identity and to look at certain health and quarantine matters. The fact that we are imprisoning—by our detention—young children, elderly people and people who may be in need of medical care, and putting them in situations that may well be replicating the situations of torture and trauma that they have experienced and from which they are fleeing, is something that we in Australia should be very concerned about.

The idea of six months of that is, in my view, intolerable. I am ambivalent about even supporting this bill with that capacity. However, I am forced to do that as the minister should be able in some situations to make sure, in the public interest, that people are not released. What I am wholeheartedly hoping for is that those who are no threat whatsoever in the community and who are in the process of being assessed for their refugee status should certainly be released into the community to those community agencies that have expressed the view that they would be glad to support them.

Basically, the thrust of this amendment is that, unless the minister thinks that a release would be contrary to the public interest, that release would be an automatic one. I am glad that Senator Spindler in his speech in the second reading debate foreshadowed some support for that notion. I would urge that this chamber consider it, look even further at what Australia is doing by its mandatory detention for such a long period as six months and support the use of a bridging visa, not only for humane reasons, but also for the practical ones which seem to carry more sway in this day and age with both the government and the opposition.

Such reasons would include the economics of keeping people in detention when there are community resources available to assist them at far less cost. They could stay in a place where they could actually be nurtured and supported, where they could look at their future and even cope with negative decisions, if necessary. They would also be prepared in a better way than by simply moving from one difficult situation, one of fleeing their home country, to another, detention and maybe even return.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are of the view that the government should choose a different option from the detention option that it is currently pursuing with such vigour. We believe that people seeking asylum should be released into the care of responsible community organisations, mostly church based organisations, which are prepared to accept responsibility for these people and which can assist them in their quest to stay in Australia and, more particularly, to overcome the trauma that clearly they have suffered in fleeing their country of origin and seeking asylum in Australia. It would be a much more humane policy to follow. While there may be some isolated exceptions to that rule, it is a rule that I believe Australian citizens would want our government to follow.

PARA.TAB: These amendments moved by Senator Chamarette go some way towards that by putting a limit on the detention that the government is implementing. I think it is eminently sensible for the government to allow people, after six months detention, to be released into the care of responsible community organisations and to stop that only if there are public interest considerations which would militate against that course of action. For that reason, the Democrats will be supporting the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) needs to explain to the committee why the amendments moved by Senator Chamarette should not be accepted. I would have thought they meet certain criteria which the government has set for itself in relation to its approach to asylum seekers and its obligations under the refugee convention.

PARA.TAB: The refugee convention imposes an obligation on this country, and every other signatory country, to give protection to those persons who have a well-founded fear of persecution on the grounds of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group. It is to be determined whether that is a well-founded fear. But we have people coming to the country, asylum seekers, many of whom have gone through enormous sufferings to get here. And what happens to them? They are locked up in detention centres up on the isolated north-west coast of this continent, far from any possibility of their communicating in their own language with people who may be sympathetic towards them.

I am not criticising in any way the officers of the department. That is not the point. The point of these amendments is that if there is to be detention—and, as has been expressed around the chamber thus far, this is a second-best alternative to those people being cared for by certain community groups or released to certain community groups who would be responsible for them whilst their application is being heard—and the period of detention is for a period of more than six months, the detainee should then be released into the custody of community organisations.

As has been indicated—and we have all heard from those organisations—they are prepared to assist. They are prepared to give succour to the people until such time as those asylum seekers are determined to have a well-founded fear of persecution on any one of those five grounds. That, as has been indicated by Senator Chamarette, should appeal to the government's and the opposition's economic sensibilities, and, indeed, to all of our sensibilities, when it comes to taxpayers' money. It will save taxpayers' money.

It is up to the minister. If the minister thinks this determination would be contrary to the public interest, then these amendments proposed by Senator Chamarette will enable the minister to make a determination and have it tabled in the parliament to set out why the determination has been made and to set out the minister's reasons for thinking that the determination would be contrary to the public interest—that is, to say the release into custody would be contrary to the public interest. I think this is an eminently reasonable proposal that has been put forward. I would like to hear what the minister has to say, but it certainly appeals to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just go to the issues of the amendment and place on record that what the government is doing here is, in fact, implementing recommendations 10 and 11 of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report on asylum, border control and detention. In saying that, let me place on record that we have had a process of looking at the detention policy. You, Mr Temporary Chairman McKiernan, chaired that committee and the opposition, of course, were part of that committee as well, as were other parties represented in this place.

PARA.TAB: During your deliberations and at the end of it you recommended that we do certain things and, in respect to detention, they are the things that we are picking up in the government's legislation on this particular point—recommendations 10 and 11.

In reading your report and reading the evidence before you, I think it is fair to say that the view the committee took was one that acknowledged our international obligations and acknowledged that what we are doing here is in accordance with that. You also acknowledged the standard of services in detention centres, and let me say there that they are not just acknowledged within Australia and by your committee; they are acknowledged internationally in terms of the services we provide for people whilst they are awaiting decisions.

Most importantly, in terms of your deliberations and the parliament having deliberated on this particular issue in the past, there has been an acceptance, I think by a broad cross-section, though not unanimous in this place—and the legislation spells it out—that it is very much in Australia's national interests to have the detention policy that we have. They are our starting points and, as I say, we are picking up your recommendations.
Senator Chamarette is moving amendments somewhat in line with her dissenting report to the inquiry, but that dissenting report was one the government has not accepted.

Can I just in this context mention one other thing, and I think it is important to place this on record. I said just a few seconds ago that there is recognition of the way that people are handled in the Australian detention system. It is recognition which is unanimous, I suppose, internationally—almost unanimous—from the bodies who work in this area, UNHCR, whether it is regional or from Geneva, the Red Cross and whatever; they all have access and they all make judgments. The judgments made about how we do it here stand, I think, our processing system in good light.

I would like to read and maybe incorporate in Hansard a letter which was sent to me towards the end of last year from the Refugee Council of Australia. I think it is important to place this on record not just as an endorsement of what the government is doing, because I do not think you would expect it to do that totally, but in recognition of how the processes have developed over the last few years—and a recognition which needs to be placed on the record too, in essence, given the picture of how processing and how our policies are impacting on people.

It is a letter to the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald and I am not so sure that it actually got run in the end—I don't think it did. But the relevant parts of this letter from Margaret Piper commenting on an article by Padriac McGuiness, `Boat people and the law', state:

SPEECH.PARA: Readers would be forgiven for thinking that he has followed the recent developments in this sensitive area. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The picture he paints is a distorted and anachronistic situation, far removed from current reality. Driven by bias and misinformation, he ignores both the complexity of the situation and the major developments that have taken place in the last two years.
It is true to say that there were major problems with the Department of Immigration's handling of refugee status determination processes two years ago but not so today.
Of course, there is room to argue about both those points, but it worth placing them on the record. The letter continues:
To call them "Policeman Plods" and accuse them of "insensitivity to the issues" is ignoring the major and hard won advances that have taken place.
Determination procedures have been made fairer and more rigorous and major advances have been made in the area of access to welfare and medical assistance.

To accuse the advocates of using "propaganda" and "blackmail" is equally offensive and similarly removed from reality. Refugee advocates use the legal process that exists to ensure that the law is upheld and the rights of their clients are preserved. Two years ago this brought them into regular conflict with the government, but here too things have changed because there is widespread recognition amongst advocates that things are changing for the better.
She concludes by saying:

If Paddy wishes to preach, let him at least get his facts straight. No one wins from his biased piece. Not the bureaucrats who are striving to make things better, not the advocates whose pressure have helped to make these changes happen, not the asylum seekers whose lives depend on the efficiency of the system and certainly, not the public who are being "duped by this ridiculous media portrayal".

I read that letter out to put on the record the assessment, which relates to how things have changed, of an independent body which is more often than not critical of government. That assessment is very much in line with our international reputation on how we handle people here.

PARA.TAB: I say in conclusion that the spirit of cooperation between government and opposition senators, which is reflected in your report, Senator McKiernan, is something that is not often seen in inquiries but is something for which the government is quite grateful. The cooperation we have received from the opposition on these issues is in the national interest. I seek leave to have this letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to the minister's comments and ask a question. The minister would be aware that I am member of the Joint Committee on Migration that he referred to. I acknowledge that Senator McKiernan, who at the moment is acting as Temporary Chairman of the Committee of the Whole, is the chairman of the committee that was given the task of looking at the difficulties surrounding the detention of those people who are asylum seekers. It was also given the task of discovering whether we are really in breach of our international commitments by actually detaining people in a prison-like setting when they could be found to be refugees who have fled their countries for very justified reasons and who have already experienced torture and trauma and therefore deserve asylum rather than be subjected to a repeat of that trauma.

PARA.TAB: From my memory of the committee's discussions, all of the committee members, even those who felt that a period of mandatory detention was the appropriate response to people who come to our shores without identification papers or authorisation, felt that more than six months of detention was undesirable. Some people expressed extreme repugnance that it was the outcomes of court cases that seemed to extend that detention.

I remind the minister that, even though the report made the recommendation for a six-month mandatory detention period, there was a clear understanding that that was to be the maximum period. If it was to extend beyond that—and that would be the fault of the department—it was clearly undesirable.

From my point of view, even though the minister stated that this bill deals with the recommendations of that committee, it was not necessarily part of that recommendation that the six-month mandatory detention period be a minimum amount which can be automatically extended. It was clearly the reverse—that more than six months was undesirable. What we are debating here is the mechanism by which we determine that period. That is the point the amendment is addressing.

It is really very important that the people who are still in detention are the responsibility of the minister. He should be aware of those who have stayed in detention for more than six months and he should not just be able to assume that the whole of the detention is valid no matter how long it lasts.

I would like to ask the minister a question and then complete my comments after foreshadowing it. How many of the people who are in detention at the present moment have been there for longer than six months? It is very important that this parliament be aware of that fact and know the kinds of numbers about which we are speaking.

I also want to mention that the quality of care in detention centres in Australia is not an issue here. Far be it from me to criticise the attempts that all the people who have been involved in this difficult problem have endeavoured to bring to that situation. It is not a question that there is any criticism implied here about the quality of care, but neither is it the point.

I have visited a Hong Kong detention centre and seen the conditions there. I have visited Port Hedland on two occasions—once in the early days when there were some difficulties in the regime there and people were suffering quite considerably from them and again when people were much happier with the way in which the whole program was being administered. I have no complaints whatsoever about that. However, it was very noticeable when I went back and the conditions were improved that the psychological distress of the people under detention was actually worse than it was when the conditions were bad.

The reason for the change, in a way, is that not having enough cutlery or crockery, it being very hot or having difficult situations with supervision, et cetera, distracted people from their own internal distress as to what they were going through. When they received very fair and good handling, the real distress from which they were suffering was more apparent to the rest of us. We could see that the pure psychological impact of detention on people who have already come here in a distressed situation was what we should be concerned about as well as the humanitarian impact of detention on those people.

I would disassociate myself from any criticisms of what is being done. I am critical of the fact that this parliament is in a position to say to people, `Anything more than six months is undesirable, and if that period comes around it should be possible for a bridging visa to be given.' The purpose of this amendment is really to put the onus of that onto the minister so that if there is anyone who, for public interest reasons, should not be released, it is in his hands and he will know that person.Therefore, we can be sure that we are not contributing to an out-of-sight out-of-mind situation.

Each person who has been held in detention for more than six months will be somebody of whom the minister is aware because he will have actually laid before each house of parliament a statement as to why a determination has not been made to release them into the community's care and support which would help them to adjust to whatever the decision may be. The statement will set out the minister's reasons for the determination and for the public interest aspects involved in it. That will prevent us from escaping our responsibilities.

It will also, I believe, fulfil the spirit of the recommendation of the committee. While it decided that six months was an appropriate period of time—and I have already said that I was not happy that it was such a long period of time—in my recollection of what took place there was an understanding that anything longer than six months was inappropriate. By reversing this, we will know who has been in there for longer than six months so it can be brought before this parliament and assessed. That will mean that nobody will be overlooked, there will not be any oversight, and we will actually be carrying out our responsibilities as an international citizen in relation to refugees and asylum seekers in a far better and more responsible fashion.

So I ask the minister: how many people are we talking about here? Why is it that we cannot actually allow the bridging visa to be an automatic measure after six months, with those who are not eligible to be clearly notified to the parliament and for the minister to have the capacity to make the determination and give us the reasons for it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure Senator Chamarette and the committee that people who have entered Australia illegally are not out of sight or out of mind. These people take up a lot of my time and attention as well as that of my office, the department and this parliament. My gripe is that I wish we could spend as much time talking about the benefits and the contributions made to Australia by the people who come here legally. We spend a lot of time on people who come here, make an application for asylum status, fail, and then protactedly draw out the system. They are not forgotten people. They are very much there and they receive the attention of both sides of parliament as well as the minor parties and the non-parties, including Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that six people from the boat Pluto have been in detention for more than six months. Those people have made visa applications but have not as yet received a primary decision. Others who have a right to make a claim for asylum status are not in detention. I assure Senator Chamarette that we do not ignore these people. We have obligations under the legislation, as well as international obligations, and we are pretty dinkum about trying to meet them. We do that. This parliament fulfils its role as part of the Australian political system in relation to this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure all of us would be absolutely delighted if only six people were being detained. I am supported in my amendment because it would be quite easy to detail the names of those six people to the parliament and have us aware of them. We will be grateful when the numbers are diminished to the situation where no-one is in detention. I cannot believe that only six people have been detained for more than six months in either the Curtin detention centre or the Port Hedland detention centre. I would be grateful if the minister would give us the total number of people who are detained in those places. We need to know that there is no-one in Australia who has been detained in a detention centre for more than six months. Could the minister elaborate on that? How many people are in detention? Presumably the information we will receive is that anyone who is detained has been there for less than six months.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been verballed again. There are six people who have made a valid protection visa application after arrival. These people have been detained for more than six months, they have a right to make an application, but they have not as yet received a primary decision. Those people will benefit under the clause before us which is consequential to the recommendation of the joint standing committee.

PARA.TAB: We all know that quite a number of people have come into Australia who either do not have the right to seek asylum status or who, having exercised that right, have failed in either the primary application or on review. Those people are also in detention. We are talking about 639 people at the moment. Of those, 465 are affected by the safe third country legislation. It is worth placing on record that already 325 people have been returned to China. We are working with the Chinese authorities on verification in respect of the remaining 465 people.

It is important to note that people can prolong their stay in detention by choosing to pursue avenues of appeal through the tribunal or through actions in the court. It is worth placing on record that on an average the department now takes some five to six weeks to process a primary application from a boat person in detention who has a right to make one. The Refugee Review Tribunal now gives priority to people who are in detention and on average the tribunal takes less than eight weeks to finalise a case.

That is so far so good; on the other hand, litigation is something we have no control over. It can take quite some time and it can be expensive. Many boat people have decided to take legal action when they have disagreed with decisions. Of course, there are people in detention at the moment who are going through that process of taking us to the Full Court of the Federal Court or to the High Court—a right which, because of our constitutional structure, if for no other reason, cannot be denied to people within Australia.

I take you back to the point that a primary decision normally takes, on average, five to six weeks and the RRT, on average, takes less than eight weeks to finalise a case. But, of course, there are people in detention who are appealing further or who have no right to seek asylum status—and they are the ones who come under the process with China.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. It is very good to have the full picture. While I will put off the major debate as to what happens to those 639 people while they are in detention, I repeat the point that, if there are only six people being considered at this moment in time under the particular parts of this legislation, then there is even more reason to support the amendments that the Greens have put forward. I could have expected the minister to say, `Senator Chamarette, this is a very burdensome responsibility. I will have to set out my reasons why any of these people may not be released.' But, if it is setting out his reasons why six out of that number have not been given their bridging visa, then I think the argument has been removed.

PARA.TAB: While I think it is a tragedy that it is only such a small number—if it is this number of people—who have even the capacity to be eligible for this, on the other hand it provides the best argument whatsoever for having that automatic provision for release after that six-month period unless the minister exercises his discretion and his right to say that it is not in the public interest to allow that to occur. I urge the opposition and the government to consider the validity of this, particularly in the light of the minister's response.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have much more to add to the comments I have made so far in respect of the government picking up the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Bolkus) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 [No. 2] makes certain amendments to the Migration Act retrospective to 1 November 1989 in an attempt to ensure that certain provisions of the act are consistent with what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, and his department claim are their previously understood effect. This bill has been re-presented to the Senate after its defeat in this place on 9 November 1994.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned on behalf of the coalition when the bill was debated last year, the bill is an attempt to deal with an issue that has plagued successive immigration ministers in this government. I stress the point that it is a problem entirely of the government's own making. It is only due to the fact that this incompetent government, and this incompetent minister, cannot get its legislation right that we have to keep revisiting issues such as this.

The coalition has recognised the government's dilemma and, at all times, has attempted to take a principled and responsible stance to its consideration of and its responsibilities in these matters. Our stance on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), this second time, continues in that vein. Although we will not oppose the passage of this bill on this second occasion, we will criticise and, where appropriate, seek to defeat or amend any legislation which we consider to be significantly or fundamentally flawed. Under this government we have seen this to an unprecedented degree.

One of the defining characteristics of Senator Bolkus's administration of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs—indeed, it goes back to the latter part of the administration by his predecessor, Mr Gerry Hand—has been his legislative incompetence. The saga of this bill is only one of many examples. It is staggering to note that there has been an average of five bills in each of the years of Senator Bolkus's administration of the portfolio which seek, in some way, to amend the Migration Act; that is, almost one bill for each month of sitting days that the minister has been in charge of this portfolio.

Secondly, the implementation of the Migration Reform Act—major changes to the whole of the migration system—was deferred for a period of almost two years because of difficulties that the government had in really getting its act together to achieve what it was trying to do legislatively. Even though the reform act's implementation was deferred for two years until September 1994, even with that extra time the department still could not provide the regulations to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in advance of their release as, I think I can accurately say, had earlier been promised.

Thirdly, there have been a large number of bills introduced by this government which have had to be amended by the Senate at the instigation of the coalition to ensure that they actually fulfil their stated purpose. Fourthly, we have seen the constant problem that the government has with its legislation being challenged in the courts. There are numerous examples of this. The bill now before the Senate is, by the Government Solicitor's own admission, likely to be challenged—in fact, almost certainly to be challenged—and quite possibly overturned by the courts.

We saw the High Court decision to dismiss an appeal by the minister for immigration against an adverse decision by the Federal Court over the interpretation of the department's own 273-day maximum period of detention for boat people. We also saw the government's difficulties over the definition of `refugee' and China's one-child policy. The minister's handling of that issue was all over the place from the start. Initially, in December 1994, he claimed that he was going to introduce urgent legislation to deal with the matter. However, the legislation he introduced was so poorly drafted that most witnesses appearing before the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee looking into the bill believed that, if enacted, the legislation would fail its stated purpose. They are just some of the examples of the incompetence that we have now come to recognise as flowing from this minister and from this government.

The events which have led to the creation of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3)—the bill now before the Senate—and the background to that bill are relevant to this debate. This aspect of the bill applies only to illegal border arrivals or boat people who were detained between November 1989 and May 1992. They were detained illegally, but according to the government this illegal detention was caused by a technical fault. The government's first attempt to solve the problem by limiting damages payable to those illegally detained to $1 per day of illegal detention was subject to constitutional challenge. The majority of opinion suggested that such a challenge would be successful.

This government has been plagued by such `technical' faults—to use its word—in the whole area of immigration law for a long time now. It is a matter of great concern that the government is continuing to run into these problems. It must say something about the method of preparation of proposals within the department, particularly the drafting of legislation. I think it is fortunate that the Senate is diligent in its examination of legislation to ensure that more mistakes do not get through the system than is now the case.

Detention policy and the onshore processing of asylum seekers alone have been plagued with costly technical errors. As I mentioned previously, the government was defeated last year on what has become known as the 273-day case. In that case the department misinterpreted the amount of time that this legislation allowed for lawful detention of illegal immigrants. That was compounded by the fact that it occurred after the commencement of the Migration Reform Act—an act which was meant to make Australia's detention policy much more watertight.

Further, in late 1994 the government's previous inaction and its blurred and inconsistent signals contributed very significantly to the arrival of hundreds of Sino-Vietnamese boat people who believed that, because they were getting such mixed signals from the government, one way or another they would be accepted in Australia for merely seeking a better life. The government had ample time to address that problem, yet either through incompetence or neglect it waited for the problem to escalate and to stretch to breaking point before any action was taken.

I have already mentioned the incompetent two-year delay in the implementation of the Migration Reform Act. Today we are dealing with yet another immigration portfolio disaster. By detaining some 450 illegal boat people without proper legal authority, the Keating government has potentially made the Australian taxpayer liable to a compensation bill of up to tens of millions of dollars. When this bill is passed, as I think it will be, it still appears likely to be subject to successful High Court challenge, if you can believe the government's own legal advisers.

To this point, the government has refused to pursue any avenues other than the legislative one, to solve its problem. Until now, the minister has claimed that section 54RA, the clause implemented by Migration Amendment Act (No. 4) 1992 which limits any compensation payable to $1 per day, has restricted them from entering into an out of court settlement with the plaintiffs. With the passage of this bill, that section will be removed, thus removing the impediment to settlement. I believe that is an avenue which the government should consider pursuing. An out of court settlement may indeed be the best way to address this issue and to save taxpayers' funds.

The coalition's original opposition to this bill was a protest against a bad legislative response by the government. The bill, at the time of its introduction 10 months ago, was claimed to be most urgent. The bill actually stemmed from another bill—namely, Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994—which was introduced more than a year ago and which was withdrawn and replaced by bill No. 3 for purely political reasons. That further delayed the consideration of what the government was trying to claim was urgent. This bill was originally defeated in November last year. The government has failed to have it debated until this late stage, despite its so-called urgency.

This is yet another example of the Keating government's inability to manage its Senate program. It is an indictment of Senator Bolkus, who has failed to ensure that this and several other migration bills are debated within a reasonable time.

The coalition's original decision to vote against the bill in November 1994 was made, on balance, because of its retrospectivity. As I have already mentioned, the bill had been introduced in an attempt to cover past policy and administrative failures by the Labor government. At the time, however, we were conscious—and said so—of other considerations, particularly the potential cost to the public purse if the bill were defeated, and the community concern about paying compensation to people who arrived in Australia illegally.

Since taking that original decision, we have all been made aware of growing community concern about what many people in the community perceive, rightly or wrongly, as rewarding illegal immigrants with compensation. We have also been made aware of increasing community concern generally in respect of arrivals by boat in recent times, many of whom do not prima facie appear to be genuine refugees. Although the recent arrivals of boat people have nothing to do with this bill, they have served to highlight strong community concerns about the integrity of our national borders and Australia's right to decide who can and cannot enter Australia.

In deciding, on balance, not to vote against the bill on this second occasion, we have taken account of the clearly expressed community views, particularly at this time when we are calling on the government to do much more to contain its expenditures. The government has its budget in one almighty mess. It is the single most significant problem facing the economic management of this country. It is incumbent on the government to do all that it can to reduce the horrendous budget deficit of more than $8 billion that it is inflicting on the Australian community this year. It is a budget that looks like blowing out still further as the year progresses.

Nevertheless, having said all that, we remain strongly concerned about the retrospectivity contained in this bill. We stressed and expressed that strong concern on the previous occasion when the bill was debated. I want to place that on the record. The strength of that concern as expressed on that previous occasion should be noted.

Although the coalition will not vote against the bill this time, I want to make it absolutely clear that we remain highly critical of the Keating government—and this Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in particular—for the legislative incompetence surrounding this whole issue of unlawful detention. I remind the Senate that it is through the Keating government's mishandling of Australia's immigration detention regime that it has exposed Australian taxpayers to the possibility of millions of dollars in compensation payouts. I repeat, in conclusion on this section of the bill, the hope that the government may now consider and work towards an out of court settlement on this matter. There is no technical reason, once this bill has passed, why that should not happen.

This bill also proposes to amend the Migration Act so as to stop the use of repeat applications for protection visas by non-citizens to delay their removal from Australia. The bill will effectively stop a person from making a repeat onshore application for the same protection visa whilst in Australia. The minister will, however, have the power to exercise non-compellable discretion in favour of allowing a particular individual to lodge a repeat application if he thinks it is in the public interest. This component of the current bill is a recent addition. It was originally attached to the government's ill-fated Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995, which I understand has now essentially been withdrawn.

The coalition will not be opposing the repeat application clause. We accept the arguments that have been put for it. We stated our support at the time, and that support has not changed. We are of the belief that applicants who have been unsuccessful in their applications for protection visas should abide by the umpire's decision and depart. We do not support the unlimited access to our onshore protection visa processing facilities. Such unfettered access would be a misuse of a very important and expensive program. We believe all applicants should be processed in accordance with the act and regulations, and any abuse of those regulations should be dealt with firmly.

At the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs public hearings on the original bill, several groups expressed concern that this will only lead to the limiting of access to Australia's processing system to applicants with genuine concerns. In such cases the minister has the ability to grant consent to repeat applications if he believes it to be in the public interest. We in the coalition believe that this is an adequate safety net to ensure that those applicants whose situations clearly change or who have fresh evidence may lodge a fresh claim. However, it would be reassuring to have the minister state in this place what he sees the relevant criteria for the initiation of these powers to be. On that voiceless note, I think I might cease. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust your voice will improve prior to the meeting of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in a short time, Senator Short. I, too, want to address Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). In doing so, I want to do something I very rarely do—that is, throw some bouquets across the chamber and thank my colleagues on the opposition benches for their support for this legislation. It is a sincere `thank you', and it is a `thank you' that I make on behalf of my constituents in Western Australia. Were Senator Panizza here, he would undoubtedly agree with me, as I am sure all West Australian senators would agree with me.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that has happened since this bill was debated previously in this chamber is that parliamentarians, from my state in particular, have felt a white heat from the electorate. When the opposition previously decided to oppose the earlier bill and allow for the possibility of a windfall gain to a large number of illegal migrants to this country it truly had sections of the population up in arms. I certainly felt the heat of it. I did not feel it as warmly as those colleagues of mine on the opposition benches because I supported the original bill. They rejected it, and in so doing left open the possibility of a $96 million windfall gain—and that is not a government estimate; that is an estimate made by one of the very vocal advocates of boat people in this country, Dr Mary Crock. She made that estimate in the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee.

I could let Senator Short seek to score some political points in debating this legislation here this afternoon. I would prefer not to do that. I did try to score some when we last debated. I think at that time I called for my colleague's resignation as the shadow spokesman on immigration. I am not going to repeat that. The magnanimity of this very important event that we will be witnessing here this afternoon hopefully when the bill is passed—which undoubtedly it will be with the weight of numbers in the chamber—tells me that we should all be good together, that we are today acting in the best interests of the electorate and of the community by blocking this possible windfall gain to people who did not have a right to be here in the first place. It is a very welcome decision, and I wholeheartedly applaud my opposition colleagues for their support for the bill.

In addressing the bill I want to make some comments about Western Australia, in particular, and Port Hedland, where the people are detained at the moment. I have said my bit about Port Hedland from time to time. I do not want to add my words so much as the words of a constituent about Port Hedland. I would like to read into the record a letter from a Ms Brenda Armstrong from Port Hedland dated 26 July this year which was printed in the Sydney Morning Herald. I do not know when it was printed; I do not have the reference on this bit of paper, but it is a very interesting letter. It relates to the content of the bill and to the whole issue of illegals arriving in this country. It is not particularly long. It is entitled "Port Hedland is not a `wilderness'":
I and many of the 13,000 residents of this multicultural town of Port Hedland are wondering how one gets the title `Justice', as in Justices Michael Kirby and Alistair Nicholson.
Justice, I thought, meant weighing up all the evidence and visiting the scene of the crime before making a judgment and passing sentence.

However, these Justices have, in the public arena, condemned our great town as being in `wilderness' and the Department of Immigration Reception Centre as `inhumane' and likened to `a concentration camp'.
I ask the Justices:
1. How many `inhumane concentration camps' send their detainees' children to a private Catholic school for their education?
2. How many `inhumane concentration camps' pay the detainees a weekly allowance and have the K Mart magazine delivered so they can buy whatever they like.
3. How many `inhumane concentration camps' are furnished, air-conditioned, well-maintained former BHP employees' homes, where they lived, without media interest, for almost 20 years?
4. How many `inhumane concentration camps', when the detainees have babies, send them to a hospital overlooking the ocean and put them in air-conditioned private wards with en-suites?
5. How many `inhumane concentration camps' provide televisions so the detainees can see themselves on TV when they revolt?

6. How many `inhumane concentration camps' have interpreters, nurses, doctors, dentists, psychologists and welfare workers to ensure the wellbeing of the detainees, also lawyers paid for by Legal Aid to try to get them out?
7. How many `inhumane concentration camps' take the detainees to the swimming pool and on other outings?

SPEECH.PARA: There is a short bit left in the letter. I probably will not have the time to read it. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
8. How many `inhumane concentration camps' take the detainees to one of the nine local churches to be married or baptised?

Yes, the Department of Immigration Reception Centre has a fence around it; but let us not forget, the `boat people' have purposely entered our country without any identification whatsoever, and until it can be established whether they are, in fact, some of the 200 million refugees around the world or just discontented citizens of another country trying to jump the queue, they are illegal immigrants.

All we ask is, can the do-gooders, who appear to know very little and are doing absolutely nothing, except getting a bit of attention for themselves, please stop denigrating our great town—with its position on the Indian Ocean and masses of palm trees and fragrant flowers (not a wilderness)—and the facilities supplied to the `boat people', and let us get on with the job at hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Brenda Armstrong,
July 26. Port Hedland (WA).

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the time. I will conclude my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will move to matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to bring to the Senate's attention the dilemma that some of my constituents in Western Australia find themselves in. Indeed, it is more than just a dilemma, it is a dire situation. This has its origins in the investment by a number of people in Western Australia in two schemes involving Century Insurance Ltd and Mineral Sands.

PARA.TAB: During the course of 1990 and 1991, approximately 65 investors in that state invested a total of $3.5 million in those two schemes, via Quentin Ward Investment Services. This matter has been the subject of some attention by the press; but I believe that this matter should not slip away unnoticed and that it behoves me, as a senator for Western Australia, to put to the Senate the plight that these people find themselves in.

The majority of these investors are elderly and they were investing funds to accommodate their retirement. It does not necessitate any explanation to convey the concern and anxiety that such a loss would cause people in that position. The investors I mentioned were introduced to these schemes by Mr Quentin Ward. As I understand it, he was a financial consultant who was known in the areas of the Avon Valley, Northam and Beverley, and the environs thereabouts.

The investment money in this instance was under direction in Australia to be placed with the CMI medical group—the Clerical Medical Investment Group—which is a large and respectable insurance company in the United Kingdom. This investment money did not reach its destination and, in fact, Century Insurance Ltd—the company I mentioned—proved to be a $1 company set up by a Mr Donald Davies in the Cook Islands. A number of complaints were made by the people concerned to the Australian Securities Commission in 1991 and 1992 when the fraud was realised. These complaints did not result in any action. Some 50 of these investors combined to form a group—the Quentin Ward Investors Action Group. As such, they instructed corporate investigators and asset recovery specialist group McLernon Group Ltd to carry out investigations on their behalf.

These investigations revealed that between 28 March 1990 and 5 November 1990, $2.1 million worth of funds were transferred from trust accounts under the control of Quentin Ward to trust accounts of, firstly, the New Zealand Guardian Trust Co. Ltd and, later, its wholly owned subsidiary NZI International Trustee Co. Ltd. Both accounts operated from a Sydney bank. The moneys were not disbursed as directed to the Clerical Medical Investment Group but, instead, were invested as follows: $1.2 million to either Don Davies or companies controlled by him; $669,000 to pay out 50 lapsed insurance policies with the CMI Investment Group; and $200,000, being the balance, paid to professional appointees of Don Davies, including an accountant in Hong Kong.

Furthermore, the CMI Investment Group—and you should remember that that was the group that these investors had directed should be the recipient of funds for the purposes of investment—had never at any stage had a business relationship with Century Insurance Ltd or Don Davies. Moreover, they had not given any authority for their name to be used in any brochures advertising for potential investment. That is crucial because it shows that the CMI Investment Group were not aware of this aspect of the investment which was going on.

The McLernon Group Ltd has now compiled two detailed reports which have concluded that some of the foreign companies who acted for and advised Century Insurance Ltd in Australia were not registered to do business in this country. Both of these detailed reports have been provided to the Australian Securities Commission, who advised in April 1995 that the matter would be handled by its Brisbane office. When the McLernon Group contacted the Brisbane office on 17 July 1995, that office declined to act and suggested that the complaint be dealt with by the Western Australian office of the ASC.

I am advised that a meeting between the ASC and the McLernon Group took place on 25 August 1995. That was a meeting set up at the invitation of the ASC. I am further advised that the Quentin Ward Investors Action Group wanted, and still wants, the ASC to investigate both New Zealand companies I mentioned for unlawfully doing business in Australia, contrary to the companies code; to investigate Century Insurance Ltd for unlawfully doing business in Australia; and to investigate the conduct of Don Davies in relation to Century Insurance, with particular reference to him holding himself out to be a director.

I am advised by the McLernon Group that, notwithstanding the merit of the complaint, it was advised that, due to the ASC's policy position and lack of resources, the matter would not be investigated. It has also been put forward that, as this matter is the subject of investigation by the Queensland fraud squad, it is better left to the Queensland police to investigate. As I understand it, the investigation in Queensland does not pertain to the matters that I raise today and relates to other activities of Mr Davies.

I do understand that the Quentin Ward Investors Action Group did make a complaint in December 1994 to the Queensland police, and that has resulted in this action. What is being sought is action by the ASC, because what we have here are the actions of two New Zealand companies operating out of Sydney, and Century Insurance, a company doing business in Australia, albeit it was registered in the Cook Islands.

I can only say that I am at a loss as to why the ASC will not take this matter any further—a matter which was first complained of some four years ago. Therefore, I call upon the minister representing the Attorney-General in the Senate: firstly, to either deny or confirm the merit of the complaints made by the Quentin Ward Investors Action Group; and, secondly, to confirm whether these complaints cannot be investigated due to government policy or lack of resources.

If it is the case that this matter cannot be investigated due to government policy, I call upon the government to tell the Senate, to tell the investors involved, what that policy is. I call upon the government to tell the Senate what the criteria is that is used in these instances. Which complaints are dealt with? Which complaints are not dealt with? Is there some sort of general policy that the government has put in place and which the ASC has to abide by?

As far as lack of resources is concerned, I would put it to the Senate that the government has to account to the people of Australia as to why it will not resource such an important area of law enforcement. We have here some 65 people who have lost $2.1 million, which they can ill afford to lose—money which was intended, in the main, for their retirement—and we have no action on behalf of the government.

I therefore call upon the Minister representing the Attorney-General in the Senate to give this his urgent attention and I call upon him to answer the questions that I have put. These questions certainly require answers if not for the community at large then formthe 65 Australians I have mentioned who have lost the money concerned—money, as I said, which was important for their retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity of the matters of public importance debate today to address the important issue of the implications of statehood for the Northern Territory and point out where a recent visit by a senior Australian Labor Party official to the Northern Territory, in fact the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, got it horribly wrong.

PARA.TAB: Usually, before a minister visits a particular electorate, he receives a brief from his own department on the issues that ought to very properly apply and that will arise in the course of that visit. On the occasion of Mr Beazley's visit this month to the Northern Territory he obviously did not read a departmental brief. In fact, we must question very seriously where he got his information. Mr Beazley got it horribly wrong. I must call into question, therefore, his credibility, particularly on telling the truth, and question whether that is a matter like the debate that has proceeded here in this parliament over the last week or so about Dr Carmen Lawrence, or whether it is about the Northern Territory's funding. It is very obvious that Mr Beazley is taking a lot of licence in not being very deliberative.

In talking to Fred McHugh, a senior journalist with the ABC, in Darwin on 17 August, Mr Beazley said two things about statehood that either foreshadow a drastic and dramatic change in established funding arrangements for the Northern Territory, or they indicate that he is getting very poor advice. Let me quote from that particular interview. Mr Beazley said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think I'd be very concerned in pressure for statehood that I wasn't moving too far ahead of Commonwealth commitment of resources. I think it would be unavoidable that were statehood to be achieved then there would be a consequence. You could not sit down with the other states and justify the level of subsidy in per capita here if statehood had actually been achieved.

That quote indicates two issues that need to be addressed: firstly, that the Northern Territory could not justify the level of per capita subsidy should statehood be achieved. This is nonsense since there is absolutely no connection between the two matters. The Northern Territory receives a higher level of federal funding not because of its constitutional status but simply because of territory and remote disabilities such as distance, disbursement of population, the high Aboriginal population and similar factors. Not one of these factors will be changed in the slightest by the grant of statehood.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the Australian Labor Party would start treating us territorians like another state financially and that would produce a very substantial reduction in federal resources. Let me quote Mr Beazley again:

SPEECH.PARA: I'd be careful about getting into a position where a finance minister like myself could sit down, and my successors as the years go by could sit down and say, `That's pretty cool, now we'll start treating them like another state.' That would produce a very substantial reduction in federal resources.

I do not know where Mr Beazley has been for the past seven years, but the Northern Territory has been treated like a state since 1988 when we were included in the pool of financial assistance grants. It is true that, much like the states, as a territory we have suffered continuing cuts from the Commonwealth over that period. But becoming a state will have no bearing whatsoever on whether such unjustified funding cuts continue. As territorians, we have just about given up on the Northern Territory's federal member, the quisling Mr Snowdon, who never acts or talks like a territorian.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! It is not parliamentary to refer to a member of the other chamber, or of this chamber, as a quisling. I ask Senator Tambling to withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the comment, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker. We certainly have no confidence whatsoever in Mr Snowdon as a federal member. He never acts or talks like a territorian when funding or statehood matters come up. In fact, he said recently, on 9 June:

SPEECH.PARA: The process of proceeding towards statehood for the Northern Territory is incidental to the process for getting to a republic and that's been made very clear.

It is altogether too much when the Deputy Prime Minister continues that line of drivel about statehood. Obviously, he took his brief on that particular day from Mr Snowdon and not from his own Department of Finance. Territorians can only hope that Mr Beazley will come back to Canberra to get briefed by his Department of Finance about the facts of Northern Territory funding.

PARA.TAB: This matter was raised in the Northern Territory parliament on the same day as the radio broadcast. A question was asked of the Minister for Constitutional Development in the Northern Territory, Mr Steve Hatton, and I take the opportunity to quote from Mr Hatton's response on that occasion. Mr Hatton said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . funding for the Northern Territory, under the Commonwealth/State tax-sharing arrangements, are now on the same formula base as that used in relation to every state in Australia. It is correct that we receive higher per capita funding, and as we all know in this House, or should know, that is because it costs a great deal more to deliver the same standard of service in many of the rural and remote, scattered communities of the Northern Territory, which is what the Grants Commission assesses. We are assessed for assistance under the same formula as every state in this country and, since 1988, the funding comes from the Commonwealth/State tax-sharing pool, not from a separate allocation of funding as is used in the early days. There are no differences in those financial relationships between us and the states.
Mr Hatton went on to say:

PARA.TAB: What amazes me is that somehow Mr Beazley . . . obviously does not understand that, which is a matter of some concern in a minister in the federal government or, if he does, he is deliberately lying and scaremongering in the Northern Territory. Either way, it is totally unacceptable to suggest in any way that there are any financial constraints to statehood.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only reiterate Mr Hatton's opinions, and I am concerned that Mr Beazley is revisiting the ALP scare tactics in the late 1970s before self-government was achieved for the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: This, of course, is most unfortunate and unnecessary. It is very much going to the issue that this parliament has been addressing in considerable detail this week about truth: in parliament, out of parliament, in the media and anywhere else, for that particular instance. The statements by Mr Beazley on this occasion give us a great deal of concern. Mr Beazley will quickly find that there is absolutely no connection with the statehood question and the funding question which he has raised by misusing the truth and getting off the proper bandwagon. I hope that he will set the record straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the seven years or eight years I have been here, very rarely have I spoken on a matter of public interest, but today I am prompted to speak on a matter of public interest that has been of quite some concern to parents right round Australia and, particularly, in my own state of Tasmania. I refer to the unfortunate circumstances caused by cystic fibrosis, and the fact that tomorrow the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is reconsidering its earlier decision to give controlled listing of pulmozyme in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This particular drug has shown, in some cases, that it has great potential in reducing the effects of cystic fibrosis, a very debilitating affliction, on young people. It has a marked effect on reducing the mucus blockages of about one-third of the cystic fibrosis patients, and that involves something like 800 to 1,000 Australians.

PARA.TAB: The drug company Roche Australia has indicated that it would be prepared to absorb the costs of the initial prescriptions to ensure that the listed drug can maximise its effectiveness. It is a very expensive drug—something of the order of $13,500. It would cost between $10 1/2 million and $13 1/2 million for the likely patient group within Australia.

As I said, this particular matter is going to be reconsidered by the PBAC tomorrow. I would like to quote from a few articles that have appeared in our local paper, the Hobart Mercury, where their health reporter, Mary Rose, has brought this to the attention of not just the public of Tasmania but to a lot of politicians. I was contacted by concerned general practitioners, namely, Dr Derek Mitchell, Dr John Saul and Tim Jackson from Lauderdale and Lindisfarne respectively and I have received many letters from constituents concerning the affordability of this drug. Yesterday in the Hobart Mercury I read an article which reminded me of a family's desperate plea earlier this year for access to this new drug. Verne and Clarence McCauley from Risdon Vale spoke out about their family's predicament in not being able to afford this particular drug. They made the point that the federal government has twice refused to put it on the free list and they said:
It did this despite recommendations from the Highly Specialised Drugs Working Party and a committee of cystic fibrosis medical experts.
A spokesman for the Federal Health Minister Carmen Lawrence said the drug was rejected for listing because there was no proof benefits lasted more than two months.

SPEECH.PARA: Exeter builder Mal Mackrill would probably disagree. Here is a case where a builder is virtually facing financial ruin to pay for this drug to help his 15-year-old son Aaron who has been so ill he has spent six of the last eight weeks in the Launceston General Hospital. Mr Mackrill is working seven days a week and spending about two-thirds of his income on providing this drug for his son. Luckily, since his son started using the drug, his condition has improved markedly. He is one of the hundreds of Tasmanians who have been writing to Tasmanian politicians. Senator Sherry may have received similar letters from some of his constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all on salmon at the moment.

—Well, it is rather serious. I also notice that Hobart schoolgirl Alice Bednall is one of the 70-odd people afflicted with cystic fibrosis in Tasmania. Just months ago this 16-year-old girl could not walk because this debilitating disease was causing her lungs to block up. Since she has had access to this particular drug, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: I couldn't run a marathon but I'm a hell of a lot better than I was.
There is plenty of evidence to suggest that in some cases this particular drug is of great importance.

PARA.TAB: Considering that the government, or Carmen Lawrence's office, has rejected this drug twice, I wonder what these people think when they read that the government, or ATSIC, is to spend $425,000 on building a house for an elected official on Thursday Island. I wonder what they think when they read that the taxpayers of Australia are going to spend up to $10,000 a day on defending Carmen Lawrence in the Western Australian royal commission. I wonder what they think when they see that $17,000 is being spent on a soft serve ice-cream machine for the Royal Australian Air Force at Williamtown.

I also wonder what they think when they see that the Australian taxpayer is spending $650,000 a year on cutlery and crockery for the defence department, $31,000 for pens for DAS, $14,000 for tea, coffee, milo and biscuits for staff at the Defence Housing Authority and over $1 1/2 million a year for the National Media Liaison Service. This list alone—this wasteful list of government expenditure—would allow 195 cystic fibrosis sufferers to enjoy life. There is enough money being wasted or spent there to support the 80 sufferers in Tasmania for at least two years. I am trying to put into perspective this particular disease and the high price it exacts on our young people.

I point out, once again, that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is meeting tomorrow. I hope that when it reconsiders this matter members of the committee will find it in their hearts, and will have the commonsense, to take note of what has been happening around Australia and to give some hope to all those young people and families who are putting themselves out and spending so much money on this lifesaving drug. I will wait to see what happens tomorrow and I just hope that it will be a case of third time lucky for them.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Calvert, I take the liberty from the chair, as a former chairman of the Cystic Fibrosis Research Trust in South Australia, to say that I have been listening most intently to what you have been saying and I hope that there is a good outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The selling of Australian icons overseas has become a matter of concern, I think, for many Australians. The fact that even iced vo vos are now foreign owned worries a lot of Australians, and vegemite has been owned by an overseas company for many years. But the rush on Australian icons by overseas interests has really only arisen during the years of this so-called nationalistic Australian government, an Australian government that is so nationalistic that it wants to change the flag, change the constitution, make Australia more Australian and all the while it is busily selling off the farm or, should I say, the piggery. That is the situation.

PARA.TAB: Here we have this Australian government standing over a situation where not only are more and more of Australia's icons being sold overseas but, according to the latest figures, Australia is going into bigger and bigger debt in order to pay for this government's incompetent economic policies. It is the terrible thing: not only are we selling many Australian icons but we are also now massively in debt. The great bulk of our food industry is now owned overseas, and massive proportions of our mineral and oil industries—the areas of greatest potential growth in Australia—also appear to be dominated by overseas countries.

In other words, we have not sold off enough of the farm to pay our bills. We keep having to borrow more and more, as I think today's figures of our foreign debt show. As Senator Calvert says, we are having to pay interest on the interest. In fact, the interest bill alone is now about $1,000 million a month net. This is a disaster. My concern is not only that we are going so massively into debt but also that we are trying to sell off the farm to pay for what we are importing at the moment, pay for the difference.

The point that I made earlier, that we are not only selling off the farm but selling off the piggery, is very much to the point. As the Financial Review reported only last week, under a heading `That piggery goes totally offshore', we find that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is involved in selling off his assets at a big profit, along the lines of so much of Australia. Not only is he encouraged by his economic policies of selling off the farm, he himself is selling out to make a quid—to make a quick quid while the shareholders of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which still includes the Australian public as well as direct shareholders, have suffered a substantial loss.

The reason I am raising this is that there are many matters of concern that emerge out of the total sale now of the Keating piggery—which was to have been a joint venture with Danish interests—to overseas interests at huge profit to Mr Keating. We know that this sale was from Mr Keating, via an intermediary, to foreign interests. I gave notice this morning that I intended to move tomorrow a motion in relation to this, because of the way an intermediary was used to hide the fact that Mr Keating was selling out to foreign interests.

Mr Keating owned half of this piggery group. He told the parliament he was selling to his partner, when the documents we have now seen, which have been filed in various courts, clearly show that, three days before Mr Keating made that sale, an agreement was reached with the Indonesian interests involving the sale of Mr Keating's half interest. Mr Keating must have known of that agreement before he sold. Here we have a situation where because, I presume, he did not like the political consequences, firstly, of his being involved in `selling out the farm'—apart from having encouraged it from many Australians—he did not want to be seen to be selling out the piggery to foreigners. Also he did not want to be seen to be in the position where he really was: in a potential for conflict of interest where he stood to gain from a decision by the Foreign Investment Review Board and his own Treasurer (Mr Willis), to whom the Foreign Investment Review Board reports. He did not want to be seen to be in a position to be gaining from such a decision by his own government and so he interposed this intermediary, with the result that if it were not for my investigations the Australian public would not know that Mr Keating has received a substantial benefit from a decision by one of his own government's bodies, the Foreign Investment Review Board.

I am not saying whether it is right or wrong that the FIRB should have approved this sale. My view is that it would probably have been quite wrong for the FIRB not to have allowed such a sale, because after all it is allowing everyone else to sell out. It is allowing the disposal, if you like, of so many Australian icons that you wonder what useful purpose it does actually serve. But it does raise questions about why the Prime Minister, who is supposed to be leading our country with propriety but who has a curious approach to the truth, judging by his role in the Carmen Lawrence affair, should be allowed—without comment—to get away with using this facade to avoid the reality, to avoid revealing that he sold out to foreigners for a huge profit, despite the fact that his piggery was suffering substantial losses. These matters I think should be looked at and it is up to the Prime Minister to come clean at last.

I have put these sorts of matters before the Prime Minister repeatedly in this chamber and we never ever get a substantive answer. All we get is that Baume is up there smearing this beautiful, perfect Prime Minister who never does anything wrong. Talk about St Carmen; we have St Paul now. The ludicrous thing is that he is prepared to hide behind this facade and, if anyone dares to suggest that it might be a good idea if he tells the truth, that person is personally smeared—as I have been—as being a person of no repute, telling lies about him, and so on. All I ask the Prime Minister to do is to come clean and to answer these substantive matters. There is one very serious substantive matter in particular and that is the question of what happened to the $20 million the Commonwealth Bank of Australia was owed by the piggery group while Mr Keating was its half-owner?

We know from court documents that the group owed something like $13 million last year after a takeover by Indonesians. We know that this amount is made up of something like $7 1/2 million from one company—I think it is Hunter Valley Piggeries Pty Ltd—and another $2 million or so from Darling Downs piggery. I do not know where the rest comes from—probably from a company called Rincraft, although who knows what has happened to Rincraft, which was the borrowing company for the Brown and Hatton group, because it has disappeared off the face of the earth. There are no proper returns filed for the Brown and Hatton group, the group that Mr Keating half owned. I cannot blame Mr Keating for that because the failure to file the returns took place after he ceased to be a half owner, but the shonky relationships within that group and which resulted in continual breaches of the Corporations Law while Mr Keating was half-owner of the group have continued.

What is important about this is that clearly there has been an agreement or a deed or some kind of registered mortgage to take over this debt because, as I said, we now see that the companies which have acquired the assets of the Brown and Hatton group—that is, Hunter Valley Piggeries Pty Ltd and the Darling Downs piggery under the Euphron structure—have an arrangement with the Commonwealth Bank resulting in substantial borrowings. The borrowings are at least $7 million for the Hunter Valley piggery, $2 million for the Darling Downs piggery and, presumably, some other amounts from other members of the group, if any. As Mr Constantinidis told the court recently, that gives a total of around $13.7 million.
What concerns me is that there is a letter dated 1 March 1995 from Mr R.E. Griffiths of the Commonwealth Bank to the directors of the Hunter Valley piggery and the Darling Downs piggery noting:

We refer to our letter dated 14 February 1995 regarding interest on the Piggery Joint Venture debt for the month of February payable by 28 February 1995 to CDB and CBA for the total sum of $105,057.54.
The non payment of the above amount constitutes an event of default under Schedule 2 paragraph 3 of the Restructure Deed dated 11 May 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: This kind of document should be, if it is a registered mortgage, reported by the companies involved. The Senate would not be at all surprised if I reveal that neither Hunter Valley Piggeries Pty Ltd nor the Darling Downs piggery nor, naturally, Euphron have reported such a deed. I cannot check the existence of such a deed with the former companies who owned these activities—that is, the Brown and Hatton group; there are four or five in that group—because they have failed to put in their annual returns for the year to 30 June 1994. Surprise, surprise! What is new about that? Just continual breaches of the companies law by Mr Constantinidis who was shown as the director and who, in the past, filed all these accounts.

PARA.TAB: Of course, we do not know whether Mr Constantinidis still owns these companies which he is alleged to have acquired from Mr Keating when he acquired the rest of the interests as a letterbox as part of the transaction when Mr Keating sold out to the Indonesians. A company called Rincraft, another called Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, another called Brown and Hatton Wholesale, another called Brown and Hatton Rural and another called Belesdan have simply not lodged proper documents with the Australian Securities Commission revealing their latest state of affairs .

In other words, the shroud of secrecy behind which this Prime Minister has hidden in his relations with this infamous piggery arrangement continues. I simply hope that the Indonesians who own the piggery group in its entirety—Indonesian interests through companies registered in Singapore, with directors who appear to be in Hong Kong—and have now taken over the operations, will behave in a manner which is in total contrast to the improper behaviour of Mr Constantinidis. I note, at no stage has Mr Keating ever criticised or endeavoured to distance himself from the improper activities of Mr Constantinidis.

Mr Keating has always simply said, `I'm not in charge of running the thing. Therefore, I can't be blamed for anything that's done.'
