He has never, ever sought publicly to distance himself from it, to criticise it or to say, `Yes, I admit, that's not proper practice and I would rather it had not gone on.' Instead, Mr Keating has always sought to slander me when all I have been doing is providing details available from the Australian Securities Commission when they are ultimately made available by this reluctant company.(Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Condolences: Dame Pattie Maie Menzies GBE

TALK.START.PARA: —Before embarking on my remarks, I wish to place on record my personal regret at the passing of Dame Pattie Menzies at 7.45 this morning. I trust that the Senate will, at an appropriate occasion, have the opportunity for appropriate condolences to be expressed. Dame Pattie Menzies was the matriarch of the party that I have the great honour of serving in the Senate. I extend my personal condolences to her son and daughter and to the families of the late Dame Pattie Menzies.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—That is very sad news for us all to note.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I wish to raise is the ongoing saga of the National Media Liaison Service. I have been pursuing the question of the National Media Liaison Service for some substantial period of time. In fact, $1.5 million of taxpayers' money has been allocated to it. This service is allegedly a government information service designed to give timely information about government programs. However, as former Prime Minister Hawke's press secretary Barrie Cassidy has clearly indicated on national television, it is a propaganda unit for the government and the Labor Party and it is used for that particular purpose. The shadow minister for administrative services, Senator Rod Kemp, has been pursuing this matter with me now for some considerable period of time.

PARA.TAB: The Senate will recall that, as a result of the vigorous questioning and the exposure of the activities of the National Media Liaison Service, its head, Mr David Epstein, was removed from having the role of overseer of the National Media Liaison Service and was to be only involved in the Ministerial Media Group. Before that, he was responsible for both the Ministerial Media Group and the National Media Liaison Service.

I remind honourable senators that, despite the fact that this Mr Epstein had signed letters indicating that he was both Director of the National Media Liaison Service and Director of the Ministerial Media Group, in front of the Senate committee he denied that he had that dual role. However, the weight of the facts were so overwhelming that, ultimately, the government had to do the right thing and ensure that the National Media Liaison Service and the Ministerial Media Group were separated, housed separately and a separate person appointed to be in charge of the National Media Liaison Service.

Mr Acting Deputy President, people such as Senator Rod Kemp, the shadow minister for administrative services, and I considered that to be a bit of a victory and thought that at least proper standards of government accountability would once again apply to the National Media Liaison Service. It will, of course, be recalled that when the Auditor-General tried to audit the National Media Liaison Service the government set up all its defences so as not to allow the Auditor-General to check up on the activities of the National Media Liaison Service which, of course, from our point of view on this side of the chamber, was an admission of guilt as to the sorts of activities that the National Media Liaison Service engaged in.

The parliament has a communications directory, as most senators would be aware. In the February 1995 edition for the autumn sittings, there is an entry on page 127, under communications and facilities branch. Underneath that is listed the National Media Liaison Service with director, adviser, media advisers, secretary, et cetera. These are all listed for all of us to see and make contact with. Since then, of course, there have been the exposures of the National Media Liaison Service.

So, I had some interest in looking up the spring sittings communications directory to ascertain how the National Media Liaison Service would be described. Under communications and facilities branch, all of a sudden the National Media Liaison Service no longer appears. It is no longer in the index. You can no longer find the National Media Liaison Service in the communications directory. The National Media Liaison Service is supposed to be a master of communications and it cannot even get itself listed in the communications directory. The interesting thing is that, in the place where the National Media Liaison Service used to be listed, we now have the Ministerial Media Group. The Ministerial Media Group is unashamedly a propaganda machine for the ministers and the government. We do not necessarily, on this side of the house, take umbrage at that; that is their role and good luck to them.

In the past, the government used to say the National Media Liaison Service was distinct from the Ministerial Media Group and that they would not get involved in that sort of tacky politics that the Ministerial Media Group might get involved in. Once we had exposed the National Media Liaison Service for being what it is, they said, `We're going to separate the two and make sure they operate separately.' But, what do they do? They replace or substitute the Ministerial Media Group for the National Media Liaison Service. Under the Ministerial Media Group, the former director of the National Media Liaison Service, Mr Epstein, is listed as the director.

The adviser in the Ministerial Media Group is Mr Terry Counihan. It is interesting that, when you read the February edition of this communications directory, under the heading of National Media Liaison Service, who is the adviser in the National Media Liaison Service? None other than Mr Terry Counihan. So what have they done in separating these two bodies? They just get the adviser, Mr Terry Counihan, out of the National Media Liaison Service straight into the Ministerial Media Group, exactly continuing the activities that we alleged the National Media Liaison Service were engaged in, but now under the cover of the Ministerial Media Group. We go through this February edition of the communications directory: secretary, Ms Olga Ivancic. We then move to the August edition and, under the Ministerial Media Group, all of a sudden this same lady appears, yet again, under the Ministerial Media Group—out of the National Media Liaison Service.

The government really is going from bad to worse in this ongoing saga of the National Media Liaison Service. First of all, it tried to deny that these people were engaged in party political activities. It tried to prevent the auditor looking into its activities. It obfuscated at the Senate estimates committees and this Senate had to pass a special resolution, as you would recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, for a supplementary hearing of Senate estimates into the National Media Liaison Service to require the minister to answer the questions which we, in this Senate, believed were pertinent, were proper and reasonable to be asked. Even then, we had real problems in getting answers and, in fact, we got conflicting answers because the minister and Mr Epstein and Mr Beazley, the minister responsible, all got their stories wrong. It really became a bit of a disaster.

When the Labor Party thought that we might be moving into election mode, about the time that they got rid of the liability Mr Howe, the Deputy Prime Minister, and installed Mr Beazley, they also, at about the same time, got rid of the liability of the National Media Liaison Service, took Mr Epstein out of it, said that it was going to house them separately and treat them separately. From then on, the National Media Liaison Service would be purer than the driven snow.

But a little telephone call was made yesterday to the directories people in Parliament House and a simple question was asked, `What is the extension for the Ministerial Media Group?' The answer was 6090. We then asked, `What is the extension for the National Media Liaison Service?' Guess what—6090. Exactly the same telephone number, yet again! This is the sort of farce that this government believes that we ought to accept, as the people who are responsible for overseeing this $1.5 million that the people of Australia pay towards the National Media Liaison Service. This sort of behaviour by this government is indicative of a government that has become arrogant, a government that thinks it is no longer accountable, that it can do whatever it likes and treat the people and, indeed, this place with distain. It is exactly the same behaviour Senator Baume complained about prior to my speech in relation to the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to his private investments, where the Prime Minister expects a standard of all members of parliament other than himself. For some reason he is somehow different.

The National Media Liaison Service will continue to be an interest of mine and, I am sure, of Senator Kemp and others on the opposition side, until such time as it is run in a fair and proper manner and abides by the terms of reference under which it is supposed to operate, to provide timely information on government projects, and not do the sort of hatchet work that it has engaged in against the opposition over a substantial period of time. I note Senator Sherry is smiling smugly. I can assure him that we on this side do not smile when we have—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, can I just assure Senator Abetz through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that smiling smugly had nothing to do with the issues he is debating.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government may well feel smug about the way that they have handled this issue, but they have now been exposed, yet again, for a degree of duplicity which I am sure the people of Australia will not accept. Indeed, it is said that people often operate in this place on the basis of making selective leaks to the media. I have to thank many members of the media who have, in fact, made selective leaks to people such as Senator Kemp and me, indicating the underhand activities of the National Media Liaison Service and its operatives. So we have no doubt that the National Media Liaison Service has engaged in party political activities, which is clearly outside its terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: The people of Australia had yet again witnessed and had exposed to them the duplicity in which the government has gone about giving itself a $1.5 million free kick in relation to the advertising campaign—and, basically, that is what it is. They have given themselves $1.5 million per annum to try to defeat the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Democrats, the Greens, Independents, anybody other than themselves. The people of Australia, who I am sure have a spirit of fair play embodied within them, would condemn such behaviour. And I assure the government that they have not heard the last about the National Media Liaison Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I too would like to pay tribute to a great lady, a great Australian—Dame Pattie Menzies—who passed away earlier today. I also use this opportunity to express my condolences to her children. Later today, of course, the parties and individual senators will be going into more detail in their expressions of condolence. I also wish to take this opportunity to thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for allowing me the opportunity of participating in this debate by taking my responsibilities in the chair.

PARA.TAB: The issue that I raise is an important one because it is a fundamental principle of our democracy that there be no taxation without representation. Increasingly, we are finding in our society today an abrogation of that principle. We have all come to expect that the way taxation is levied—by imposing taxes on income, which involves bringing to account assessable income, and the allowability of deductions—is determined by legislation properly passed by the two houses of parliament and approved by the Governor-General. Alternatively, matters of detail as to how it is going to be paid are imposed through regulation. It is mandatory, of course, that those regulations be placed within this parliament within a stipulated time so that they can be disallowed—a perfectly democratic principle.

However, we are increasingly finding that people's opportunity to participate in representation is being taken away, because what the tax office is doing is determining rulings. So, for example, a deduction that was available last year is not available in the current year. I would like to speak briefly to a taxation ruling known as TR95/21 which applies to deductions for the real estate industry. It is quite blatantly saying that a deduction is allowable for expenses incurred by real estate employees before 1 July 1995. So what has been legitimate? Before 1995, a taxpayer could claim, providing he could substantiate the claim with the relevant documentary evidence, those expenditures. However, for the year 1995-96 and later years, those expenses are not deductible.

This appeared a perfectly good law in the past. Suddenly, we have this cut-off and we are told that in the future, without reference to the parliament, by way of a tax ruling that has limited circulation, people in the real estate industry will be denied deductions. I presume that, if this sort of tax ruling is applying to this particular occupational group, there are similar rulings that apply to other occupational groups. It is time the government took heed of what is happening, because it is a very serious issue.

For 1995-96 and later years, these expenditures are not deductible: advertising, club sponsorship, gifts, greeting cards, property presentation and wages. It appears that every employee around Australia is being categorised as if they were a public servant.

In other words, public servants do not normally have to employ staff to help them enhance their businesses by keeping records and so on, or by way of letterbox drops, clerical assistance and so on. In the past, if you paid your wages and had the proper group certificates, and it was genuine, not private—like child minding while you were going out and doing legitimate work—you could enhance your commissions and claim all those sorts of things. But, as from next year, expenditure on employing people for these sorts of purposes will suddenly be denied.

I can understand that, if you work within the tax office, your wages are not going to be increased by employing your wife at home or doing letterbox drops, because that is not in the character of that occupation. What we seem to be overlooking is the manner in which people earn their incomes, and the expenses which are necessarily incurred in gaining those incomes.

I do not think it is up to the tax office to say to a person, `You should not employ staff to enhance your income; you have just got to do that yourself. You have just got to burn the midnight oil, and walk twice as fast to make the appropriate deliveries into letterboxes.' For example, a number of estate agents spend money on mowing the lawns of the houses they have responsibility for selling, so that, when the auction day comes along, the places do look presentable. People will be denied those expenses. I would have thought it would fit within the parameters of section 51 as an expense that is necessarily incurred, because of the nature of the business.

Then, of course, we have advertising. We all know that real estate agents have cards printed and circulated around the neighbourhoods for which they have particular responsibility. But, in future, these cards will have to be produced by the employer, not by the employee or the commission agent. Advertising might be a letterbox drop, a signage, bunting and all sorts of razzamatazz. I would have thought that that was perfectly legitimate. But here, by a tax ruling, everybody has been constrained, and you cannot do this and get a tax deduction.

I think it is absolutely abhorrent. I will certainly be working with the Real Estate Institute to look into this, because I think it is an abrogation of the ordinary principles of democracy. What are we doing here, if laws are being made by the tax office—beyond our reach—and the denial of deductions is among them?

If you have greeting cards or introduction cards printed yourself there is no tax deduction. Of course, a deduction is allowable for the cost of attending conferences, seminars and training courses—I am very pleased to see that that is something that has been retained—but a greeting card is no longer allowable. I hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) takes this on board as a matter of principle. I hope that he looks into this and that he reports back to the Senate at the earliest opportunity. This is a principle that, as senators and as a house of review, we cannot allow to go unchallenged. I seek the parliamentary secretary's response.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of comments in response to some of the contributions during the matters of public interest debate. In respect of Senator Watson's concerns, I do not know about the recent rulings, but I will ensure that the matter is drawn to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Willis). Senator Watson always follows these types of issues diligently, enthusiastically and sincerely, and I will certainly draw that to the Treasurer's attention.

PARA.TAB: I noticed Senator Baume making the usual speech on piggeries. He has an obsession with piggeries; it is about all he ever talks about now. That is a bit unfortunate for Senator Baume and it is one of the reasons he is sitting on the backbench after all these years.

There is also Senator Abetz's obsession with the National Media Liaison Service. I do hope that he enjoys his time reading the telephone directory. I am sure it is thrilling reading, but, personally, I have not opened the front page of the February edition of the directory.

I have two other very brief matters to draw to the attention of the Senate. In the balance of payments figures which were released yesterday there is a nine per cent surge in exports in the resources area: sugar, gold, coal and liquid gas. Another important area, the trade in services area, has moved from deficit to a $13 million surplus. These figures are a very important indication of the direction of our balance of payments and it is more good economic news for this country to enjoy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about debt, Nick.

—I have been invited to tell you about debt, so I will tell you a little about debt. It is important that people understand the perspective of Australia's debt. For almost its entire history Australia has been an importer of money and capital and it uses these funds to finance development. Overseas funds come to Australia in a wide variety of forms: loans,—
—What was debt when you clowns took over, Nick?

—I will give you a little bit of a chat about debt, just hold on. There is foreign investment in Australian companies and there is foreign investment in Australian property. As Australia has become more open to the world, Australian funds are increasingly being loaned overseas or invested in overseas companies. That, in part, is why we are enjoying very significant economic growth at the moment. A considerable sum of money is also being invested by Australian companies in overseas corporations. BHP is a very good illustration of the success of Australian companies in the international arena.
—But net foreign liabilities have gone up. You know that.

—We will get to this in a moment. You can debate this on another occasion, if you wish. Profitable overseas ventures return income to Australia. I have highlighted the issue of our trade in services moving from deficit into surplus, which is a very important development for this country. These profitable overseas ventures return income to Australia and Australia's overseas investment undertaken today will help lower the current account deficit in future. We cannot always take one month's figures; the critical issue is that we are seeing the longer term trend develop. Our total borrowing from overseas is equal to the gross foreign debt and more than half of that foreign debt is private debt.

PARA.TAB: We have private corporations in Australia making commercial judgments about the moneys they need to borrow. Some of it is borrowed offshore. These private corporations seek funds either from overseas or the domestic capital market in Australia. The various financial institutions that lend money are doing so on the basis of the financial strength—the assets, income, profit and loss, and various other financial indicators—of these various Australian corporations. The government cannot deny private corporations access to capital. I hope that is not what the opposition is suggesting as one of the solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just give us the debt figure.

—I am getting to the importance of the debt figure in a moment, Senator O'Chee. Debt is not necessarily a bad thing, Senator O'Chee, as I am sure you know. The important thing is whether you can sustain the level of debt and what our debt is comparative to other countries. But we will get to that in a moment, Senator O'Chee.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the private foreign debt that is owed by Australian companies, these companies use that money from overseas to finance investment projects. Presumably, these projects that investment is occurring in have a rate of return that justifies the repayment of that debt. These private borrowers—not just companies—are responsible for paying the interest and the principal on these borrowings. A large part of Australia's foreign debt, around $25 billion, is owed by companies owned by state and Commonwealth governments.

As is the case with private companies, these public trading enterprises use their borrowings to finance investment projects that benefit Australia, and there are numerous examples of this. We have electricity corporations that borrow money offshore and this is supported and sustained by the earnings of those corporations. Australian individuals and companies not only borrow from overseas but also lend funds to overseas companies. Taking this lending into account, Australia's net foreign debt is approximately $167 billion. When we talk about billions, it sounds like a lot of money

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.
—It is a lot of money.

—Yes, but we have got to put it into perspective. The important issue is whether we can sustain the debt and what our debt is comparative to other countries. If you cease interjecting for a few more minutes, you will learn just what our relative debt is and how we can sustain it. What I would emphasis is that 61 per cent of this debt is owed by private companies not by Australian citizens or by governments. It is owed by private companies and corporations. Only a small fraction of this foreign debt, 4 1/2 per cent, is Commonwealth government debt. This reflects the fact that the Australian government has not borrowed money in overseas markets since 1987. We have a very successful record as a government of not borrowing money in overseas capital markets. We have not borrowed a dollar as a government in eight years. That is a remarkable record, particularly in comparison to those opposite.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, most of Australia's government foreign debt is state government debt. The state governments have a total foreign debt of $42.5 billion. That is not a consequence of federal government policy. The best way to get a clear understanding of the size of the foreign debt is to compare it to the size of the Australian economy. Since September 1993, the size of the foreign debt relative to the size of the economy has fallen. I wish those opposite could understand the significance of that. It has fallen from 43 per cent to 37 per cent.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—The debate on matters of public interest is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, will be absent from question time today and tomorrow. He will be overseas from today until 11 September on official government business visiting a number of ASEAN countries to discuss trade matters. He will also be attending the first joint meeting of AFTA and CER ministers, details of which he outlined in question time yesterday. In his absence from question time, Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services and I will take questions on trade matters.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the minister: now that you have had 24 hours to reconsider your appalling premeditated attack on counsel assisting the Marks Royal Commission, Ms Ann Vanstone, will you now apologise for your profoundly defamatory slur on both the royal commissioner and Ms Vanstone?

—There is no basis for an apology here. I was simply making the point that the standards of propriety and impartiality demanded of those who are involved in the conduct of judicial or related proceedings have always been very high—and rightly so—and they ought to be regarded equally highly in the present circumstances.
—Why don't you require Justice McHugh to resign from the High Court?
—Order! Senator Abetz!

—They are much higher than the criteria of impartiality and maintaining the appearance of impartiality that we apply to ordinary affairs of community or employment life. Any analogy based on sex discrimination legislation or comparable things of that kind, which was sought to be called in aid yesterday, comprehensively misses the point. A judge in a court proceedings has always sought to disqualify himself if he is in a family or defacto relationship with a particular person appearing before him or if, in some other way, the nature of the relationship could be seen, whatever the manifest integrity of the participants in the process, to be in issue.

PARA.TAB: This is the very same point that Senator Vanstone made with great vigour and enthusiasm just a few months ago in this place in the context of a particular family court situation where a judge was involved in a situation with a particular person appearing as a solicitor before him and in which all these issues were out in the public domain. Senator Vanstone had no difficulty at all in that context about making a series of very fierce points about the need for the appearance of impartiality, of integrity, of propriety to be maintained in processes of this kind, notwithstanding all the issues that might normally be thought to arise in a sex discrimination context.

We have a situation here where the question of the appearance of a possible less than impartial approach to this is particularly relevant because of the highly politically charged nature of this particular enterprise and moreover the highly political impact of a series of decisions which have been made in recent days about the actual conduct of those royal commission proceedings—decisions in which counsel assisting have been manifestly closely involved because of the nature of the particular role played by counsel assisting.

There is a question about the appearance of impartiality in those situations. It is absolutely reasonable in all the circumstances of this particular royal commission—conducted as it has been from the outset without any regard at all to the consideration of propriety and the proper use of power and the proper use of taxpayers' money by the Western Australian government and those opposite here who have supported them—charged as it is with all these different dimensions, to demand that the appearance of impartiality be strictly observed as it always has been required to be observed in matters of this particular kind in comparable circumstances in the past.

DEBATE.TITLE: LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion of censure of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to the Western Australian Royal Commission on the Easton matter.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

That a motion to censure the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to the Western Australian Royal Commission on the Easton matter may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) for his cowardly and unfounded attack upon the integrity and reputations of Royal Commissioner Marks and Counsel Assisting, Ms Ann Vanstone QC.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely unusual action for us to take. It is some years since we interrupted question time, which I guess demonstrates how important we regard this matter to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —It replaces question time—you understand that?
—You do not control this chamber, Gareth.

—We believe that after 24 hours the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) today would be just a touch contrite, just a touch concerned about the reputations that he was prepared to attack yesterday without any reasonable basis whatsoever. We thought the proper procedure, therefore, was for the first question today to give him an opportunity to withdraw the accusations he made yesterday against both the royal commissioner and the counsel assisting—
—Withdraw the royal commission! You coward.
—Order! Senator Cook!
—and to apologise for the damage that he deliberately sought to do to their public reputations.
—You coward!
—Order! Senator Cook!
—You are a coward.
—Senator Cook yells out `coward'. There is only one coward.
—You are not at a union meeting now, Cook.
—Order! Unless there is silence on both sides, the debate simply will not go ahead. I ask Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Cook in particular to keep silent.

—There is only one coward in this place—that is, Senator Evans. He is not prepared to go outside and say what he said yesterday against the reputations of both Commissioner Marks and Ms Vanstone. He, here in the coward's castle, sought to damage their reputations, to attack their professional integrity, to attack them in circumstances where they are seeking to perform a public service—
—Rubbish! Rubbish!
—All Minister Cook seems to do is to further compound the felony. No concern at all about the integrity of what is going on here.
—That's a lie.

—The integrity and reputation of both the commissioner and counsel do not deserve to be treated in this way by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. This is the fairest court that you will come across, Minister—a much fairer court than the way you are dealing with the royal commissioner.

PARA.TAB: Do they have the opportunity to come in here and answer the charge? Of course they do not. Senator Evans makes his charge in here where he knows it cannot be answered by those he seeks to attack, by those reputations he seeks to besmirch. That is disgraceful. That is why we should take this rare and not unprecedented action today in suspending question time in order to take him to task for his failure.

This was, as I said, a cowardly attack. It was directed deliberately and premeditatedly against the integrity of two professionals for short-term political gain. The motive was short-term political gain. Of all people whom the public has a right to expect to maintain a certain standard of parliamentary behaviour it is the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

Of all people who the public has a right to expect to protect the interests of individuals it has to be the Leader of the Government in the Senate. People have a right to expect that standard of behaviour from all senators, but particularly from those who hold high office. In this instance he did not do so. It is this failure to uphold a reasonable standard of parliamentary behaviour that causes us to bring this action today. As I said, we gave him 24 hours to reflect on it; 24 hours to think about the damage that he had done to these individuals, and he was not prepared to take advantage of it. We in here have a responsibility to protect individual rights.

That is why we are given certain power. That is why, if you so wish, you can defame—as the Leader of the Government in the Senate did yesterday. He deliberately sought to defame these individuals, but did he do that in order to protect individual rights? No! He did so in order to destroy the integrity of individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been defaming Carmen Lawrence for months.
—He did that for the most base of political motives.
—This is the height of hypocrisy!

—Mr President, I think we all understand that this is a very unusual course of action to follow. I am sure you appreciate that as well. There can be no excuse for you not holding people like Senator Cook to account for what is clearly a deliberate attempt to disrupt this whole debate to the point where you will be forced to call the whole exercise off. That is what he is trying to do. You have a very serious obligation to make sure that he does not do it, or to ask him to leave the room.
—Order! Which I will do, but I must say it is a question of the kettle calling the pot black. Senator Cook, I would ask you to keep silent.

—We all know why Senator Evans sought to attack the royal commissioner and his counsel yesterday. He sought to do so to protect the political hide of Minister Lawrence. There is no other reason whatsoever. For Senator Evans political motives are supreme above the interests and reputations of individuals.
—What about your political niceties, you hypocrite.
—Senator Bolkus, withdraw that.
—I withdraw.
—He rather sought to destroy those who deserve his protection, and he did so in an effort to protect the political hide of Minister Lawrence. The political motive of this minister was supreme.
—You have no morals.
—Who are these people, Senator Bolkus? A retired judge who has been prepared to perform this public service—
—What is your political motivation?
—You laugh at him—when people—

—Mr President, I draw your attention to the fact that for the last five minutes straight there has been non-stop interjection from the government side and there has been no interjection that you have referred to—nor has there been one to refer to—from this side of the chamber. You have not pointed to any member on this side of the chamber in the last five minutes. I now draw your attention to the fact that you have failed to take action to prevent our leader's speech not being able to be heard in this chamber. There have been non-stop interruptions, particularly from Senator Cook and the front bench of the Labor Party. What are you going to do about it?
—It is not a point of order. I have drawn attention to interjections on your side as well.
—What about Ian Macdonald?
—It is on the record. Senator Macdonald is one I specifically drew attention to.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—No!

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the last five minutes.
—What are you doing now!
—Order!
—Throw him out!

—It is impossible for me to control this House without the support of senators acting as adults in what is the national parliament. I draw everybody's attention to that because this side is just as bad on other occasions as this side is currently being.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask you to think about your image across the nation. This is the national parliament. You are being watched by people here in the public gallery who must think you are an absolute disgrace. I ask all of you to keep quiet. Senator Hill has the call.

—The point I was seeking to make was that these individuals whom Senator Gareth Evans attacks in this place, in this protected environment, are those who are prepared to perform a public service. A retired judge coming out of retirement to commit himself to—
—He was chasing a job for months, and you know that.

—Do you think he would be enjoying this process? This is what you do not understand: individuals who are prepared to perform public service do not always find it an easy task. This certainly would not be enjoyable for Royal Commissioner Marks at the moment. But what they do deserve is a bit of respect from the federal parliament, particularly from such as the Leader of the Government in the Senate—and that is what he is not getting at the moment. Ms Ann Vanstone QC, a highly respected barrister—
—They are not doing it as a public service; they are getting paid for it.
—Senator Schacht! Senator Hill has the call.
—So if they are getting paid, they no longer perform a public service and, therefore, it is legitimate to attack them, is it? It is legitimate to use the cowards' castle to attack them?
—Address your comments to the chair.
—What a strange set of values you exhibit, Senator.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill, don't take the bait; address yourself through the chair, please.

—Ms Ann Vanstone QC—who is prepared, in the public interest, to assist this royal commission and to assist the royal commissioner in his task—does she deserve to be maligned in this way? Does she deserve, in effect, to be accused of bias simply—
—She knew it was a star chamber royal commission when she took the job.
—Order! Senator Hill has the call.
—The point I am making—
—It is a political star chamber.

—No, I understand when this government seeks to attack the motivation for a royal commission, but does that give it the right to attack the integrity of the officers, the royal commissioner and counsel assisting? Of course, it does not. These ministers should be protecting these officials rather than attacking them in this way. They should demonstrate some respect for their reputations rather than seeking to drag their reputations down.

PARA.TAB: What this minister does today in refusing to withdraw his accusations and refusing to apologise is not only letting himself down but, in effect, because of his position, letting all senators down and letting the parliamentary institution itself down. That is a particular responsibility and that is why, if he is going to stand by his comments of yesterday, as he has chosen to do today, we have a responsibility to act. Anything short of that would be an abdication of our responsibility in this place. We have a responsibility to demonstrate that we recognise that parliamentary behaviour of his type yesterday is intolerable and, when this occurs, we will so act.

I acknowledge that Senator Gareth Evans's attack of yesterday on the professional reputation of these individuals is somewhat out of character. We have always heard from Senator Gareth Evans that what he does is to come in here to stand and protect individual rights, not to attack them under the protection of this chamber. We have here before us someone who on occasions has purported to aspire to judicial office; yet yesterday he came in here and, in this protected environment, sought to attack the integrity of these individuals.

Why would he do this? Why would he act in a way which would appear to be out of character? The motive, of course, is the political objective. In other words, the political objective of protecting Minister Lawrence from the public assessment on the truth outweighs all those high principles of which he has spoken in the past about the responsibility to protect individual rights.

That tells us, sadly, something about Senator Gareth Evans. It might tell us something about whether he would be suited in due course for judicial office. What an example of political opportunism. It is regrettable that he has debased himself in this way. What he has done is reduce himself to the Richardson level where the outcome is what counts, not the method of achieving that outcome. If it is necessary to attack the integrity of professionals that are seeking to do a task in the public interest, then he is prepared to come in here and attack that integrity.

We should not be surprised, I guess, by this premeditated attack because, if you look at the way in which this government has addressed this matter from the start, you will see a logical sequence of events that are designed to avoid the truth, designed to avoid the public having the opportunity to make a judgment on whether or not Minister Lawrence has told the truth to the Western Australian parliament and told the truth to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sham.
—It is a rigged royal commission; you know that.
—Order! Senator Schacht and Senator Carr!

—Let us take it step by step. The first response of this government to the royal commission was, without hesitation, to use taxpayers' money to seek to close it down by taking it through the courts to try to destroy it. Even when the mass of lawyers said that, on the basis of the Western Australian Supreme Court judgment there was no point in seeking to take it to the High Court, this government did not hesitate to take that extra step—again at taxpayers' expense—in order that Dr Lawrence might not have to appear before that royal commission. Of course, it failed. What was found was that the royal commission was legal and legitimate.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, what the Prime Minister; Mr Beazley, the Deputy Prime Minister; and Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, sought to do was to communicate that they would disregard its findings no matter what those findings were. The trouble with that—after they had read the editorials and wised up a little bit—is that it meant that, in effect, they had to excuse lying. In other words, they will not attack the motive but, if the royal commission came to a finding and they were not prepared to take cognisance of that finding, then they were going to condone lying. So that became a little awkward for this government.

The third step was to try to discredit the commission itself, the lowest possible step the government could take. Clearly, it was the premeditated choice of the government when it marched its leader into this place for the first question and answer yesterday to attack the royal commissioner and to attack the conduct of the commission. I remind you all that questions as to the management and conduct of the commission are the responsibility of the royal commissioner. If you attack the conduct of the commission, you attack the reputation of the commissioner. Secondly, it was appalling to attack the reputation of the senior counsel assisting that royal commission. If anything ever justified a censure motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Its performance already has discredited it.
—Order! Senator Schacht!

—Mr President, a point of order: I draw your attention to standing order 197(1) which says, `A Senator shall not interrupt another senator speaking.' In the last three minutes, you have warned Senator Schacht four times. How many times does he have to be warned before you name him and throw him out of this chamber?
—I will deal with that myself in due course, and without your help.
—Are you disputing my right to take a point of order?
—No, I am not.
—Well, you challenged me then, and I think you should withdraw that.
—Order!

—What Senator Evans has done is attack the integrity of the royal commissioner by attacking the management of the commission. We all remember him coming in here yesterday and talking about why would the commissioner allow an order of witnesses in this form if there were not something going on behind it—the same attack that he launched on the counsel assisting the royal commissioner.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans, with a couple of appearances before a magistrate's court, comes in here and attacks the choice of order of witnesses of a highly reputable Queen's Counsel who earnt her silk on the basis of her legal reputation, not her political reputation. He attacks her on the way she has chosen to manage the commission and, even worse, he attacks her because of her relatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do that all the time.
—Order!

—He attacks her because, through marriage, she is a relative of Senator Vanstone—the sister of Senator Vanstone's husband. Therefore, he says that we must question her conduct; we must question her in a way that we do not question others. Would he say the same about Justice McHugh in the High Court, the husband of a minister in his government? What would he say if we attacked his judgment? You might answer this, minister. What would you say if we attacked his judgments on the basis of his relationship with his wife, one of your ministers?
—You have done it!
—Order!

—You would say that is disgraceful. All of the women on the other side would leap up and say, `How dare you attack a woman such as Ms Vanstone because of the fact that she is married to a particular person? How shameful!' Yet that is the basis upon which the minister attacked her integrity yesterday. When he came in here today and had the chance to withdraw, he refused to do so. He made it worse. As I said, he simply compounded the felony. If we let that lie, it would be an awful precedent. We on this side of the chamber are not allowing that precedent to go without challenge. That is why we brought on this censure motion today.

PARA.TAB: Today is the chance for this chamber to disassociate itself from this attack by Senator Evans on these professional people. This is an opportunity for this chamber to discipline the minister for his cowardly attack on their reputations. This is an opportunity that this chamber must not forsake today. It is our responsibility to demonstrate to the minister that his standard of parliamentary performance falls far short of that which is necessary for a minister of the Crown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill and the opposition might not have liked what I said yesterday, a few other people have not liked what I said yesterday, but what I said was a perfectly permissible and responsible thing to say when confronted with a situation of the kind we are now witnessing unfold in Western Australia. The record ought to be put straight for a start as to what exactly I did say yesterday. Let us at least have a clear foundation of recollection about that, not a highly coloured and highly charged one, before we go any further.

PARA.TAB: Have a look at page 528 of the Hansard which contains the relevant passages. First of all, I began by raising the simple question of the appointment to the position in question and by identifying who she was. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it a matter of propriety or is it just a matter of coincidence that the counsel assisting the royal commission, the person whose job it is to recommend to the commission the way in which the evidence is to be prepared, as well as the person whose job it is to write the draft report of the commission, happens to be the sister-in-law of the shadow Attorney-General in this country?
That was just stating perfectly neutrally what the nature of the problem was. Is this a matter of coincidence or are there issues of propriety raised by that? A little further down, I went on to say:
Impartiality, as a matter of propriety in Australian public life—and I am asked a question about propriety—should not only be present in these kinds of proceedings but also be seen to be present.
This was the nub and substance of what I was saying yesterday; propriety should not only be present but should be seen to be present. I also stated:

How can it be seen to be present when the sister-in-law of the shadow Attorney-General is playing this sort of decisive role and is producing decisions of the kind that we had yesterday to not allow Carmen Lawrence to appear before the commission?
Then, a little further down again, I said:

. . . yesterday we had a decision where a request was formally made to bring forward her evidence to respond to the allegations that are being made; and when you make a formal request and it is absolutely denied for no discernible good reason, it is appropriate that these questions be asked.

What I was doing yesterday—you will not find any other language that goes further than that—was drawing attention to this relationship and the appearances generated by that relationship and saying that it is appropriate that questions be asked.

PARA.TAB: I am not confining my statement to that effect to this place, which you describe as the cowards castle. I was asked this morning on radio whether I stand by what I said yesterday. I repeated the nub and substance of it and said it is crucial in proceedings of this kind that not only the existence but also the appearance of impartiality be maintained. That is what is in issue here. That is what I have said publicly. I am perfectly happy to state it publicly outside the door. I have stated it publicly. Check the record. That is the end of the first part of the censure motion, which is that I am not prepared to say outside what I am saying inside. The reason I am prepared to say it outside is that a serious matter of public policy is involved here.

Standards are high, have to be high and should be high in the conduct of judicial proceedings and quasi-judicial proceedings of the kind that royal commissions quintessentially are. That has always been understood and accepted by those who participate in those proceedings. Questions of family relationship and de facto sexual relationship and all sorts of other associated matters of that kind that would be extraordinarily colourable if they were to stand in the way of something taking place in an ordinary employment situation are routinely raised as barriers for particular relationships to be maintained or particular positions to be accepted in judicial or related proceedings.

All the time, judges are disqualifying themselves from appearing in matters in which counsel or litigants may be involved with whom they have some relationship. When they do not do that, it is a proper occasion for concern. Senator Vanstone, in this March in this place, was full of enthusiastic vituperation on this subject. Without going into any more detail about it, on 9 March 1995, with regard to a family court case, she was saying that what matters is not the actual integrity or the impartiality of people involved—that may not be contested in a particular case—but the appearance, and that that appearance must be observed. If it is not observed, there has been some fundamental failing for which some political responsibility must be accepted.

Senator Vanstone is on record as saying that. It was a quite proper thing for her to say. I do not in any way criticise her for saying it. What I criticise her for is the hypocrisy of saying that I am saying something different in the circumstances of this case.

I am not saying anything different. I am saying that matters of appearance are involved here. There are matters not only of actual impartiality but the appearance of impartiality that have been to be looked at and scrutinised and can be legitimately questioned.

That is so in any royal commission or any judicial proceeding. Might I say that it is absolutely so, it is particularly so, in a proceeding of this kind that we are now witnessing. What we are witnessing is no ordinary judicial proceeding. What we are witnessing is no ordinary royal commission. What we are witnessing is the most deliberately and intendedly politically charged royal commission or similar proceeding of any kind that has ever been held in country. It is an unprecedented proceeding to set in train through the exercise of executive power—

TALK.START.PARA: —In your view.

—Give me an example if you can come up with one. I would welcome one, because I have been trying to find one. I have never heard of a royal commission being set up, as this one has been, to scrutinise what boils down to a matter of political behaviour or political propriety. I have never heard of a royal commission being established which does not go to any possible question of criminality. I have not heard of a royal commission being established which does not go alternatively to some important question of public administration or which goes to some question of financial probity, misuse of financial power, misuse of executive power or abuse of executive authority. That is the nub and substance of royal commissions in this country.

PARA.TAB: There have been royal commissions on national security matters as well. There has been a royal commission on the petroleum industry, for example, a few years ago, which was designed to pull out and identify all the complex strands of some complex policy issue and to bring up conclusions and recommendations about that. They are all the categories of things which royal commissions have been about in this country. This royal commission is about none of them. This is a royal commission which degrades the currency of royal commissions, because there is no other substance, motivation or possible effect of this royal commission other than to embark upon the political arena. That is what this is all about.

In that environment, in that highly charged political environment, with a royal commission established on that basis—unashamedly established on that basis—in an unprecedented way, it is that much more important, if you ask us or anyone in the community to take seriously the conclusions of this royal commission, that it be absolutely beyond any possible shadow of question so far as its impartiality, its neutrality, its absence of bias and its professionalism are concerned. What matters, I repeat, in these matters is not just the reality of integrity and impartiality and lack of bias; what matters, and always has mattered in these matters, is the appearance of it.

When you have a highly politically charged royal commission of this kind set upon an essentially, quintessentially, political task, and you have one of the key participants in that process—someone who is themselves directly related or closely related to someone who is an absolutely key player in the political process on one side of the equation, someone who has not been a blushing, modest violet but someone who has been up on her feet every day of the week in this parliament making political points about this process—then you have an appearance problem. You have an appearance problem in a big way, and it is legitimate for us to question that, to ask questions about it. And what was I doing yesterday? I was asking questions about it. You thought it was a bit tacky, you did not like it. A lot of people did not like it, but it was legitimate to ask questions. It always has been and it always will be legitimate to ask questions about the integrity of these processes.

There is another issue here. It is not just the circumstances of the commission as a whole; it is the way the commission is in fact being run. It is important to focus on the way the commission is being run.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know how it should be run, do you?

—It is very important to focus on the way the commission is being run because this adds a further series of questions to the pile of questions that have to be asked. And they are only questions—they are not assertions, they are not allegations, they are not claims and they are not conclusions. They are questions. They are questions about the way the commission is being run.

PARA.TAB: How is the commission being run? Was not the commission established under its terms of reference to inquire into the circumstances of the tabling of a petition by a named member of parliament involving substance put to that member of parliament by a particular private individual? That particular petition was initiated in that way. That is what it is about. It is an inquiry into the circumstances, the propriety of a petition.

One would have thought under those circumstances that the petitioner at least would be the very first person to be called to explain the circumstances of the petition and the content of the petition. One would have thought that the person on whom the petitioner relied for the information might well be the second person who was called. One might have thought, beyond that, that the person who is obviously the target of the entire proceedings, Dr Lawrence, would be the third person called. That is a matter, I guess, for judgment by those concerned. But certainly the petitioner, Mr Halden, has been asking since day one for an opportunity to get into the royal commission and explain his version of events. We have now seen them at last in the Bulletin published today because he still has not had an opportunity to give his version of the events. So there is something strange, there is something odd, there is something curious, there is something questionable—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, what do you suggest?
—Order! Senator Hill.
—There are questions that might reasonably be asked; questions that should, I believe, be answered. What I am saying is that these decisions—
—What are you implying?

—I will tell you what I am implying. I am not implying; I am stating that decisions about the conduct of the proceedings—which witnesses are called; when; in what order; in what sequence—are decisions with highly political effects. They might not have political motivations, but they certainly have political effects. They have had the effect that Mr Halden has been denied the opportunity for weeks to put on the record points that he has wanted to make. They have had the effect, of course, that Dr Lawrence has been denied, for weeks, the opportunity now that she has wanted to make the points that she has wanted to make. As the time has ticked away and as the witnesses have been brought forward in other sequences, the obvious political implications of this have grown and grown.

PARA.TAB: So under those circumstances Dr Lawrence makes the request to bring forward the timing of her appearance before the commission. That request is denied. Now there might, as I said yesterday, be very good reasons for that. It might be inconvenient, as apparently counsel assisting said—and presumably the commissioner himself has agreed with that. There might be some excellent reason based on practice and procedure. It is not self-evident, and it certainly is evident that the decision has had some political impact and will go on having a political impact.

It is against that background—it is not just the commission itself, the motivation for it, the establishment of it, but the way it has been conducted—that it becomes important all over again, and the point is reinforced, for that commission to be conducting itself with the absolute appearance of total impartiality. Anything about the conduct or the structure of that commission which has an appearance of less than total impartiality can under those circumstances be legitimately a matter for public concern being raised and public questions being asked.

There is nothing sordid or squalid about the way in which I have sought to raise this particular issue. There are plenty of things that are sordid and squalid about the circumstances that have led me to raise it, but not the issue itself. The issue itself is a matter of high and legitimate public policy. That is the way I put it yesterday. You cannot find anything in what I said yesterday that puts a different colour and substance on it. I raised it that way very deliberately because I am concerned about the questions that I have just drawn attention to. There are various ways in which these concerns—

TALK.START.PARA: —What conclusions are to be drawn from that?

—Let me tell you some conclusions that can be drawn from it. There are ways of dealing with these questions of possible appearances of impartiality or lack thereof. The most obvious one is not to accept these jobs at all in the first place if the acceptance of it can give rise to this sort of appearance. That is a question that might reasonably be asked of the people involved. But that is a question for them and I do not put it any higher than that.

PARA.TAB: A second question might reasonably be asked. If you have got this problem of an appearance, one that is inherent in the very nature of the proceeding to begin with and then reinforced by the significance of the particular decisions that are procedurally being made along the way, the question can be reasonably asked whether or not in all the circumstances one should not stand down from one's participation in those proceedings because of that appearance—not because of any actual lack of impartiality, not because of any actual lack of integrity. I make no such claims. I am absolutely perfectly prepared to believe in the honesty and integrity of your sister—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did, yesterday. You will get your just desserts. I am making the point.
—Order!

—I am making the point, Senator Vanstone, about the appearance—a point which you made yourself in spades in the Hansard in this place. On page 171, on 9 March this year you made that point in spades: it is the appearance that matters. I am making it to you now today, as I did yesterday—that that is one of the ways in which you can address this sort of problem.

PARA.TAB: Another issue that is involved here is Senator Vanstone's position. She can go some of the distance, as I said yesterday, to putting some colour of reasonableness back into this situation by getting up in this place and giving us an assurance that she has had absolutely no discussion whatsoever of any kind relating to this royal commission with her sister-in-law. It does not entirely deal with the problem of appearance but it deals at least partially with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entitled to congratulate her on getting a good job?

—What you have said publicly outside this place is yes, you congratulated her on getting a job and then you had a family dinner a little bit more recently in which you asked her how she was getting on, and you all had a wonderful chat about it. I do not know what you said, but it is up to you, I think, to get up in this place and tell us and to persuade us and to assure that us that you have not had any substantive discussion whatsoever about the conduct of these proceedings. If you do that I would be delighted because, while it does not solve the whole problem, it solves part of the problem. I said that yesterday.
—I will do it right now. Will you apologise then? No.
—Order!

—It is just the same as with the wife of a judge or somebody with whom he is having a relationship in that case that you were getting excited about in March, the Northern Territory case, which you raised. It is a matter of then saying: `Does it solve the problem if the matter is a matter of subsequent disclosure or if the person in question says, "No, we have not discussed it on the pillow" or wherever'. It does not solve the whole problem and it never will in these sorts of situations but it can solve at least part of the problem. It is a point that could only be made about someone like Senator Vanstone because of the profile, Mr President, that she has adopted on this matter. If she had sat there quietly through this and said, `There is a bit of a problem about appearances in this matter; under the circumstances I will sit this one out' that might have been a credible course for her to adopt in the circumstances. She has been anything but quiet on this matter. That is what it comes down to.

PARA.TAB: We are dealing with a royal commission which has been established on the shoddiest, shonkiest possible foundations. It has been established shamelessly to inquire into a matter which simply did not cry out for this sort of attention.

There might have been some legitimate concern in the Western Australian parliament about the course of proceedings. That concern was the subject of a privilege committee inquiry in the Western Australian parliament very shortly after this happened, in November 1992. The issues were there fully aired, including all the issues of propriety involved. But, no, that was not good enough. There had to be this further royal commission. The circumstances in which the royal commission has been set up speak for themselves about its political motivation. The terms of reference of the royal commission speak for themselves. The only thing that is to be looked at is the particular circumstances of the petition.

There is no opportunity under the terms of reference to go back in history and look at the original way in which Richard Court brought the Easton marital affair into the public domain in 1986. It was not brought into the public domain by this petition in 1992; it was brought into the public domain for the first time, in 1986, by Richard Court. But that, and all the other intermediate things that made the case a matter of notoriety, public interest and concern in Western Australia—all those pre-existing circumstances which may well have influenced people's memories about how on earth they thought that various things happened at certain times and influenced their perception of what knowledge they had—is ruled out. That is not part of the terms of reference of the royal commission. It cannot be inquired into and cannot be the subject of cross-examination. It is not relevant. The only thing that is relevant is this petition of November 1992.

This royal commission has no justification in terms of any reasonable standards of decency, propriety or legitimate concern for the quality of public administration in this country. It is absolutely unprecedented, absolutely unique and absolutely ill-motivated—and that motivation is absolutely political. You want a scalp; you will go to any lengths to get one. You don't care that the matters in issue do not involve criminality, financial maladministration, abuse of power or national security issues—or any of the things involved here. You don't care because you sense a political scalp. You cry foul if we on this side say, `Hey, there are some issues of principle and propriety involved here and you ought to do something about them. You ought to respond to legitimate questions that have been raised.'

You are a bunch of hypocrites. You accuse us of misuse of power. There has never been a greater misuse of executive power in this country than the establishment of this commission. You accuse us of misuse of taxpayers' money because we stand ready to defend someone who is the subject of an assault funded by taxpayers' money, with no motivation other than political. There is nothing more than political motivation in this. There are questions of principle that deserve to be asked and deserve to be raised; and they were raised by me yesterday in this place and publicly—and I make no apology for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just had is a very clear demonstration of Senator Gareth Evans's total unfitness to ever hold any form of judicial office. In other words, what he has done is demonstrate that he cannot separate his political prejudices from any capacity to reason or exercise judgment. The critical issue here is this: if matters of appearance are important, if you, Senator Evans, are genuinely concerned about the role that counsel assisting or the royal commissioner might play, why did you not raise the matters months ago? This royal commission was set up months back. In fact, it was about six weeks ago that Zoltan Kovacs first gave evidence.

PARA.TAB: Did we hear a complaint from Senator Evans that Zoltan Kovacs should not have been called at that point in time? Did we hear any complaints about the order of witnesses in the weeks following? No. What we had in that time was a furious attempt by Carmen Lawrence to close down this royal commission by hook or by crook, using taxpayers' funds to do so. There was never any complaint about the integrity of the royal commissioner or the political, perceived or actual bias of counsel assisting.

What has changed? Why is it that suddenly Senator Evans wants to raise questions in the mealy-mouthed way that he expresses them? He is not raising questions; he is making snide political criticisms under the guise of asking questions—a very low tactic. But why is he doing it now? The reason he is doing it now is that he has had to sit there and watch about a dozen of Carmen Lawrence's former colleagues go into the witness box and give evidence on oath, evidence that has been highly critical of her.

What upsets you more than anything else is that these people are putting integrity before politics. They are prepared to go in there and tell the truth as they know it. They are not prepared to do the Keating trick of simply playing the team game—lying your head off for the good of the side, whatever it takes. That is what has changed.

Once these people went in there and gave that damning evidence, Carmen Lawrence suddenly decided that it was about time for a significant change of strategy. In other words, what she needed to do, far from holding it up and refusing to participate and running a guerilla campaign in the media, was to actually get in there and tell her story as quickly as possible. So she did a complete about-turn.

That is what sticks in your craw—that the commissioner and the royal commission counsel assisting, say, `Well, I'm sorry. We have to assess these things on the merits. We have made arrangements for witnesses to attend.' Ann Vanstone explained that there was a very good reason why Carmen Lawrence should not be allowed to jump the queue. She said that arrangements had already been made for other witnesses. What right does Carmen Lawrence have to suddenly think that she can pull rank and go to the top of the queue?

In fact, it may not even be in her best interest. Just think about it. It may not even be in her best interest. If you are a defendant in criminal proceedings—and these are not criminal proceedings—you are given the opportunity to hear all of the evidence against you before you are called upon to respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you concede she is a defendant?
—Order!

—A defendant does not have the right to say, `By God, this trial is going badly. I have had a number of witnesses kicking me to death, so I demand the right to have my evidence intruded into the middle of the crown case.'
—It is a trial, is it?
—You concede that it is a trial?
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—They don't do that, and this is not that. But Carmen Lawrence—
—You concede it is the trial of Carmen Lawrence?
—Listen, sport, I made it very clear at the outset that we are not saying this is a trial. I'm simply—
—You just said it, you goose.
—It is very sad if you cannot understand the point that Carmen Lawrence now wants to go along to the royal commission to have her opportunity to refute—
—Hansard will be interesting this afternoon.

—Absolutely. To have her opportunity to refute all the damning evidence that has been called against her. She wants to be able to turn the tide, and she wants to do it as quickly as possible, because that is the political judgment you have made—that she is bleeding to death otherwise and you cannot simply let it run on and on. In fact, you will have further witnesses coming along putting their own integrity before politics. So it may even be in her own best interest that she not be called now.

PARA.TAB: Yet what did Senator Gareth Evans do? Senator Gareth Evans immediately assumes, by those snide questions, that Ann Vanstone, counsel assisting—not counsel determining the matter; in other words, Ken Marks QC—makes the ultimate decision. But the royal commission itself makes a decision on good grounds that she should not be given the opportunity to be heard right now, she ought to take her place in the queue, and she ought to be able to hear all of what is said against her and given the opportunity to refute it. So there is, on the face of it, a very good and plausible explanation for the commission acting in the way that it did. There is not a skerrick of evidence to suggest that that commission was politically motivated.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are speaking on behalf of the commission, are you, Richard?

—I am saying, on the record, that there is not a skerrick of evidence to suggest that the commission was, in any shape or form, politically motivated. What did we hear from Senator Evans last week? He had the cheek to say to us that he has told us all the things that could be used against him. Of course, he did not remind us of what he said yesterday—that snide little one-liner which he obviously prepared and which, one would presume, was approved by the Prime Minister. He said, `I do not want to be taken as undermining family values on the principle that the family that preys together'—and he had to spell it out for our benefit so we all knew how grubby he really was. He wanted to make a very cute little point that he probably hoped would get a run on the television. So let there be no doubt what he was up to. He said almost a week ago:

SPEECH.PARA: I cast no public aspersions on Mr Marks for taking up this particular job. That is a matter for his own conscience and he can live with that.

Let's just think about it. Are you seriously suggesting that anyone who takes up a political appointment to head up a royal commission must be politically motivated? Are you saying that because they get paid to do it somehow they are compromised? Are you saying that it is not proper?

PARA.TAB: This is what Stephen Smith said, of course. Stephen Smith gave a very non-oblique warning that anyone who cooperated, anyone who took the job, would be held to account by the Labor Party. I understand those `Keatingesque' tactics; that's the way he operates. But is that what Senator Evans is seriously suggesting? I don't think it is.

I think Senator Evans has been careful up until 24 August to not criticise Ken Marks who has an impeccable record, a long and distinguished career as a judge of the Supreme Court in Victoria, who takes on a job knowing that he is likely to be subjected to very heavy political criticism. But in no respect is there anything you can point to since he has taken up that position that would constitute political bias.

So what do you now say? Once you get a decision that does not suit Carmen Lawrence's political interests you then turn around and argue that counsel assisting must be biased and because she is related by marriage to someone in politics that somehow is a basis for her standing down. What an appalling suggestion. Talk about guilt by association! Someone who has built a career at the bar—not just six months relying on Slater and Gordon to feed you a few dock briefs but someone who actually has practised the law for many years to take the brief to do the job that has to be done.

It is one thing for you to complain about the basis of the royal commission being set up. I can understand why you squirm on that subject. Senator Evans says there is no precedent for matters of this sort. I seem to recall the Petrov royal commission was very much looking at the conduct and role of Dr Evatt. You might squeal about that. In fact, there was a trial of a certain judge that resulted from an inquiry in this very chamber that resulted in criminal charges being laid. So there are plenty of precedents for investigating improprieties.

You see, the alternative espoused by Senator Evans, and no doubt of course enthusiastically adopted by the Prime Minister, is that, really, the place for these matters to be played out is in the parliament. So if you have the numbers there is nothing you can do about it—`If our side lies and we've got the numbers, we just make sure you can't touch us. You can't lay a glove on us.'

If you only do what Mr Keating thinks is a parking offence—if you only lie to a state parliament—well, that's not even worth worrying about. What are a few fibs to a state parliament a few years ago? As if there's a strict statute of limitations on lying—I mean, it is just preposterous!
What is really offensive about Senator Evans's behaviour in this whole matter is to suggest:

SPEECH.PARA: How can it be seen to be present—
he is talking about propriety—
when the sister-in-law of the shadow Attorney-General is playing this sort of decisive role and is producing decisions of the kind that we had yesterday—

But yesterday we had a decision where a request was formally made to bring forward her evidence to respond to the allegations that are being made; and when you make a formal request and it is absolutely denied for no discernible good reason—

In other words, he is making it quite clear that there was no possible reasonable basis for that decision. It lacked bona fides; therefore, there was an appearance of political bias. That's what he is saying.

PARA.TAB: The moment that counsel assisting, or the royal commission itself made a decision that did not suit your political interests you immediately went for the political jugular. You did not do it weeks ago.

Ann Vanstone QC was appointed, presumably, some months ago. Did you ever complain about that? Did you say, `There is obviously an appearance of bias'? `Vanstone? God, that name rings a bell somewhere. I wonder whether she could be related by marriage? She is, so we'll get up and we'll make the point before anyone can complain that we're only doing this on the run in response to something that doesn't help us. We make it at the very beginning.' Did you do that? Of course you did not do it.

Why does Senator Evans wait until now? It is because he is playing the dirty, grubby political game that Mr Keating plays. Mr Keating, of course, was telling caucus the other day that Fairfax was the most politically corruptly managed newspaper organisation in the country, except for the Western Australian.

Is that the sort of behaviour you want? The trouble is that Senator Gareth Evans and his ilk have been dragged down to that level. If it was not for Mr Keating and his moral standards, you probably would not go for this sort of trick. What you do is not only demean yourself in the political process but also ensure that the public has absolutely no regard for your conduct.

It is one thing to complain about the motivation for setting up a royal commission. I know it hurts. I can understand that. But once you have set up a royal commission, and once you have had people give evidence, what is there to complain about? Are you saying, for example, that any one of those former ministers or former staffers is lying? Are you saying that they are not doing their best to tell the truth and that somehow they have been suborned by the royal commission and somehow are out to get Carmen Lawrence, irrespective of the truth? I have not heard anyone say that yet.
