It is one thing to complain about what leads to the establishment of a royal commission, but once it has been established and you have a very reputable former judge and a very qualified counsel assisting on what basis do you complain about the conduct of that royal commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —Free speech!
—And what do you complain—
—Who are you suing at the moment? You hypocrite; don't talk about free speech.

—If you do not know the difference between free speech and defamation you ought to give the game away. If you think that free speech entitles you to say anything you like, why do you challenge us to go outside? Why does Robert Ray trot the line every couple of months, `Get outside and say it. If you're fair dinkum, get out of cowards castle. Come outside'? The last time he told me to come outside, I went outside and he was not there. I even got Senator Kernot to vouch for me. She is my witness. I said, `Where is he, the wimp?'
—Was this at midnight?

—This was not at midnight. This was right after question time. Where was he when the chips were down? He was nowhere to be seen. He does not believe in freedom of speech. Freedom of speech to you and the Prime Minister is: see it our way, tell it our way and if you do not we will kick you to death, we will denigrate you, we will persecute you, we will hound you and if you have an otherwise impeccable legal reputation we will make sure that your name is mud; we will make sure that people think you simply took 30 pieces of silver; we will hound you into the ground so that we can ultimately discredit you and walk away from the findings of a royal commission if they do not suit us.

PARA.TAB: That is what this tactic is all about. I am amazed that Senator Evans has sunk so low. As Senator Hill quite rightly said, this bloke used to earn a living going around human rights conferences rabbiting on about civil liberties and telling us how important all those things are. If you had asked him 15 years ago whether it was fair enough to get stuck into a royal commissioner because you did not like his politics, he would have said, `That is an appalling suggestion. I think it is outrageous. There are some things in life that are above politics. You ought to have respect for the institutions. We will work to change them democratically.' He would never in his wildest dreams have said that it is all fair game and that if you do not like a royal commission you impugn the integrity of barristers and former judges.

It is patently obvious why you are doing it. You cannot stand the heat. The reason Carmen Lawrence is breaking her neck to get in there and put her story on the record, as if it is not already there, is that suddenly the tide has turned against her massively. She has almost been engulfed by a tidal wave and now she wants to change the rules of calling witnesses. She wants to go to the head of the queue and go on when it suits her.

I would not have thought that was reasonable. There is certainly nothing you can point to on the part of counsel assisting that would in any way suggest that she was properly motivated in making that decision. Yet we have Senator Evans saying that that decision was made for no discernible good reason. In other words, he is completely attacking and impugning the integrity of the commission.

Let us not have all this mealy-mouthed nonsense about him just raising a few questions and putting a few issues on the table. I think everyone understands what he is really on about. That is why this conduct is scurrilous. That is why the Senate ought to express its outrage that Senator Evans has sunk so low. That is why we are very concerned that anyone should be given the opportunity to put their story on the record but they should not control the show. You cannot be judge, jury and witness all at once. You play by the rules of the court.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are acting as judge and jury.

—You will have your day in court, Senator Carr. But I can assure you that you will not be allowed to get up and talk whenever it suits you. You might be able to get away with talking whenever you like in this chamber, but you are not able to do it in royal commissions and courts of law.
—You have to run off to your mates in Victoria and take their case.
—I would plead guilty if I had the brief to represent you. The fact is that you simply cannot take the heat, can you? You are not prepared to acknowledge that Senator Evans has just gone way too far.

PARA.TAB: Michael Lavarch was concerned about an issue recently—that is, the question of cabinet confidentiality and the ruling that was made. Did he go out there and say, `I know what this Marks is on about. He is politically motivated. He is just doing it so he gets Carmen Lawrence'? No, he did not. Effectively he said, `I debate the merits of the issue.' He said, `I did so on the basis of disagreeing with the commissioner's decision, not to impugn his integrity or anything of that sort to put any improper motive upon him but to question the wisdom of that political decision.'

So if you were fair dinkum you would say, `I myself can't see why something should happen in a particular way, but I acknowledge the right of someone in a better position than I to make a decision on the merits.' Is that what he has done? No. He starts out with this disgraceful suggestion that it is a matter between Mr Marks and his conscience. Then he goes even further and suggests that there can be no reasonable explanation for Ann Vanstone making a decision other than the fact that she is politically biased and other than the fact that she is related to a senator in this chamber.

That is pretty low stuff. I would think the public well understands what you are trying to do. They will condemn Senator Evans. They want Carmen Lawrence to have her day at the royal commission. They do want her to put her story on the record. They then want it to be judged. They want it to be weighed up in the balance. They want to look at where the weight of evidence falls.

I am sure you know what the likelihood is. That is what worries you, is it not? You cannot stand the thought that somehow it is not going to go your way so you have decided in advance that by hook or by crook you will put the boots into anyone that you can. It is a shame and you ought to be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —One has to go back and ask the question why this royal commission was set up. It was set up for two reasons and two reasons only. The first reason was to traduce Carmen Lawrence's reputation because she was a federal minister and a political asset to the Labor Party. There is no question about that. That is one of the reasons it was set up. That is the reason. That is the truth. It was set up for that reason. It was not set up when Richard Court came to power in March 1993, for such a critical reason. It was not set up in August 1993. It was not set up in December 1993. It was set up in May 1995.

PARA.TAB: So it was not an urgent issue as to what occurred in parliament some months before the Court government came to power. It was not a matter that pressed them to have a royal commission straight away. It was a matter when Carmen Lawrence came to federal parliament and the Liberal Party wanted to traduce her reputation.

There is a second reason why the royal commission was set up—that is, the Western Australian Liberal Party was in a total mess and a diversion was required. I am not going to go into the details of that mess. I always believe you hunt and kill your own, and that is the responsibility of those on that side. The Western Australian Liberal Party went through turmoil. Whether for good or bad reasons, and I do not make a value judgment, they assassinated the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), they disposed of the member for Moore (Mr Filing), they have gone through all sorts of internal brawlings and now they have got rid of a sitting senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not quite.

—They certainly have got rid of a sitting senator off the Senate ticket. Whether they show this senator any natural justice will be very interesting after the pompous speech by the person who is actually the Senate's loss but a gain to the legal profession from the day he came here.

PARA.TAB: The fact is the Western Australian Liberal Party was in a mess and needed a diversion. The person who really needed the diversion was Premier Court because he was part of all this. There is no use in his stepping aside now and saying he finds Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Campbell or someone else distasteful. He was part of the machine. He was part of the plotting. He was part of that internal viciousness that saw sitting members challenged and dumped.

I do not make a comment on whether their successors are better or worse candidates, but they are in the headlines every day. John Howard, the federal Leader of the Opposition, went over to Western Australia. He addressed them. He could not get out of town fast enough. There was never a faster plane that left Western Australia than he took that particular day to get back to a function in New South Wales. He scuttled out like a slimy, skunky dog to get away from Western Australia because he could not stand the mess.

The reasons why this royal commission was set up are twofold: firstly, to attack Carmen Lawrence and, secondly, to divert attention away from the internal problems of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party. We know that this decision was not made by the Premier. How do we know that? We found out yesterday. The Premier was asked, `Did you consult with John Howard?' He could not remember that, but he did say that the reason why he could not remember it was that he consulted with so many people. With whom did he consult in order to set up this royal commission?

Is this a decision of the government of Western Australia or is it a decision of the Liberal Party of Western Australia? With whom did Mr Court consult? We know he consulted with the leader of the National Party because he had to reduce the terms of reference otherwise the government may have been tangled up in the matter. We know the Premier discussed it with a whole range of people. It is not as though the government has made a decision in principle. The government made a decision to hold the royal commission almost two years after it came to power. That is how urgent it was. The real urgency is in the internecine warfare in the Western Australian Liberal Party.

When we talk about standards of behaviour we should look at the Fremantle by-election. Go back and read the Hansard and see what was said in the House of Representatives. Have a look at the disgraceful comments made by Wilson Tuckey and Eoin Cameron. Those comments were repeated in this chamber and Senator Hill, the great silent leader in this place, sat there and said nothing. Then he comes in today and pompously says that he wants standards of behaviour.

The great silent man, the leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate, sits there and says nothing when these accusations are made. He says nothing at all, as if these accusations do not exist. He does not reprimand his own people for these low standards. He sits there like a quisling, doing nothing about it and letting the hatchet men go to work.

The attitude of the federal opposition reminds me of the Queen of Hearts in Alice in Wonderland. Those opposite have the sentence, now they want the verdict, and later on they will listen to the evidence. That is the way the opposition is behaving in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble is, the evidence is overwhelming.
—Thank you, Judge Roy Bean.

—You could almost say the defence rests. On the basis of several witnesses—not all the witnesses—Judge Roy Bean, alias Senator Alston, has brought down a verdict in this chamber. He has the gall to say that Senator Evans may not make a good judicial person. What about him? The old hanging judge himself has come down with a verdict today in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: There is a valid question of the order of the witnesses. I think any reasonable person would agree perhaps Carmen Lawrence would not appear just now. I can understand the opposition's argument on that because there are court cases and other things. But fancy holding a royal commission and not calling the person who put the petition down in the first few weeks! Fancy doing that! Fancy not calling the clerk of the Legislative Council who helped draw it up and who has great knowledge of these things! Why not? Why doesn't that happen if it is such a decent royal commission? Why won't they call those people? Why does Mr Halden have to defend himself and others in the Bulletin today? Because he will not be called to give evidence!

The fact is that this royal commission is a political exercise. It is a perversion of what royal commissions should stand for. We have had some problems in the past with royal commissions because of the evidence rules. Royal commissions are different from courts and the rules of evidence that apply there. As a result, we reserve royal commissions for very important occasions. Senator Evans has gone through them in some detail.

But we have never had a royal commission into the behaviour of a parliamentarian. That is a matter for the parliament to determine. The parliament has an inquiry, it determines the matter, and it is over. But, no, in this case we have a royal commission set up. Normally royal commissions look at issues of criminality, security, corruption—all those sorts of things. There is nothing suggested in this case that involves those matters.

The hypocrisy and the double standards of this opposition! Who introduced these matters into the Western Australian parliament? They have not commented on it once. In 1986, who probably breached the Family Court Act and dumped all this onto the public domain? Mr Richard Court did so, and two of his colleagues later expanded on it. We have a 14-page speech on this stuff.

But, of course, the terms of reference are very carefully crafted not to go to these particular matters—that might be embarrassing. It might be embarrassing to get Mr Court there and say, `Who gave you the information from this Family Court case? Why did you put it on the record?' I might go to Mr Lightfoot and all those others who did so. But, for the royal commission—the fair royal commission whose process Senator Alston supports—the terms of reference do not go to any of these matters. Why don't they? It does not suit the self-interest of the Liberal Party of Western Australia to go to any of these areas.

Questions of conflict of interest are difficult ones for this chamber or anyone else to deal with. For instance, Senator Vanstone inferred in a question in Hansard on 23 August about Stephen Loosley being a junior employee of a law firm that in some way there was some corrupt or implied relationship and that they had been given the work because Senator Loosley works there. That is a dubious one, I agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually don't think it was that dubious.

—When it comes to family relationships, where were you, Senator Vanstone, when your colleagues here attacked a senator at the back of this room for whom she was married to? Not a word from you. Not a word from Senator Hill. The usual moralist, the usual standard-setter, was silent when Senator Neal was attacked by Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Michael Baume. Not one word in defence.
—How did I attack her?

—By way of interjection. I was sitting here and I heard you, Senator. You said nothing. So it is all right to attack Senator Neal for whom she is married to. It is all right for Senator Abetz to yell out about Justice McHugh today. It is all right for Senator Abetz to attack Ms Woods in an estimates committee because she was married to an ACTU executive member. It is okay to ask, `Whom are you married to?'
—I only asked a question.

—You asked the question, `Who are you married to?' Go back and look in the Hansard. It is all right for you to set those standards. Mr Silence sits here silent again. The gutless leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate says nothing, yet he expects other people on this side to have different standards. We apply to you the standards that you apply to us.

PARA.TAB: This royal commission from start to finish has been a kangaroo court; it is a political exercise. What we in this chamber are involved in is an extension of that political exercise. There has not been one question ever over there of this sort: `This isn't a political exercise. Why doesn't the Western Australian government fund the people that are appearing before it? Why don't they meet their legal fees if it is not a political exercise? Why don't they meet Mr Halden's fees? Why don't they meet Carmen Lawrence's fees?' All these questions remain unanswered. We have no contribution from you on any of these issues—on not one of these issues do we get a contribution from that side.

They talk, in ideal terms, about `justice', `fairness' and `reputation', and what do they do? They endorse crooked process and the traducing of reputations, day in and day out. That is not done by Senator Hill; I admit that. He lets his other lackeys at the back do it. He sits there silent; he never intervenes.

TALK.START.PARA: —He washes his hands of it.

—As Senator West says, he just washes his hands. He would probably say, `They're a pretty ugly bunch. They're a bit nasty. I can't control them'—the classic quisling excuses that we have come to expect from him.
—I ask Senator Ray to withdraw that remark. It was demanded of me at lunch time today.
—What remark?
—The `quisling'.
—If you referred to somebody as a quisling, I ask you to withdraw it.
—On this occasion I have referred to him as quisling-like, but earlier I did call him a quisling, so I withdraw that. It was not picked up, obviously, at the time.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did withdraw. `Quisling-like' is not a breach of standing orders. But if it is, I withdraw it.
—I have asked you to withdraw it for the sake of the Senate.
—Sure. For the decorum of the Senate that has been shown today, I withdraw.
—On a point of order: we should ask Senator Ray to withdraw the term he used when he said Senator Hill was gutless, because nobody could say that about Senator Ray.

—I appreciate Senator Herron's medical opinion and I acknowledge the fact that he is a doctor. We have to acknowledge that every day and every minute he is here, because he is a superior human being. We all know that. So we defer to him as a superior human being but one with hopeless political judgment. To sum up, what this censure motion is about today—

—I know it is hard to bring a point of order on relevance on a censure motion, but Senator Ray said he was about to sum up when he has not got to the censure motion yet. The censure motion, may I remind him, is on the attack made by Senator Evans yesterday on the integrity of Royal Commissioner Marks and Ms Vanstone. So he might just address that and defend his client before he sits down.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—To solve this, I withdraw the words, `I am about to sum up'. It is absolutely appropriate that we go to the rationale, the reason and the motive as to why Senator Hill has brought this motion forward today.

PARA.TAB: The reason Senator Hill has brought this motion forward today, I allege, is that he is full of double standards and hypocrisy on these issues because he expects a different standard on this side than he is willing to enforce on that side. In adducing that, I have shown him not to have criticised the timing of the royal commission, which occurred two years after the Court government came into power.

Secondly, any time accusations are made of some relationship between people as it may affect a conflict of interest, when it has been raised on that side of the chamber by senators consistently, Senator Hill has been silent. If anyone deserves to be censured in this place, it is Senator Hill, the leaderless leader of the Liberal Party in this place, because he enforces no standards whatsoever; none whatsoever. He is quite happy to sit there while people's reputations are smeared, while lies are told, and never ever intervene himself as leader on any of these issues—quite happy to do so to protect his leader's position so he does not come in conflict with his more rough-head backbench.

This is, as I said before, merely an extension of the whole political exercise. This opposition has found Carmen Lawrence and others guilty. They do not care about propriety, process or anything else. They could not care less about any of those particular issues. But they are more damned by their silence. They know in their heart of hearts that this is a political royal commission set up for political purposes, with restricted terms of reference and with a stacked order of appearance for witnesses.

I thought the lynch mentality had gone out of this country 100 years ago but, with the evidence from Senator Alston and Senator Hill today, it remains as viable as ever before. They expect us to behave under attack from them and have a higher standard than they have. So do I expect us to have a higher standard because I would hate to sink to the standards of the Liberal Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to contribute to this censure motion of Senator Gareth Evans for his attack yesterday, thinly disguised—as he says today, as he finally admits—as questions. Nonetheless, the purpose and intent of his remarks were perfectly clear. The purpose and intent of those remarks, dressed up as questions, do not change just because you put question marks at the end. The grammar does not necessarily change the meaning and intent of what he wanted to get at.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Evans stood up and did yesterday—which I noticed Senator Alston has said he has had plenty of opportunity to do from the beginning of the commission—because his government perceived that they were in trouble over this issue, was to engage in a shameful attack on someone simply because of whom their relatives are. By doing that, he impugned the integrity not only of the commission and its staff but also, I might add, of myself. It is not possible for the allegation to stand that there is some collusion between me and my sister-in-law unless you come to the conclusion that I would stoop to interfere in royal commission proceedings. You must come to that conclusion in order to make that allegation.

Since last year I have tipped off the Attorney-General's Department on something that they did not know—that is, they had a hole in their e-mail system the size of Texas—and since I returned to them in disk form what, if printed out, would have been the equivalent of a small truck load of documents, I am somewhat amazed that this government would stoop to challenge my integrity in the parliamentary process, let alone that of my sister-in-law. I have always believed that actions speak louder than words, and those actions speak for themselves. Let me move on.

This attack yesterday was the sixth or seventh in a series of attacks. First of all, when the announcement of the commission was made, we had the attacks primarily by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), but then by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who issued a dark warning to any judicial officer or former judicial officer or member of the profession who took part in these proceedings. The message was you will regret it if you do. That is how this started off: you will regret it if you do. The Prime Minister was a party to that attack; he probably set up Stephen Smith. But it does not matter which one set up the other; they were both in it up to their necks. It was a clear warning to any member of the profession, any member of the judiciary, any former member of the judiciary: you take part in this and you are fair game; we will tear you down. As Senator Ray says, we will go for hunt and kill. That is where it started. That is only the start.

The second attack was to say that it does not matter anyway because this is a witch-hunt. Government members seek to rely on the fact that the commission was set up this year to say that it is obviously out to get Dr Lawrence because she is a federal government minister. They seem to misunderstand that Dr Lawrence is somehow entwined in this royal commission not because she is a federal government minister but because she was a minister, the prime minister, the Premier at the time these matters arose. Senator Ray put much store on the timing. He said that it was not done immediately; that there was no urgency, otherwise it would have been done immediately. The fact that completely escaped his mind was that the royal commission into WA Inc.—set up by Dr Lawrence herself—inquired into matters around 10 years old.

Royal commissions are not knee-jerk reactions. They are not something you pull on one day to do the next and to satisfy some immediate political need. They are a final resort. They are something you are drawn to when all other processes have not worked. When the community has lost faith in the political process, that is when you go outside parliament, that is when you set up a royal commission, that is when you look for independent counsel to assist the commission, and that is when you look for an independent commissioner and set up a royal commission.

As I said, the second attack on this commission was that it was a witch-hunt. They sought to say that it was only called because she is a federal government minister, neglecting the fact that her involvement in it is because she was the Premier at the time, because all other processes have not been able to resolve the matter and because Western Australians are entitled to know whether their Premier at the time lied to them. That is an essential matter to the functioning of the proper parliamentary system. It simply does not work if cabinet ministers are allowed to lie and get away with it. If the truth cannot be got through the parliamentary process, one necessarily shifts to a royal commission.

What was the third attempt? The third attempt at denigrating this commission was trying to scuttle it by tipping heaps and heaps of hard-earned taxpayers' money into it. They are people not earning as much as anybody here. The government has said, `Let's take their taxes and put $10,000 a day into Carmen's case to see whether we can scuttle this commission.' That was the third attempt at denigrating this commission.

When it was apparent that that attempt to denigrate the commission was not going to work immediately, they moved on to the fourth attempt, which was to pursue injunctive proceedings to shut down the commission. They were not happy when they lost that in the Supreme Court, so where did they go at taxpayers' expense?—all the way to the High Court, using hard-earned taxpayers' money.

They said, `Let's see whether we can shut this down. We failed at attempt one, we failed at attempt two and we failed at attempt three, so we will go all the way to the High Court and see whether, in the fourth attempt, we can shut this commission down. We don't want to hear what people have to say. We don't want to hear what former Labor ministers, close colleagues and staffers of Dr Lawrence have to say. We must shut this commission down.'

Of course, when that did not work, they moved to chuck weapon No. 5 on the bonfire. They said, `Let's have a go at the commissioner. Let's ask him, through the Leader of the Government in the Senate, whether he can sleep happily at night with his conscience. Let's cast some doubt on the integrity of the commissioner. When all else has failed, let's go to the commissioner and see whether we can bring him down. Let's implement the first threat: to hunt and destroy any member of the profession, any member of the judiciary and any former member of the judiciary who goes anywhere near this commission.' They tried an attack on the commissioner. They asked him to check his conscience when he lays awake at night and worries whether he is doing the right thing, as though he would not every minute of the day be concerning himself with whether he was doing the right thing.

When attack No. 5 did not appear to work, they moved on to No. 6. That is where they got stuck into the commission for its process. As Senator Hill said, perhaps Senator Evans did this by appearances in the magistrate court. How he ever got his QC appointment we are at a loss to understand. I note that Senator Hill rightly points out that my sister-in-law got hers by hard work, not by ingratiating herself in the political process. Nonetheless, the sixth weapon was getting stuck into the processes of the commission. They said, `We do not know all the witnesses or what they are all going to say. We who want to scuttle it, shut it down and denigrate it will now take the high ground and say that we know how to run it. Furthermore, because you are not running it the way that we want it run, you must be a pack of politically motivated royal commissioners and staff because you now will not do what we want.' I think that was the sixth attempt to in some way to damage the commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixth.

—I think it is the sixth. I will go through them for you again later if you have lost count. The seventh was this disgraceful attack yesterday on counsel assisting. What is that designed to do? It is designed to do one of two things: firstly, to ensure that she in some way is shifted away from the process so that the public lacks confidence in any work that she might do; or, secondly, as a subsidiary motive, to ensure that my party is stupid enough to say that I should pack up my political skills and give up my job because of the job my sister-in-law has taken on. Like hell I will!

PARA.TAB: I have been on this issue because hard-earned taxpayers' money is being spent by the Attorney-General in a way that I believe is illegal. That is my job. That is what I am paid to do. I will not be psyched out from doing that by some stupid little attack from the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I will not be psyched out from doing that job.

Senator Evans and members opposite have interjected in this vicious attack, smear and slur on my sister-in-law simply because by accident of birth she happens to be the sister of the man I married and for no other reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —That should be punished—I agree, Amanda.

—You will get your turn, mate. Innuendo has been raised about the counsel from South Australia. They think there must be something bad in that. What they forget, which we all know, is that the last royal commission in Western Australia—the one into WA Inc.—appointed by Dr Carmen Lawrence chose a South Australian counsel to be counsel assisting, which was Mr Brian Martin QC. He established for himself an excellent reputation. He did a very good job.

PARA.TAB: So the precedent for going to South Australia to get counsel assisting in a Western Australian commission was set by Dr Lawrence herself. Can we believe it! We'd better believe it, because it is true. What would have occurred to these people on the other side, who purport to have a brain—especially those in the B-team behind—is that Brian Martin QC was the Crown Solicitor in South Australia. My sister-in-law went to work for the Crown very early in her career, in 1979. She spent something like a decade, give or take a year or two, working for Brian Martin and learning from him.

What do you suppose happened the next time a commission came up in Western Australia? I do not know how she got this appointment, but I think it is a fair bet that somebody said, `Brian Martin did a good job; why don't you go and ask him?' or `Why don't you get someone that trained under him—someone out of the same school to do the same sort of job?' That is what I believe happened. But of course, Mr President, they were not bright enough to think of that. It did not occur to them that Dr Lawrence actually started this process of appointing South Australian counsel to Western Australian royal commissions.

Somebody could have picked up the phone and rung Chris Sumner, the former Labor Attorney-General in South Australia. You would think that someone over there—even Schachtie, who looks asleep half the time—would have had the brains to pick up the phone and say, `Hey, Chris, what do you reckon about this Vanstone woman; what do you think?' Perhaps even Senator Bolkus might have had the brains to do that.
Opposition senators—No!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Perhaps not. Mr President, I have canvassed for you that my sister-in-law worked in the Crown Law Office under Brian Martin QC, rose to be the Deputy Crown Prosecutor 10 years later in 1989—under a Labor government, I might add—and then finally rose to be Assistant DPP. You would think that since Attorney-General Sumner was the Attorney-General for most of, if not for all of, those years, someone would have thought to say to him, `Hey, what do you think?' It is perfectly clear what he thinks. He took the opportunity to make a comment when she was made a Queen's Counsel. He made it clear that his government had decided they would not appoint any more Queen's Counsel. Of course, we are still waiting for Gareth Evans to give his up. But, nonetheless, he made it clear that his government had made that decision. He went on and said, `If you are going to have a Queen's Counsel, Ann Vanstone is an excellent appointment.'

PARA.TAB: So why is it that Ann Vanstone's integrity is being traduced in this place today by people from the same party when their own Attorney-General, the person who had been head of the department with which she has worked for something like 13 or 14 years, says, `She is an excellent candidate for performing the job of Queen's Counsel'—which would, presumably, qualify one for being counsel assisting in a commission? And Senator Evans, ill-informed as he is, says there is no precedent for this sort of commission with someone's sister or brother—sibling—acting in that commission.

Obviously, those opposite have forgotten the Fitzgerald royal commission and are not familiar with what is happening now in the New South Wales commission into the police. In the Fitzgerald royal commission, Gary Crooke QC was counsel assisting. His brother, Ken Crooke, was at the time the Queensland State Director of the National Party. I have yet to hear someone try to traduce Mr Crooke's reputation for the job that he did in the Fitzgerald royal commission. I have yet to hear that. It is a history lesson Senator Evans is yet to have.

Mr President, I move on to highlight the peculiar nature of this vicious and unwarranted attack on my sister-in-law. As the point has been made with respect to Justice McHugh, who in this place queries Justice McHugh's entitlement to sit in the High Court simply because his wife has a job in the House of Representatives? Who over there is prepared to query that? Who is prepared to say that whenever the Commonwealth is a participant in High Court proceedings he should have no opportunity to form part of the bench on those occasions, or hear matters in the first instance as a single judge? Who over there is prepared to say that? Who over there is prepared to say that there is bias in that matter?

I will tell you why you are not prepared to say that. It is because the relationship between Justice McHugh and his wife is open and on the table. There is nothing to hide; it is all open for us all to see. That is why Justice McHugh did not disqualify himself, for example, from being part of the bench in the political ad bans case. Why would he? He was appointed on merit; the relationship with his wife is open. It is there for all to make an objective assessment about. There is nothing underhand about this. It is not like, I might say, the case I raised earlier this year where the judge had what was described as a serious and close relationship—I think that means sleeping—with a fellow who was a solicitor for one of the parties, and that relationship was not disclosed. That was the problem in that matter.

For those of you who want to go back to the Hansard, I made the point of saying that I was not attacking the integrity of the judge but I was attacking, and I still condemn, both the Attorney-General and the Chief Justice of the Family Court for the disgraceful way in which they handled that matter. I was not going to raise that matter as I do not want to attack the integrity of the judge, but I just point out the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just did.

—You raised it; I just point out the difference. The relationship there was not open, was not above board and was not on the table for everyone to see. The relationship between Justice McHugh and his wife is there for everyone to see. As Senator Alston said, anyone with half a brain could see Vanstone and Vanstone. They might read the Financial Review and realise very early on that there is no hiding the fact that she is my sister-in-law. What about Sir Gerard Brennan? Does anybody get stuck into him because of his son's role as spokesperson for Aborigines? Does anybody say that he was not entitled to sit on the Mabo case?
—This is a long bow. This is a real long bow, Amanda.

—Senator Collins says that this is a long bow. I fail to see the difference between a father-son relationship and a sister and sister-in-law relationship. I think the analogy is pretty good. Did anyone suggest that Sir Gerard Brennan should not have sat on that case? Of course not. I certainly did not.

PARA.TAB: Let us move to the Gai Waterhouse amendment that I notice Senator Evans trying to squirm out of in one way or another. This is the government that says you cannot discriminate against someone because of the identity of your spouse but, all of a sudden, you can get up in parliament and deliver a vicious slur, disguised as a question, at someone, for no other reason than because, by accident of birth, they happen to be related to someone.

In the committee's report, Mr Lavarch, then a backbencher, and the committee said that a fundamental premise of the Sex Discrimination Act is that an individual should be judged on his or her own merits, and it recommended discrimination based on the identity of a person's spouse should be prohibited—specifically aimed at the Gai Waterhouse situation. It is a bit thin now, is it not, since this government wants to preach lack of discrimination against someone on the basis of the identity of their relatives but does not want to practise it—something we see so often in this place.

Mr President, I think I have made the case that I wanted to make to you. It is this: this vicious slur yesterday was just another in a long list of attempts to denigrate this commission. It is one of a long list of reasons why those opposite want to find opportunities to denigrate this commission. Why do they want to do that? Because they think they will want to denigrate the findings. Why would they think that? Because they suspect they know what the findings will be.

I will recap—for the benefit of Senator Evans, who seemed to lose count—before I conclude. The attacks on the integrity of the commission are these: No. 1, attacks by the Prime Minister and Stephen Smith clearly warning any member, or former member, of the judiciary, or member of the profession, to keep away. No. 2, calling it a witch hunt—`Let's pretend this is not about parliamentary integrity; let's pretend it is all about Carmen Lawrence and her political career. Let's forget the need to look at cabinet responsibility; let's forget to look at the need for ministers to tell the truth; let's just protect Carmen.'

No. 3—attack No. 3, if you are keeping count, Senator Evans—funding to scuttle the royal commission. Attack No. 4, injunctive proceedings to shut it down. Attack No. 5, `Let's get into the commissioner himself and query his conscience; tell him he should lie awake at night and worry about what he's doing.' Attack No. 6, get stuck into the commission processes, even though this is the commission you do not want and do not want to be a part of—the commission you want to shut down—and then not worry about that because you will be entitled at any point to jump up and say, `I know better than any of you guys how to run this, and now I, Dr Lawrence, want to come on first but, by the way, I've got some witnesses that have to come before me because I think I know how to run this.' As has been said before, Dr Lawrence only wants things one way—her way—all the time.

Attack No. 7 is an attack on counsel assisting the commission. I do not think that is the end of the list. This is going to go on day after day after day until this government has satisfied itself that it can so rubbish this commission that it will be able to turn its back on any finding. It will have the safety valve of being able to do that and keep Dr Lawrence in office. That was your vicious slur yesterday, pathetically disguised today. What a weak, pathetic excuse it was for someone of your intellect to come in here and say, `It was just a question I was asking.' It ought to give me pleasure as someone who opposes your party to see you reduced to that level, but frankly I am embarrassed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been a member of the Senate chamber for 12 years or more and I have never seen the Senate stoop so low as it has today. This motion brings the Senate down to a new low of hypocrisy. The motion itself is hypocritical in the extreme, and it is not surprising that it is. It is hypocritical because hypocrites by their very nature want to turn the accusation of hypocrisy to others. That is what this motion does—it turns what the opposition is guilty of towards the government and does so in a way and on a basis which has no substance to speak of.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a lot of artificial and false claims of principle on the opposition side. In this debate I will deal once again with the issues of hypocrisy to which Senator Vanstone has just referred and of which she herself is guilty. I will deal as well with the circumstances in which the royal commission—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask you, Senator Cook, to be careful of the word `hypocrisy'.

—I refer to the Liberal-National party, who have given rise to this motion. I refer to the collective conduct of honourable senators opposite, who are members of that party, and I am within standing orders in doing so.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I understand that it is quite clear that a reference to a party in which senators serve is just as offensive as if it is made directly to an individual senator of that party.
—I was about to make the same point myself. Senator Abetz is correct. The word `hypocrisy' has many precedents as being out of order.

—In which case double standards apply here. In politics people are hypocrites and if I am unable to use that term here I will not, Mr President, out of deference to your ruling and I will withdraw. But double standards do apply here. People outside this place are aware of that and are keenly interested in pinning it down when it does occur—and in this motion it has occurred.

PARA.TAB: The attack that has been launched on Senator Evans and on the government is an attack of no substance whatsoever and does not stand up to any forensic scrutiny at all. What we have heard is a precious, self-aggrandising performance by Senator Vanstone which goes to her significant role in this matter and which does not stand up on her own tests—the tests she has applied that are the tests that ought to apply to people in public office, the tests she has applied that should apply to things judicial. I note that when I make that remark she has not the courage to remain here and hear the detail of the point. What Senator Evans did yesterday was not make allegations, as has been said in this motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too late. You are out of your seat and you can't come back. He never did that. He asked questions which are reasonable and proper questions to be put in these circumstances. I commend him for having the courage to ask the questions, which were on the minds of most of the people in the Australian community. It is important that those questions were asked.

PARA.TAB: But before I turn to the detail of that, one of the things that I do agree with about this whole circumstance is that there is a massive injustice being perpetrated here. The massive injustice is not the injustice that is the subject of this motion. The massive injustice is the injustice that there is a royal commission at all into this affair in Western Australia and that the Senate has not moved to condemn the holding of that royal commission or the government that gave rise to it.

What is true is that the government of Western Australia is mortally divided about the efficacy of holding this royal commission in the first place. We know that the deputy premier exercised considerable disquiet within the cabinet about that and leaked his disquiet to the Western Australian media. We know that the leader of the coalition party—the National Party—Hendy Cowan, did the same. They did it because they were concerned about the impropriety of the Premier of Western Australia dragging his government down the road of holding this royal commission.

What is the offence? The outstanding offence here is this royal commission. The fact that it is a judicial function and is steeped in judicial powers should not deflect anyone from recognising that, nonetheless, its origins and birth give rise to a political purpose that, as has been said in this debate, has nothing to do with whether or not anyone conducted themselves in a manner in which they abused their powers in office; nothing to do with whether anyone conducted themselves in a way that would endanger the national security; nothing to do with whether anyone was involved in financial mismanagement; and nothing to do with whether anyone misconducted themselves in terms of the exercise of executive power. It has nothing to do, in fact, with what have been the grounds, historically in this country, for the holding of royal commissions.

What it has to do with is a political assassination of the reputation of the minister for health in this government, because she is a successful minister. As Senator Ray pointed out, we waited three years for this royal commission to arise. It was not urgent when the Court government came to power; it was not urgent in the first or second year of office. Suddenly, this royal commission is put on for the very reason that Carmen Lawrence is a successful minister; and she has to be destroyed. Also, we know it was put on to cover the massive disputation within the Liberal Party of Western Australia over the so-called—and I recognise him opposite—Noel Crichton-Browne affair which was disrupting the party. They needed a smokescreen to deflect public attention from that.

Let me go to the details of the allegation. I will do so by starting with the words of Senator Amanda Vanstone when she talked about what has to happen in terms of justice being done and justice being seen to be done. Earlier, Senator Evans said that when he asked his questions he did so in order to establish not whether justice was being done, but whether—appropriately and properly, as a principle of our justice system—it was being seen to be done. On that subject, what has Amanda Vanstone, the shadow Attorney-General, said? I quote from an adjournment debate in Hansard on page 1716. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to distinguish between a finding of appearance of bias and actual bias. A finding of appearance of bias at law will overturn a decision on the basis that justice must not only be done, but must be seen to be done. The threshold for overturning a decision is therefore the appearance of bias. The question of whether actual bias was displayed need not be addressed. Confidence in the judicial system will be lost if there is a public perception of bias in the courts.
That was not an island opinion, isolated just to that occasion. She said further:
It is clear that the judge's action in creating an appearance of bias could in itself amount to misconduct.

So when you ask the question, `What is the relationship between two people who have a family relationship but are both key actors in this issue,' it goes to the very issue that Senator Vanstone herself was raising—the appearance of justice.

PARA.TAB: This is an area of well-travelled judicial principle, an area in which there is great concern for precision and certainty. It is an area in which there was some doubt, given the principal roles of the actors, and needed to be put beyond doubt. Therefore, it was a reasonable question to ask. Has it been answered? Have we got a clear declaration from Senator Vanstone about it? Has she put it unequivocally beyond doubt that there is no discussion, or any sort of discussion, and things are acting in a way in which propriety holds all and the well-travelled principles of legal conduct are beyond dispute? No, she hasn't. She had her opportunity a few minutes ago to do that.

Did she come out unequivocally and do it? Absolutely not. Given that she had her opportunity, why didn't she? She was invited to by Senator Gareth Evans, but she squibbed it. She did not say it and the question still hangs while she dodges it. The issue is: if she is dodging it, why is she dodging it? She was given a clear invitation and she should, to rightly and properly clear up this mess, say so openly. But it is now a matter of record in the Senate that she did not. One can only assume, since she knew, that she dodged it; and, therefore, that does raise a significant question, and one that ought to be pursued.

The other questions that were asked in that exchange go to issues that are in the mind of ordinary people—the plain person, the man or woman on the Pentonville omnibus, the person who forms what is a reasonable person's view of what is appropriate in these circumstances. There are questions about this commission that ought to be properly asked. Given its birth, given the controversy of it, given its purpose, given the political inspiration and witch-hunt character of the way in which the Liberal government in Western Australia set it up, there are a series of questions about its conduct that now should be asked.

Why are the witnesses being streamed in the way in which they are? Why are people who are being traduced in the public debate, like Carmen Lawrence, who speaks out for herself, getting a warning from the commission that if they do so they will be in contempt? No-one else got a warning. Everyone else was speaking out. Editorial writers were opining away. Commentators on television were giving views. It was a matter of notorious public debate. But as soon as Carmen Lawrence said, `Hang on. I am the victim of all this. I'd like to say my piece,' the commissioner says, `If you do, you'll be in contempt.' What are her rights? She does have them. She is entitled to some respect. This is not a trial, as Senator Alston would say. It is not a trial, although he claims it to have been a trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not. Mr President, I raise a point of order. As you will see later from the Hansard, I sat beside Senator Alston at the time he gave his speech and he did not say that Dr Lawrence was on trial.
—There is no point of order. If Senator Alston wants to make a personal explanation, he can do it later.

—It is not a trial, but she is being treated as if she is in the dock as a defendant. Unexamined witnesses come to give evidence and everyone goes off and forms a political judgment on it. What right does she have to defend herself in those circumstances? She is entitled to, but as soon as she says, `Hang on, I want to say something,' the commissioner says, `You'll be in contempt if you do.' I think that is a travesty of rights because she is being tried in the public domain politically, and she is being tried in the royal commission legally or judicially under the authority of the Western Australian government.

PARA.TAB: A fundamental right is the right of the individual to defend herself. Even if she happens to be a successful minister for health in a successful Labor government which will be re-elected next election, she is entitled to defend herself against being traduced in the political arena. I think the perfidy of the opposition in this is beyond belief and beyond imagination. This royal commission was set up to assassinate the political reputation of this person.

In the normal course of any judicial function in a circumstance like this, the foundational thing would be to give that person, at least, the right of funding so they can defend themselves in the process. Has the Western Australian government funded Carmen Lawrence after having set up a royal commission to attack her? They have not. As soon as we, as the federal government, say, `This is one of our ministers who is being attacked because she is one of our ministers, and for no other reason, so if they won't do the right thing we will,' we get attacked by the opposition. Where is the honesty, where is the sincerity, and where is the principle in that?

What are the rights of the person being attacked here? Of course, the rights of the person are to have a legitimate defence. That goes to challenging the efficacy of the process that is attacking her. There is principle in that. Nick Greiner challenged ICAC and got funded for challenging it. Your former Premier, Mr Gray, got funding to challenge the Rouse royal commission. They are the precedents you have set. But when it comes to us, do we get the right of those precedents? No! You say we cannot have those rights. We say we are entitled to them and this government will defend those principles and those rights.

I come to a conclusion and I come to a conclusion about standards because this debate has come down to standards. What this government has made absolutely crystal clear on the public record is that we stand for the highest standards of ministerial conduct and we do not resile from that point in the face of anybody. But, since you raised the question of standards, let us look at your standards for a minute.

On your front bench under the leadership of John Howard is the honourable Wilson Tuckey who appeared recently on national television declaring himself to be a liar. He said it. I am quoting him; I think that is in order, that he said that. Yet he is maintained on the front bench, a self-proclaimed liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wasn't at the time.

—He wasn't at the time! Whether he was on the front bench or off the front bench, he is a liar no matter what because he said he was a liar and he is a liar wherever he sits, at the back of the room or at the front of the room—a self-proclaimed liar; therefore, he is a liar.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, who else do we have on the front bench? My shadow, Mr Moore, described as `a treacherous person' by the current Leader of the Opposition, John Howard—`a treacherous person' being sent out, if there was ever a Howard government, to industry dealing with commercial-in-confidence matters. What sort of reputation do you think you would have in the commercial world? What sort of person would Mr Howard be tolerating someone he has branded as `treacherous' sitting on his own front bench?

Let's talk about standards—let's talk about the standards on which you attack people on this side because of who they are married to. Let's talk about you attacking people in the nature of Stephen Loosley because he is associated with a law firm which is, in one sense, related to this action, as if he, Steve Loosley, is guilty of this. What a joke! These are not standards. You are a disgrace and the people of Australia know you are a disgrace.

This motion is launched today not only to assassinate the reputation of Carmen Lawrence but to bring down the reputation of the Leader of the Government here, Senator Evans, to provide a smokescreen over your lack of standards and your impropriety and because you know you are losing this argument on the Lawrence affair and the electors are turning against you because they can see you for what you are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Cook on his contribution because it effectively cleared the chamber. Because Senator Cook's boring, nay, his irrelevant contribution highlights his penchant for `rhetrical' contributions.
—`Rhetrical'?
—`Rhetrical' contributions. Senator Cook comes in here with all his new buzz words, does not know how to pronounce them and then tries to ask us to believe him.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that the government has woven a web of deceit, starting with certain comments and each time the issue keeps going they have to add to this total package. Let's look at what the motion actually says. It has nothing to do with the royal commission. It has nothing to do with Dr Lawrence's behaviour. It has nothing to do with the opposition. The motion deals with Senator Gareth Evans's cowardly and unfounded attack upon the integrity and reputation of Royal Commissioner Marks and counsel assisting, Ms Ann Vanstone QC.

Senator Cook and others have tried to assert, as did Senator Evans, that all they were doing was raising questions. Allow me to read from the Hansard of yesterday—and it is very telling because Senator Evans starts off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to be taken as undermining family values—-
Then he gets cut off on a point of order. There is half a column of Hansard and then Senator Evans continues:
As I was saying, I do not want to be taken as undermining family values on the principle that the family that preys together—spelt `e-y-s'—stays together.

In other words, what Senator Evans did was pre-meditated. He thought about it. It was not a spur of the moment assertion, question or allegation. He had thought about it. He had pre-meditated and tried to assert that because Amanda Vanstone and Ann Vanstone are related through marriage, somehow they had `preyed' together and set out to somehow corrupt the royal commission and the outcomes of that royal commission. That is what we are debating today.

PARA.TAB: I fully accept that in the heat of political debate one can make a silly comment and that after some hours one can say, `Look, I have made a mistake. Yes, I do apologise.' That is what Senator Robert Hill gave Senator Evans today. He gave him the opportunity to apologise for that gross statement about Ms Vanstone QC. The sort of honour that would be required of a UN general secretary, the sort of honour that you might expect from a High Court judge, is not to be found in Senator Evans. After 24 hours reflection, there is an incapacity to apologise.

Instead, he digs himself in deeper by trying to assert that all he was doing was raising a question. He did more than raise a question. He made the direct allegation that the family that `preyed' together stayed together. The implication was very clear for the Vanstone family. Senator Evans, you ought to be ashamed of that. You ought to have the integrity to apologise, but, unfortunately, you do not. Senator Evans's contributions on this matter in recent times make a pig's grunt sound eloquent.

Even if we were to accept that there is some hint of bias, they have not answered the question about Justice McHugh, who is married to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. His Honour has to sit on the High Court bench and make determinations on federal legislation which has a profound effect on the Australian Labor Party and this government. Yet nobody on the Labor side of the chamber is suggesting that he ought to resign or, indeed, that Ms McHugh ought to resign her ministry.

The brother of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, is a member of the Labor Party. Should John Howard's brother resign from the Australian Labor Party because he is related to John Howard, the Leader of the Liberal Party? That is the sort of mentality that has been injected into this debate by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the man who would be a High Court judge or the general secretary of the United Nations.

As I have said, to err is human. We can all make mistakes, but when you are given the opportunity to apologise you ought to have the good grace to apologise. If Senator Evans did that, we would have had the full question time today. Of course, the grace to apologise does not rest in the soul of Senator Evans.

Just in case people think that this is a Liberal beat-up, because that is the way those speakers opposite have tried to present it today, let me quote from Mike Seccombe. I have to say that in my 18 months in this place I have not known Mike Seccombe to be an apologist for the Liberal and National parties. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Funny that they—
referring to the Labor Party—
should think the kind of defamatory slur that got them in this mess should get them out.

The defamatory slur is what started this mess, and they have perpetuated it right through. They continued it yesterday and repeated it today. What Mike Seccombe did was point out that somehow they think that if they repeat the tactic they will get themselves out of the trouble that that sort of defamatory slur got them into in the first place.

PARA.TAB: Then there are the attacks on the royal commission because of the timing of the calling of witnesses. Let us remember that the minister, Carmen Lawrence, did not want to appear before the royal commission. She wanted to abolish the royal commission. Now, all of a sudden, she wants to appear. As I have said in this place before, I think it is highly appropriate that any witness that might give evidence to which Dr Lawrence might wish to respond, ought to give his or her evidence first to give Dr Lawrence the capacity to respond. Procedural fairness would dictate that. There is no way that one could argue against that.

What would Dr Lawrence be saying if she was the first witness called and then there was a cricket team of witnesses giving evidence contrary to her evidence which she did not have the opportunity to respond to? She would have to be called again and again. What absolute nonsense. Senator Evans ought to know a lot better about procedural fairness. I have spoken about Mike Seccombe's comments, but what about Peter Cole-Adams from the Canberra Times? He says about your behaviour, Senator Evans:
At one point, Evans went over the top, in an ugly reference to Ann Vanstone . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

PARA.TAB: Nasty stuff. Evans might have got away with it if he had been content merely to make the point—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, about the principle of impartiality. He then went over the top. Senator Vanstone then reminded him about the legislation that this government is supposedly supporting whereby it would be illegal to discriminate against somebody on the basis of whom they are married to.

PARA.TAB: We could talk about the royal commission. We could say that it all started because Dr Lawrence wanted to torpedo Richard Court and that it has backfired. It has blown up in her face. That is not the content of this motion. This motion talks about the cowardly and unfounded attack on the integrity and reputation of Royal Commissioner Marks and counsel assisting. That is what we have to confine our remarks to today. I have referred to the comments of Mike Seccombe and Peter Cole-Adams. I believe every other decent thinking Australian would say that we should keep those sorts of relationships out of it.

What we have is an arrogant government. This a government which had people such as Graham Richardson, who said, `Don't worry about morality. The only question is whatever it takes.' Senator Robert Ray told us that in the political process `we hunt and kill our own'. What a great statesman, what a man of great stature, what a man of great morality, what a man of integrity, to come into this house and tell us that all these things are somehow political virtues. And when he tells us about the Batman preselection, `It is not about fairness; it is about outcomes.'

That is the way Senator Evans has behaved in this matter. He is not concerned about fairness to the royal commissioner. He is not concerned about fairness to Ann Vanstone QC. He is about trying to keep Carmen Lawrence alive politically.

You ought to realise, Senator Evans, that you do not build Carmen Lawrence up by trying to chop the royal commissioner and counsel assisting off at the knees. You do not build up Dr Lawrence in that way. You ought to be concerned about fairness. Dr Lawrence will stand or fall on her own evidence, on the outcome of the royal commission and on the judgment of the people of Australia. But you do not make her task any easier by attacking the royal commissioner and the counsel assisting. Senator McKiernan, who I note is sitting opposite in the chamber, suggested that Dr Lawrence ought to go before a royal commission and ought to be giving evidence and things of that nature. But, as I have said, that is not the issue in this debate.

Senator Ray, in his contribution today, was unusually quiet and lacking in substance. He was unable to deal with the basis of the motion. The only time he got near it was when he tried to make an attack on me relating to questions during Senate estimates. I thought he was wrong at the time and I said so by way of an interjection. The Hansard of 21 June 1994 will disclose that. He mentioned a person's name in this house, a person whose name I never mentioned at all during the questions at Senate estimates. My question at those hearings was:

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to ask whether any members of the executive staff of TUTA are related to ACTU executive members?

There was a lot of toing-and-froing about it. It is interesting to see Senator Ray's response, which is disclosed a page over. I set a trap and Senator Ray foolishly walked into it. I then went on to say:
I will not pursue that line, Mr Chairman.
It is interesting that the Prime Minister did not undertake that same attitude to Niki Savva.

Niki Savva is a journalist in the press gallery here whom he had attacked only a few days before because she is married to a member of the Liberal Party federal secretariat. I was making no attack. I set him up beautifully. Like a fool, he walked into it. I then exposed him for his Prime Minister's actions in relation to Niki Savva, a member of the press gallery whom the Prime Minister sought to denigrate because of her matrimonial relationship.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to the motion. We in the Senate ought to be censuring the leader for his cowardly and unfounded attack upon the integrity and reputation of Royal Commissioner Marks and counsel assisting, Ms Ann Vanstone. There has been nothing submitted in this debate in any shape or form by the government to substantiate its cowardly and unfounded attacks. For that reason, this motion ought to be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Needless to say, I oppose this censure motion that has been moved by Senator Hill on behalf of a very desperate opposition. What I think the Senate probably understands, and what I think anyone listening to this debate needs to understand, is that we have in this royal commission nothing more or less than the most tawdry of political exercises. It is low-life politics from the Liberal Party of Western Australia. This is from the same people who have such an appalling record in relation to the management of their own affairs.

PARA.TAB: Really, the political exercise has reached new depths in this chamber today with this censure motion on the Leader of the Government in the Senate. This is without doubt the most hypocritical motion that has ever been moved in this chamber, and that is saying something. This has been moved by the party who have in their midst the masters and mistresses of sleaze, the masters and mistresses of slime, the masters and mistresses of smear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order: there is a reference to members of our political party. It is a reference to us and it ought be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Senator Faulkner, you would be interested to know we have a ruling on comments Senator Evans made yesterday. On that, I am again advised that it is unparliamentary if it is a direct reference to senators or a group of senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw `sleaze' and `slime' and I am delighted that I can bat on with `smear'. How can this group of people who so abuse the processes of the Senate, who so abuse the political process in this country, who so misuse this chamber, actually propose a censure motion?

—On a point of order: it is contrary to standing orders to accuse a senator or honourable senators of having an improper motive in the exercise of their functions as a senator. That is exactly what Senator Faulkner has done. He has accused people of abusing their powers as senators. That comment is quite clearly unparliamentary and should be withdrawn. It is an imputation of improper motive.

—That is making it very hard for me, Senator O'Chee. I will go directly to the Clerk on that. I think we all concede that the point of order is in a grey area. There definitely is not anything unparliamentary there. But, as you are bordering on being unparliamentary, I bring it to your attention, Senator Faulkner.

—I am pleased I am only bordering on being unparliamentary. The point I am making is that it is utterly preposterous for this sort of criticism to be levelled at Senator Evans from a group of senators who so use or misuse the forms of this chamber. I think it is reasonable for the hypocrisy of this motion to be laid bare.

PARA.TAB: The Senate has become more and more a chamber for slandering people in this community, for defaming anyone the opposition has a disagreement with, for maligning the reputation of people who do not deserve to have their reputations maligned. This opposition, which complains today about the actions of Senator Evans yesterday, is the same opposition that is willing to go on this political witch hunt that we have in Western Australia. This is the same opposition that will stop at nothing to try to end the political life and public life of Carmen Lawrence. It is hypocrisy. It is the worst instance I have ever seen of the pot calling the kettle black to move this motion of censure on Senator Evans.

This royal commission was established as an act of desperation from the Western Australian Liberal Party. I am pleased to see the cracks that are appearing in the Western Australian government today. We read today that Mr Cowan, the Leader of the Western Australian National Party, appeared before the Marks Royal Commission today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deputy Premier.

—He is also the Deputy Premier. I hope the National Party will give this consideration when they cast their vote on this particular motion, Senator O'Chee. Asked by Michael Barker, counsel for eight former state Labor government ministers, whether he had any reservations about the commission being called, Mr Cowan said:

PARA.TAB: There was only one reservation but it was very, very important to me.

SPEECH.PARA: I go on:

PARA.TAB: I have not known of any royal commission where people who are brought before it ever come out of that with their reputation enhanced . . .

My comments to the premier were that as he would be a critical witness in respect to this royal commission, that it would not be something that would enhance the premier's reputation and for that matter, for any other member of parliament that appeared before it.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that Mr Cowan and the resources minister and, I think, Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, Mr Barnett, have both stated publicly their concerns about the calling of this royal commission. I suppose they are in a better position than virtually anyone else—that is, the Deputy Premier and the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party—to know how politically motivated this royal commission was, to know what the circumstances were that led Mr Court to call this royal commission. The reality is that it is an act of desperation from the Western Australian Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: We all know that the Western Australian Liberal Party has become a festering sore on the rotting carcass of the federal opposition. But it was an act of desperation for what is happening over there. It is interesting to see what has happened to the moderates in the Western Australian Liberal Party. Mr Rocher, who represents the seat of Curtin, was bowled out in a factional brawl. Mr Filing, who represents the seat of Moore, was bowled out in a factional brawl. Both of those members are going to run as independents in the next federal election. We have the situation concerning Dr Brian Hilbert. I believe that he was the Liberal Party candidate for the seat of Swan at the last election. What happened to him? He lost pre-selection and he is running as an independent in the seat of Swan.

We have had the very unseemly circumstances and activities surrounding the role of the Australian Federal Police in Western Australia and their investigations into the affairs of certain Liberal Party members of parliament. Of course, we have had the situation surrounding the future of Senator Crichton-Browne, a member of this chamber.

I am convinced that this particular censure motion is probably a very sophisticated device on the part of the Liberal Party to try and ensure yet again that Senator Crichton-Brown does not have the opportunity to jump to his feet and ask the question that we all know he has been wanting to ask for the last fortnight: what are you going to do tomorrow? What device or ruse are you going to develop tomorrow to stop Senator Crichton-Browne getting to his feet and asking the question? We are all very interested. All the ministers on this side of the chamber stand ready, willing and able to answer that question if it is directed to any one of us. We are looking forward to having that opportunity.

This is what is happening here. This is a base political exercise from the Western Australian division of the Liberal Party. These are the people who have no problem in dragging the reputations of others through the murk and the mire and the mud. We have some people on the other side of the chamber who have become past masters at that very exercise. For those opposite to come in here and condemn Senator Evans is the most extraordinary leap of logic possible for any member of parliament. You are experts at traducing peoples reputations. You are experts at maligning people. You are absolute experts at abusing the processes of this chamber.

I want to say this. The reason why we have had this censure motion today is because Senator Evans, in question time yesterday, got up and destroyed the opposition. He won question time hands down, and you know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten zip.
—Ten zip, as Senator Collins has said.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you wanted to give him the opportunity to do exactly the same to you again. You know that is the situation. For you people, who behave in such a despicable, unprincipled and contemptible way, to come in here and condemn Senator Evans for his activities in question time is a most extraordinary hypocrisy and it ought to be exposed as such.

PARA.TAB: I think your motivations are well known to Australians. I think, unfortunately, it is all catching up with you. I have to say that I think Australians have a real sense of justice. Australians know that this royal commission is not justice the Australian way. They really are, I think, growing in impatience and anger at what you are doing. You are being exposed, and you deserve to be exposed.

The government will be continuing to take these issues on in the same manner. When I was asked by the press this morning I said, `We are not going to be a punching bag for the outrageous and contemptible actions of a group of people driven by the basest of political motives on the part of the Western Australian Liberal Party.' We are not going to take that sort of attack without exposing their motives and outlining the truth of the situation to the Australian people.

We are not going to be punching bags, and you are going to find that the more publicity there is, the more you are exposed, the greater the damage that will be done, but it will be done to your party and particularly the Western Australian Liberal Party and the premier, Mr Court. You stand condemned for what you have said. You stand condemned for moving this motion in relation to Senator Evans.

Look at the record in this chamber over a long period of time. Anybody who has any knowledge of Australian politics would not come to any conclusion other than that this is a case of the pot calling the kettle black. It is unbelievable hypocrisy from those on the other side of this chamber who abuse and misuse parliamentary process and who abuse and misuse this senate chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with others who have said in this debate that the remarks made by Senator Evans during question time yesterday were out of character for him. I think that is true. I do not know whose strategic decision it was to pursue such a tactic, but I think it was a misjudgment. In saying that it was a misjudgment, I think that the use of the word `cowardly' in the motion does not reflect accurately. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "cowardly and".

As a matter of fact, I think it was probably outrageously audacious and a mistake—or foolish. Senator Evans does, however, raise questions about some aspects of the royal commission about which the Australian Democrats are also uncomfortable; namely, the unprecedented nature of this royal commission and the nature of the terms of reference of this royal commission. But these were decisions taken by the Court government, not the commission itself.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans is right also, in the Democrats' view, in saying that impartiality should be seen to be present in these types of proceedings. But he is absolutely wrong to suggest that in this particular instance the proceedings cannot be impartial because counsel assisting happens to be the sister-in-law of the shadow Attorney-General. Perish the thought that my brothers-in-law should have to be responsible for anything that I have done.

It is for Ms Ann Vanstone herself whether she should make a decision to disqualify herself. In the Democrats' view there is no evidence that she is not impartial. If she does not chose to disqualify herself we are not therefore entitled to assume that she is incapable of professional impartiality. The mere fact of a relationship by marriage is not enough.

Senator Evans has said too that there are issues of principle involved. The Democrats think that the principle is: at what point do family relationships, particularly those which arise in an extended family way by virtue of marriage, render a person incapable of being professionally impartial?
