We feel strongly that it is inappropriate and unfair to automatically assume that the existence of a family relationship will impair impartiality.

But in all of this squalid mess you can always see a longer term policy question, I think, and this time I think it is that the political tactics and comments surrounding this royal commission run the risk of undermining the very serious role that royal commissions have historically played in the checks and balances of our democratic system. Governments which choose to set up royal commissions have a duty to consider this. In the pursuit of a political tactic, Senator Evans went too far this time.

With the word `cowardly' deleted, the Democrats will support this censure motion, but we do not support the role of Mr Court and the Western Australian government in establishing this royal commission in the specific way he has done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have seen today is the most extraordinary behaviour by Senator Evans, because Senator Evans concluded his speech to this Senate by saying that he made no apology for anything that he said yesterday. That is what this censure motion revolves around; it revolves around Senator Evans's conduct in question time yesterday; it revolves around whether his remarks were a proper comment to be made and also whether Senator Evans's conduct was befitting an officer of the Crown, a person holding high office, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. That is what this motion is all about.

PARA.TAB: It is not about Carmen Lawrence. I could talk about cricket teams against her, but it is not about that, so let us leave that out of it. It is not about Carmen Lawrence; it is not about Richard Court; and it is not about Carmen Lawrence exercising her rights to challenge the inquiry with $10,000 of our taxpayers' money. That is irrelevant, too. All the things we have heard from the government side in defence of Senator Evans are irrelevant as well, because the defence we have heard from the government's side today is what I call the bus driver defence; that is, you pile everybody into a Brisbane City Council Brookfield bus and you drive them around and around in circles and you never get to a conclusion. Senator Evans would probably be pretty pleased with that because, if we got to the conclusion, Senator Evans would be in grave difficulty because the fact is that Senator Evans has refused to apologise—not once, but twice—for his grotesquely based comments about Ann Vanstone QC in this Senate chamber yesterday.

Just so everybody knows how gross and base those comments were, I am going to remind Senator Evans. He started off by saying, `I do not want to be taken as undermining family values,' and then he was interrupted—not once, but 11 times—by the President, Senator Ian Macdonald, Senator Hill, Senator Knowles, Senator Bob Collins and Senator McMullan. Then he continued and said:
As I was saying, I do not want to be taken as undermining family values on the principle that the family that preys together—spelt `e-y-s'—stays together.

SPEECH.PARA: Then he went on to impugn the impartiality of the commissioner, Mr Marks QC, as well impugning the impartiality of counsel assisting, Ann Vanstone QC. This was a deliberate, premeditated attack on—not one, but two—highly reputable Queen's Counsel. I stress—not one, but two of them.

PARA.TAB: It was a deliberate attack, but we gave him the benefit of the doubt. We said, `Maybe Senator Evans was full of passion, in the flow of anger or whatever it might be. We will start question time today by giving Senator Evans the opportunity to apologise.' Senator Evans not only failed to apologise; Senator Evans embarked on another disreputable attack on Ann Vanstone and a disreputable attack on members of the opposition as well.

It is worthy of note that this attack—an attack which alleges collusion; an attack which borders on alleging a conspiracy to corrupt a royal commission—must also be an attack upon Senator Vanstone. Whether one agrees with Senator Vanstone's politics or not, Senator Vanstone's actions, her undoubted integrity, speak louder than any words that Senator Evans can throw at her.

Nobody in this place can accuse Senator Vanstone of anything less than the highest standing of political integrity because last year, given the opportunity to gravely embarrass the government by being presented leaked material, she instead took the task of exposing the flaw in the government's security and returning the documents to the government without ever disclosing to anybody what those documents were. That is the integrity of Senator Vanstone and that too has been impugned by Senator Evans.

So we see that what Senator Evans has been involved in is a most disreputable, a most grotesque and a base attack on the good reputation of three people. And he failed to withdraw those allegations. But it is worse than that, because in his defence, Senator Evans said, `I want to put on the record what I said yesterday,' and then proceeded to quote very selectively from the Senate Hansard. He spoke about how he had said that maybe it was just a matter of coincidence that counsel assisting the royal commission was the sister-in-law of the shadow Attorney-General.

Then he went on to say that he had said yesterday that it was not just that propriety occur but that propriety be seen to occur. This is the grave sin that he committed today. He said to the Senate, `And I said nothing stronger than that'. Of course, he said something stronger than that. He accused Senator Vanstone and Ann Vanstone QC of conspiratorially preying on people. That is what he did. So he has misled the Senate as well. In his desperate effort to defend himself he has misled the Senate.

Senator Evans had the opportunity to withdraw. He did not withdraw. Senator Evans had the opportunity to put the record straight in a full, frank and honest way, and Senator Evans has failed to do that. That is not the standard of conduct that is befitting the Leader of the Government in the Senate and that is why Senator Evans should be censured by this place.

But it is more than that, because Senator Evans was defended by his mates, who said, `We're proud of what he did. We're proud of the way he is defaming people.' Senator Cook got up and said that he was proud of what Senator Evans did. Well, I am ashamed of what Senator Evans did, even though I sit on the other side of the chamber. If we are going to start defaming people or slurring their integrity because of their family relationships, then heaven help the good governance of this country.

Are we going to slur Mr Justice McHugh? I hope not. Are we going to slur Justice Elizabeth Evatt on the basis that her father was a Labor minister and her uncle was leader of the Labor Party federally? I hope not. Are we going to slur Mr Gary Crooke? I hope not. So what are we going to do? Are we going to allow this particular matter to go unpunished—one of the gravest slurs that I have heard in this chamber? It is not just a slur against a member of the opposition—we are used to that from the Labor Party; this was a slur against two eminent Queen's Counsel and a member of this Senate whose integrity has never before been impugned.

The gravity of the attack that we heard from Senator Evans is truly despicable. The suggestion that either Ann Vanstone QC or Mr Marks QC is manipulating a royal commission is thoroughly despicable and made without any basis at all in fact, based only in Senator Evans's prejudice and dripping vitriol. We are being asked by the other side not only to endure that but also to vote with the other side and condone it. What Senator Evans did can never be condoned in this chamber. It is about time that the integrity of the Australian Senate was maintained by censuring Senator Evans.

I will conclude by highlighting some of the comments that were made by Senator Faulkner who said that he was disappointed that the Senate was being used to malign the reputations of people who did not deserve to be maligned. I agree with Senator Faulkner in that. The Senate was used yesterday by Senator Evans in a premeditated and despicable fashion to undermine the integrity of three very fine Australians who certainly did not deserve to be maligned. I believe that, if Senator Faulkner had the courage of his convictions, he would vote with the opposition in support of the censure motion and vote to ensure that Senator Evans is brought to book for his disreputable conduct in question time yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to correct a misrepresentation of me today by Senator Ray.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In this debate Senator Ray falsely alleged that I had attacked someone in this parliament on the basis of their being married. In correcting this false allegation, I refer to page 1836 of Hansard of 21 March 1995 in which I criticised as totally incorrect the false claim by Senator Neal that Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd, the New South Wales Labor Party's multi-million dollar loss black hole, did not have to provide key financial data information in its annual return to the Australian Securities Commission because its accounts are audited when they had not been audited—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order. Sorry, we were under the impression that it had something to do with the debate. But the debate has not finished, so this is not an appropriate time right in the middle of the debate, I would have thought.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—There was no objection given when Senator Baume asked for leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there was.
—I am happy to do it at the end of the debate. I was told I should do it at the first opportunity. It has to do with this debate.
—If you are willing to make a personal explanation at the end of the debate before the vote, we will call you then.

—I apologise if we did not understand, Senator Baume, that you were giving a personal explanation in relation to the debate. When you began to speak, we thought it was on an earlier matter. I think it is appropriate just to wind up the arguments in relation to this particular debate, which is the censure of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, for his cowardly and unfounded attack upon the integrity and reputations of Royal Commissioner Marks and counsel assisting, Ms Ann Vanstone QC.

PARA.TAB: I will just foreshadow that the Greens will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Kernot to delete the words `cowardly and' and will retain our support for the censure motion. The basis for doing that—it is a very serious matter in the midst of a whole series of rather untasteful slanging matches within question time of the last few weeks—is that, it is important that when a royal commission is set up and when somebody who is involved in that is working, they should not be impugned because of a relationship they might have with somebody who has the misfortune of being on the political scene and working here.

I might add, and this is one of the concerns that Senator Margetts and I had, that we did feel there was a measure of legitimacy to the comment raised by Senator Evans yesterday, which was to defend the perception of fairness and openness and to step aside from any conflict of interest matter. To that degree he could have gained our support. However, the way and the manner in which he did that was absolutely outrageous. We may well be used to these kinds of attacks going across the chamber to one another. I believe it was an attack on Senator Vanstone rather than on her sister-in-law or on the royal commission, but it certainly became an attack on them. I believe that is not something that we should support.

We have often said that accusations always reveal much more about the accusers than anyone else. I just wonder whether the imputation we might make from the accusation that Senator Evans made was that, if a family member of the ALP were involved in something like that, it would be impossible for them not to communicate information with each other. I was pleased to see several members of the front bench repudiate that when they said that it would be utterly inappropriate if that should happen. I think because that is so, they should not make those accusations themselves.

Another comment that was made was a repeated kind of running down of the royal commission. I have often said that I do not necessarily agree with the setting up of the royal commission. However, there is no question that there was a legal basis for it being set up. The reason for the delay, which was raised many times as though there were some kind of Liberal Party plot that it had taken three years for the commission to be set up, does need some reminding about.

I wonder whether the government has forgotten that, if the royal commission could have been called when the now Premier, Richard Court, were the Leader of the Opposition, it may well have been done except that it was not possible at that time. Maybe when Mr Court became Premier he could have set it up at that time; he would have if he had been able to have any evidence. Actually, it was two former cabinet ministers who provided the evidence, and that was the timing that was involved.

I am not saying that as a way of justifying it; I am just pointing out that there are lots of accusations flying around that are not appropriate. I do not want to put any more remarks on the table but simply to say that it is with regret that we support this censure motion. We do feel it is appropriate. It is a good reminder that the level of this debate needs to be more focused on proper conduct within the parliament and needs to refrain from taking advantage of our parliamentary privilege by slinging accusations at other places like royal commissions and courts of law. For that reason, we will be supporting the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generally speaking, of course, I come here for question time. I did not do so today because I was feeling unwell and was lying on the couch with the flu and a splitting headache. However, I have listened to almost every word of this debate. I do not know whether I am any the worse for wear than I was previously, but I do feel that, on balance, I am going to take the attitude that was expressed by Senator Kernot. I will be supporting the amendment that she has moved and then voting for the motion as amended. I hope Senator Evans will understand my not going into the reasons for that.
—More in sorrow than in anger.

—It is, as a matter of fact. As you know, I have been here for a long time and I really could not believe it when you said that yesterday. Nevertheless, I have made my position clear and I am sure that you will appreciate it if I sat down now.
—The word `coward' was inserted because it was our view that it was said under the protection of parliament.
—But it has been done elsewhere.

—I have been told that subsequent to the commencement of this debate. That is why we used the very descriptive word `coward', because I thought it had been done here under protection and that was cowardly. But the minister has owned up and said that he has gone outside and said it. I therefore logically accept the amendment of the minority parties.
—I'm not called a minority party. I have a name.

—The Australian Democrats, the Greens WA, and Senator Harradine as an Independent have joined together and have sought that that word be deleted. I accept that also. I am pleased that the Senate is sending a message to Senator Evans today. I would like to think that he would heed it. I suspect that is probably asking for too much, and it would probably be a bit gratuitous of me to remind him that he does have responsibilities in this institution in the high office that he holds, and he might think about those before he attacks individuals in the way he did yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Kernot's) agreed to.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's), as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation. During his interjections across the chamber after I completed my speech, and certainly during Senator Cook's remarks, Senator Evans sought to make much of the fact that I take up the opportunity offered to me—that is the politest way I can put it—by him to set the record straight in this chamber. I am very willing to do that. I am only sorry that I did not do it at the time. I had prepared what I wanted to say. I stuck with that script and had no intention of varying it.

PARA.TAB: Lest anybody should have the idea that I have had any conversations with my sister-in-law that could possibly, by the longest bow and the widest stretch of the imagination, be construed as conversations going to substantive matters in some way to influence the commission, influence her or ascertain an order of witnesses, I am happy for someone to produce a list, tick the items off and say no to every one of them. It simply has not happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented.
—Not by your tie, you haven't been.

—I acknowledge the comment on the tie. I am not quite certain which one is Paul. In the debate that has just concluded, Senator Ray falsely accused me of attacking people in this parliament on the basis of who they were married to.

PARA.TAB: In correcting this false allegation, I refer to page 1836 of the Hansard of 21 March 1995 in which I criticised as totally incorrect the false claim by Senator Neal that Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd, the New South Wales Labor Party's multi-million dollar loss operation, did not have to provide key financial data information in its annual return to the Australian Securities Commission because its accounts were audited when they had not been audited. I then pointed out what Senator Neal failed to reveal, which is that she was providing false information about a company of which her husband was a director and who signed the company's return. I criticised her for her actions of misleading the Senate on behalf of her husband, not because she is married to Mr Della Bosca. It was not whom she was related to; it was what she did on her husband's behalf that caused me to criticise her.

On another occasion, I criticised Mr McLeay MP for failing to put in his declaration of interests to the parliament the required information related to shareholdings by his wife in a company run by a mate of his. He was criticised for not meeting the requirements of the parliament, not for being married to his wife. Senator Ray's accusations against me are false.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that all questions today be placed on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion that questions may be put to Ministers until 28 questions, including supplementary questions, have been asked and answered.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of aspects of today's debate which many of us would rather not be associated with the Senate. Many people in the community cringe when they see the House of Representatives acting in ways that we would like to say the Senate usually does not act.

PARA.TAB: The important thing people want to know is that we are all doing our job, that we are asking questions, that the government is being kept accountable as far as possible and that the real work of the Senate—that is, in scrutinising legislation, in dealing with the way that moneys are expended and in making sure that the process is improved in any way possible—takes place. Therefore, it is extremely important that the small daily opportunities that exist for the real work of the Senate to take place continue to happen. We are using this opportunity today to move to suspend standing orders so that the work of the Senate can continue, that scrutiny and accountability can continue today and that the public basically will see, for some of today, what we believe we are really here for, which is to do the work of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Needless to say, the government will be opposing this suspension of standing orders. We faced a rather unusual situation in the Senate this afternoon when, just shortly after 2 o'clock, Senator Hill proposed a censure motion. It has taken three hours to complete that debate this afternoon. Senator Hill, even in moving this censure motion, did note how unusual it was to move this at the commencement of question time. This is what was said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely unusual action for us to take. It is some years since we interrupted question time, which I guess demonstrates how important we regard this matter to be.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans—It replaces question time—you understand that?

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the government will not support the suspension of standing orders to have question time now. The opposition does have a right to move a censure motion or propose the suspension of standing orders at any time. That was a right that Senator Hill exercised at the commencement of question time today. He did so knowing full well that question time would not be held.

PARA.TAB: Everyone is aware that a censure motion of a minister or the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) would normally take longer to debate than just the hour of question time. It is frankly preposterous for Senator Margetts to suggest that government ministers come into the chamber at 5.15 p.m. on a Wednesday afternoon and not even have an hour's question time but answer a stipulated number of questions. She has said, `We will not only change the procedure about when we will have question time but also change all the procedures. I can see that I have convinced Senator Hill with the strength of the arguments I have presented. I have indicated that the government will be opposing the suspension.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to support the government position, but, after listening to Senator Faulkner, I am tempted to change my mind.
—Be tempted, Robert.
—How are the numbers looking at the other end? We are very conscious—

—I will listen to the rest of the argument.

Indeed, when the motion was handed around it was clearly scribbled at very short notice and we were about 15 minutes into the debate before we even got a copy of the motion. I take it from what I see on my left that the Greens were not consulted either, nor was Senator Harradine. PARA.TAB: The opposition has been doing their darnedest to cut us down to one question a day. Now they have taken question time away all together. I put it to them that it is only fair that they reconsider their position if they are minded to agree with the government on this and at least give us question time now.

I fully support the argument that Senator Margetts has used in supporting her motion for the suspension of standing orders. When you get one side accusing the other of some misdemeanour and, in defence, the other side attacks saying, `Oh yes, but you did so and so' the organisation itself suffers and parliament is brought into disrepute.

Again, I appeal on those grounds to senators to support the suspension of standing orders and to let us have question time. That is, perhaps above any other part of the parliamentary proceedings, the part which demonstrates the proper democratic processes at work, where the opposition, the minor parties and the Independents can question government ministers as to their performance in relation to the management of all aspects of the governance of this country—the economy, social welfare, the environment and so on and so forth. TALK.START.PARA: —Blame them.

—We are partly blaming them. I accept the argument you put that they could well have asked their question, taken offence at the answer and then moved their suspension after question time. They chose not to do that. We have to deal with the situation as it is now, at 20 past five. Given that circumstance, I would appeal particularly to the opposition to support the motion for the suspension of standing orders to allow us to have question time and to get on with the questions. After all, the 28 questions with supplementaries is approximately what we have anyway. So do not take offence at that feature of the motion. Let us have question time. Let us redeem in the eyes of the public, the few who are in the gallery and those who are listening, the structure and functioning of the parliament.

—I rise to speak in support of the motion for the suspension of standing orders. I realise that the opposition in consideration of their priorities had every entitlement to do what they did today, that is, to seek the suspension of standing orders. I would have argued, as it has just been argued, that maybe that should have been done after question time. PARA.TAB: I appeal to the opposition to consider this proposal. When it comes to exercising our functions of audit of government actions, question time is very important to us and I am sure it is very important to the opposition. I have had my question this week. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind you that you are talking to the motion to suspend standing orders.

I happen to believe that that minister should be answerable to this parliament for certain actions that she has done or not done, irrespective of this matter. The opposition, by exercising its rights to put a censure motion at any time, when it chooses to do so at question time—and that is not in dispute; it is its right and neither is it in dispute that it is a serious matter—at the same time is denying the democratic rights of everyone else in this chamber, including the government and the ministers. PARA.TAB: We have effectively been deprived of our rights by the time allocated to this censure motion. Nobody from the Democrats, the Greens or the Independents was warned of this possibility. If this motion for the suspension of standing orders is supported—and I urge my opposition colleagues and the government to consider this—we would certainly be willing to go straight to the vote and put it. You may feel that 28 questions is inappropriate and that a lot of the material that is normally canvassed in question time has already been canvassed. That could well be argued. I urge that we do support this suspension if possible, not have the debate, go straight to the substantive motion and vote on it. We can have some questions that go to the points that those people who have been able to be part of this debate but not put their questions, and those who have not been able to be part of the previous debate, may want to put.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on Senator Margetts's proposal. She now seems to want to take the high moral ground on this issue after allowing a debate to occur—which was a censure of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans)—which she knew full well, as did all senators sitting at that end of the chamber, would be a politically motivated and politically charged debate. They come in here after voting with the opposition and participating in the debate, choosing to try to castigate us and the rest of the Senate by saying, `Look, it was a very poor performance,' knowing full well what has happened previously.

PARA.TAB: They then say, `Now we want question time.' Quite frankly, they really cannot have it both ways. In terms of high moral ground, I think they ought to consider their position a little bit. The same goes for the Democrats. I thought Senator Bell was going to ask some important questions today. He chose to deny himself the opportunity. I, too, urge senators, including Senator Hill and the opposition, to oppose this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have listened carefully to the debate and I hear merit on both sides. It seems to me that the Greens should be entitled to ask their questions. On the other hand, the government has sent its advisers home. I understand how difficult it is for ministers to respond without advisers, so I think that the best solution is a two-hour question time tomorrow—two hours or a minimum of 28 questions. I am pleased to announce that I cannot be here tomorrow.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Corporations and Securities Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities I present the report of the committee on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1995, schedule 4, items 1 to 4, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I advise the Senate that this matter arose out of the delay by the government in pursuing this bill through the Senate. I remind the Senate again that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) accused the opposition during the recent recess of delaying the bill and thereby penalising small companies.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this First Corporate Law Simplification Bill is to make it easier for small companies to be managed. It allows small private companies to operate with a single director and a single member and allows them to avoid having to put in financial reports and having an annual general meeting. These are laudable things and will make the process of running small business easier.

The government should have pushed this bill through the parliament months ago but deliberately chose, during the last session, to leave it until the second last day, when only a few minutes was allowed and, the last day, when again only a few minutes was allowed. As a consequence, the bill did not go through in the last session.

One consequence of the delay caused by the government was that small business brought to our attention some potential problems with the bill—that is, the definition of small and large companies: those which would get this benefit of not having to report and not having to put in financial statements, and those, the large ones, which would. As a consequence, the opposition moved an amendment—moved by Senator Vanstone and passed by the Senate—that this matter should go off to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, which has been done.

The committee held hearings this week—on Monday night and yesterday—and I am pleased to say that the report essentially looks at the options for this definition of which companies have to report and which companies are exempt. There were four options we looked at. The first was whether we should increase the threshold of the definition of what makes a company small or large. There are three criteria in the bill dealing with that, and for a company to be declared large it has to meet two out of the three criteria—that is, turnover of $10 million, assets of $5 million and the number of employees more than 50.

The second proposal was that the exemption power of the Australian Securities Commission under section 313 of the Corporations Law be examined whereby compliance could impose an unreasonable burden on the company, its officers or auditor. The ASC reported to us that the criteria needed further clarification if we were going to go down that route.

The third option put before us was to drop the need to have an audit altogether—a proposal which actually works for very small companies in the UK. The fourth option was that proposed by the accountants—that is, to retreat from the definition of `large-small', as set out in the bill, and go back to what the accountants call a reporting entity.

The committee ended up agreeing with option two as I have just outlined—in other words, that we should go with the route of the exemption power for the Australian Securities Commission as set out in the Corporations Law. We rejected the accountants' proposal from the previous report in March this year. On the basis of evidence we heard, the committee confirmed today that the right way to go was to retreat from the small-large criteria, as set out in the bill, and go back to a reporting entity.

However, it came to our attention that there are problems with some companies. For example, some motor traders may be called `large' because their assets go beyond $5 million, their turnover beyond $10 million and their number of employees often beyond 50, but they are not often regarded as very large companies and as such would be unfairly penalised if they were forced to pay audit fees as required by the bill.

As a consequence, the committee recommends that, in order to give guidance to the Australian Securities Commission, the bill be altered, by way of section 313 of the Corporations Law, to exempt a proprietary company, and there be set in there the criteria to guide the ASC—the expected cost of burden of audit, the expected public interest or benefit of making information available, the number of creditors, the nature and extent of the company's liabilities, whether in the first year the company is required to prepare audited accounts or whether the company is one which is likely to repeatedly be moving in and out of the large proprietary company category.

I remind the Senate that, if that is done, the ASC would follow its normal procedure, which is a public procedure, in seeking exemptions. The key points there are: to invite applications for relief, to publish guidelines in the business community about when relief may apply, to hold public consultations, to advise the Attorney-General, and to provide a review mechanism. The committee is in thorough agreement with this, and we think this is the only practical way of getting out of the problem that has been legitimately raised by business interests.

I might also add that the business interests that appeared before us last Monday night—the ACCI, the Victorian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Motor Traders Association—all supported the committee's previous decision to stick with the `small-large' definition of what is a large and what is a small company rather than going with the accountants' definition. That is basically why the committee has stuck with that.

We think the process that has been proposed by the committee must be taken up by the government. I wish to condemn the government for not taking up this matter before. The business groups which appeared before us last Monday night had put submissions to the government over a month ago. The government told them not to advise the opposition of what they were proposing and rejected their proposals out of hand. But the committee—chaired by the government and with a majority held by the government—in handing down this report today, has found that these people did have matters of substance to put before the parliament. As a consequence, the committee recommends that the bill be altered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on its hard work in trying to fix up some more government-flawed legislation. The volume of flawed legislation that comes before this place is evident from the volume of amendments, often forced at the last minute, to legislation which not only is badly thought out but also, in some instances, is bad in principle.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is not taking the dog in the manger approach of saying to the voters of Australia, `Look, you elected this lot. You deserve to get the consequences of the sort of grubby, incompetent legislation that this lot gives you.' That is one political opportunity that any opposition has. We take, however, a more responsible approach, which may well be to our disadvantage: we seek to fix up the mess that the government continually makes of legislation—as we are seeking to do in this particular case.

Unfortunately, it means that the people of Australia are continually protected from the consequences of pretty rubbishy, incompetent legislation which often has enormous volumes of unintended consequences which work to the massive disadvantage of Australians. In this case, as a result of coalition pressure, there was a recognition by the Senate that this matter had to be re-examined. There had been lengthy examination. There is no doubt about that. But despite that lengthy examination, there were clear flaws in the way this legislation would operate.

I must say that I am very glad indeed that following this latest committee hearing—and I commend Senator Gibson for his role in that—we do have a situation where, I believe, there is now an opportunity for some of the unintended consequences to be avoided, particularly by providing the ASC with guidelines on the manner in which they should examine whether or not a company is a large or small company for the purposes of detailed reporting.

I say, initially, that I commend the proposal that small proprietary companies should no longer have to go through the enormous burden of reporting which has been imposed upon them for many years, even though I am a strong believer in the principle that, if you give someone the benefits of limited liability, there are offsetting massive obligations to the community, which has given you that right, to avoid the risks of financial loss if your company goes broke. There are far too many Australians who have been robbed of their assets—some of their livelihoods, some of their businesses and many of their savings—by people who have hidden behind the corporate veil to rip them off.

So, while I believe it is absolutely vital to have an effective system of regulation, as this report tabled today says in passing, one must recognise that there should be some assessment of the benefits of the regulatory requirements as against the costs of regulation.

There is no doubt that under this government the costs of compliance with a mountain of legislation have got totally out of hand. It is just ridiculous to have these huge costs of compliance with ever-mounting laws. The 1,130-odd pages of the taxation act have blossomed under this government to 3,360-odd, thus massively increasing the costs of compliance. The same goes for the sales tax legislation, the fringe benefits tax, you name it. And, of course, on top of that the Commissioner of Taxation keeps putting out statements massively amending the law without reference to parliament, requiring a whole lot of additional compliance costs.

But I do have some problems with some elements of the recommended changes here. Apart from anything else, if you are to have the criteria that establishes whether or not you have to report in detail—and if you are a big proprietary company now you have to report in great detail, you have to have an audited set of accounts which have to be filed with the Australian Securities Commission—whether you are a big or small company, you have to be aware of the `value' of your assets, the size of your company in employment and the volume of turnover.

My concerns about policing this are that I do not know how the ASC plans to ensure that people who do meet that criteria in fact report, because so far the ASC has done very little indeed to ensure that its database on proprietary companies is accurate. I will want to see a commitment from the Securities Commission to recognise that these changes bring a burden of responsibility for it to require people in this situation to meet their requirements. That might well mean that the Securities Commission should adopt the same sort of spot audit approach that the tax commissioner does in the matter of self-assessment.

I have raised this matter repeatedly with the Securities Commission and under the old system of exempt proprietary companies it had no interest or desire to do down that track whatsoever. My own view is that the commission had better go down it now because it has been relieved of a massive burden of supervision with all small companies now exempted from those requirements. So it means that the Securities Commission can address itself to the question of whether those who should report are reporting accurately and properly. The ASC has a legal obligation to ensure that its database is accurate, and for years the ASC has been unable to meet that obligation to meet that requirement. This legislation gives it the opportunity to do so.

But I also have some concerns about the three hurdles that someone has to get over before being regarded as a small company and therefore exempted. I notice that such a company's assets are to be taken into account—$5 million in assets. Quite frankly, I think the report is wrong in this matter regarding assets as the test rather than liabilities. As Mr Govey from the Attorney-General's Department admits in the Senate Hansard of this committee meeting on Tuesday 29 August:

SPEECH.PARA: Sure, you will get some companies which quite deliberately understate their assets or turnover in order to avoid being classified as large. That is the usual enforcement problem which I guess any regulator has.
But at the end of the day it will be relatively clear on which side of the line they fall when they are looked at.

Frankly, I do not think it is sensible to have a test that can be so easily avoided. I know the legislation does say, `What is the test of an asset?' and it should be by the accounting standards. But the fact is that liabilities are the clear and much more relevant matter that should be taken into account—not just liabilities but external liabilities.

PARA.TAB: The discussion before the committee on this point seemed inadequate because the people involved, it seemed to me, from the task force were not focusing on the reality of external liabilities; in other words, liabilities owed to people outside the company structure. They simply dismissed the concept because they said, `Ah, but a lot of the liabilities are internal.' Of course they are, but this provides a much more realistic hurdle and would remove the problems, I believe, of many companies that should not be regarded as large for these purposes.

The proposal to allow a `grandfathering' of this matter so that people who have their accounts audited but do not file them with the ASC should be allowed to get away with it for a couple of years, I think, is disgraceful. It gives them a competitive advantage over those new companies entering the field. They will be forced to reveal their full audited accounts as against those existing ones which do not have to. That seems totally unprincipled. I regret that the committee has come to that decision, while recognising that for many companies it would be inconvenient. But, Mr Govey says that the reasons for doing this are, essentially, simply pragmatic. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I would also like to address my remarks to the motion that the Senate take note of the committee's report. As stated by Senator Gibson and Senator Baume, a particular matter within the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill was referred back to the committee by the Senate. Otherwise, all matters within this bill are agreed upon by the committee. But there was that contentious matter of the small-large test.

PARA.TAB: I have made a dissenting report for the second time in our deliberations on the small-large test. I dissented from the committee's view when it first handed down its report. When the Senate referred this matter back to the committee, I again dissented from the main committee report. While it was a difficult matter for the committee to decide on the options on reporting, nevertheless, it was not a unanimous decision in the final analysis. I preferred the reporting entity test against the small-large test.

Substantially and briefly, my reasons were, firstly, that the reporting entity test is an accepted accounting standard. A very compelling submission was put to the committee by the two largest accounting bodies, which should know more about this matter than anyone else—the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of Accountants. Two powerful and representative bodies supported the reporting entity test.

The second reason, and probably the main reason, is that the small-large test will affect business and the integrity of the legislation because it is open to rorting and avoidance on a grand scale. Asset valuation, which is one of the tests, is open to rorting. No-one is quite sure how those assets are going to be valued. The legislation does not mention whether it will be taken on directors' valuations, historical costs, a particular depreciation regime and so on. So the assets test is open to avoidance.

Of course, it is a disincentive to employ. As we know, one of the criteria is 50 employees. There is no mention in the legislation of whether those employees are full-time, part-time, on or off, or whether that is just a benchmark on 30 June. Of course, that is a disincentive. Prior to 30 June if you wish to drop below that benchmark of 50 you will put an employee off. You may decide not to employ that extra person, that 50th employee, because there will be a cost not only in respect of that employee but also with auditing.

We were told at the committee hearings about the proliferation of trust companies that would be set up to avoid this test. Those that now fall into the large category will be burdened with extra auditing costs. That is why I agreed with the very compelling submissions from the accounting bodies that a far better test would be the reporting entity test.

I know that this is a very complex matter and one that many would find hard to follow. However, there is a very basic point at issue here—that is, that many small businesses are now going to have to pay extra auditing fees. This does not simplify the legislation, as it was hoped in the bill; it is an extra cost and a complication. It is just like the tax act. This legislation will result in added costs and complications for businesses that can least afford them.

You would have thought that the business representatives would have noted this and gone in far stronger at the second hearing of the committee. They could have represented small business far more vigorously than they did. Anyone at those committee meetings would have realised that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry representatives were at best, to put it kindly, very equivocal and at worst betrayed small business. The fact that the Senate deferred this matter as a result of the submissions of several business groups gave the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry a chance to have the large-small test abolished and have it replaced with a far cheaper and less complicated measure.

In its submission, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry pointed out that the new audit fees would impose on many thousands of businesses a cost of between $25,000 and $40,000, particularly for family businesses. It knows that that is an enormous extra burden. If the ACCI knows that this is going to result in an extra cost for its constituency, why is it that it came before the committee and supported the small-large test?

I am not sure whether this group knows who they represent. Maybe they have had too many long lunches as lobbyists in Canberra. Maybe they have not gone out and consulted their constituents. I would say that it is more likely that they are not sure whether they represent small business or large business. They seem to be torn between the two. This legislation is not going to affect large business. If you are one of the thousands of small businesses or family companies in this country, you have been poorly represented by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

They tried to play a double game before the committee. They have betrayed small business. The small business members of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry really have to question their membership in this organisation and they have to do that very soon because their membership fees are not cheap. They have to support a very large complex down the road and support the many lobbyists who have very lucrative salaries and have very good lunches. This is done using the membership fees of small business members.

There is absolutely no doubt that they have become technocrats and bound by the Canberra lobbyists' philosophy. They got totally sucked in by the government leading up to this committee meeting. It was the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and representatives from his office who went to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and said, `Don't complain about the bill. Don't go to the opposition. Don't talk to the opposition because we will adjust it to your particular liking.'

By the time the legislation hit the Senate the government had dumped them. Why would they not? This government has always dumped small business. It has often lied to the Australian public and it has done exactly the same to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. You would have thought that experienced lobbyists would have realised that, but they got hooked and then came running to those of us on this side of house at the very last minute so we could try to get them out of the fat.

Someone got to them again. Maybe it was the government. By the time they rolled up to the committee hearing they had changed their views again. If anyone sees their submission, and they will, and if anyone sees the Hansard of the evidence before the committee, and they will, they will know that those representatives were equivocal, weak and unrepresentative of the facts.

They cannot go around pretending that they represent small business when they concede that there is a new expense for small business because of this new regime. No thanks to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, small business is going to be subjected to an almighty extra audit fee in coming years. I think they ought to have a close look at who represents them. Maybe they should start looking at COSBOA, which seems to me to be a far better representative body.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted earlier in the debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 [No.2], I had just concluded reading into Hansard a letter that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald, which described the finer points of that wonderful town of Port Hedland in the north west of my state. I want to stay with the Port Hedland theme for a moment. I draw the Senate's attention to a media release from the mayor of Port Hedland, Councillor Alan Eggleston. He put out this press statement to express the Port Hedland council's dismay at remarks that Mr Justice Michael Kirby made about Port Hedland and about the immigration reception and detention centre in that town.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Port Hedland council for jumping to its own defence on this matter so quickly. The comments that Mr Justice Kirby made were not particularly good. I will not read the whole press statement into the record but if anyone wants a copy of it they can either get a copy from me or get a copy directly from the council in Port Hedland. I draw the Senate's attention to the last two paragraphs of the press statement which state:

SPEECH.PARA: Port Hedland has probably the most multicultural population in Western Australia with at least 62 different nationalities in the Town and the economy of the Pilbara is linked to the Asian nations of our North.

It would probably broaden Mr Kirby's outlook were he to visit the Pilbara and help him understand that there is more of Australia and Australian society than the narrow legal world of Sydney in which Mr Kirby moves.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will make a good senator one day, that bloke.
—I believe he is No. 3 on the Liberal Party Senate ticket for the next election.
—Who's this?

—Dr Alan Eggleston, the mayor of Port Hedland. He is a doctor in the town. I believe he knows what he is talking about in regard to this matter. There is another doctor in the town who has also had some publicity. He has made some comments about the remarks that Mr Justice Nicholson, the Chief Justice of the Family Court, made about the detention centre at Port Hedland.

PARA.TAB: The unfortunate thing about Mr Justice Nicholson and Mr Justice Kirby is that they both went on the public record and talked about things they do not know about. I think it is inexcusable for people of their standing and status in our society to come out and make those comments in the way that they have in recent times. The Port Hedland council has invited Mr Justice Kirby to visit the town. I wholeheartedly endorse that invitation. I hope that he does visit the town and takes the time to visit the detention centre so that the next time he opens his mouth on this matter he will at least know what he is talking about.

I did not debate Justice Alastair Nicholson because I responded to the remarks he made at a conference in Melbourne last week. In a prepared press statement he bagged the conditions at the Port Hedland detention centre which neither he nor probably any of his judges has ever visited. Yet he is prepared to go on the record to castigate and make untrue inferences about the conditions in the detention centre and also make remarks about the town of Port Hedland in talking about its remoteness.

For some people on the Sydney or Melbourne legal circuits, of course Port Hedland is remote; but for the 12,000 or so people who live, work, play and recreate in Port Hedland and the Pilbara region it is not remote. In their remarks, the two justices put a slur on Port Hedland, put a slur on Western Australia, and put a slur on rural Australia.

I hope they never make ignorant remarks of that nature again. If they do, I shall use the confines of this place to again take them to task. I will quickly make the remark that I am not using this place as a coward's castle; I am not saying anything in here now that I have not said on the public record before or, indeed, put out in the periodicals that I produce in my office and send to some thousands of people now on the issue of the boat people. I have done it already. I am not using this place as a coward's castle.

I repeat again that I am very pleased that the opposition has changed its stance on this bill, which will save the taxpayers of Australia potentially up to $100 million. It is not my figure, as I said before lunch; it is a figure that was produced by one of the leading advocates of illegals in this country who seeks to regularise their status—that is, Dr Mary Crock. By the changing stance in the opposition parties, this bill will be put through and the taxpayers' dollars will be protected.

I want to move on and talk about another element in the bill, and that is the government's action to stop repeat applications by people in detention who have failed to gain refugee status in order to gain protection in this country. They go through a series of court actions, come back, lodge a further application and go through the review process again. It is not before time that the government or the parliament is changing this to stop what I believe has been in some cases an abuse of the system. I did qualify my remarks by saying `in some cases'. There is the need, as is accommodated in the bill, for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to have an ability in certain circumstances to allow a person to make a repeat application for a protection visa in Australia. I know that there will be people in our society who will yet again criticise the government because of the contents of this bill. I will ask those people to legitimise themselves before they make any criticism. I want to explain my remarks by going through an experience I had last month when I visited Port Hedland and its detention centre.

We have heard of how people can be psychologically damaged in detention centres. I have no doubt that that may be the case in some instances. I witnessed one individual being psychologically damaged. It was not because of the actions of the minister or the department, and it had nothing to do with this parliament, but it was because of the actions of a migration agent who was purportedly representing one of the detainees in Port Hedland. Obviously I will not name names here now, but I would hope that those people, when they come out and criticise the government or criticise me, in turn will criticise this very prominent migration agent for their efforts on behalf of the individual.

The individual had been in detention for quite some time. He had previously had an application for protection refused, his appeal was refused and he then joined in a number of legal actions, both at the state level and through the Federal Court, which were all unsuccessful. He then started on the treadmill yet again by applying, with the assistance of the agent, for a protection visa, which application failed. He then lodged an appeal to the Refugee Review Tribunal. In a matter of days before the individual and his agent were to appear before the tribunal, the agent sent a message through to the applicant to say that he was not going to be represented any more.

I find that a despicable act. Here you have this person whose hopes had been built up again and again—in some cases by direct lies, untruths—by being told he might have the opportunity to get refugee status in Australia when clearly he had been rejected quite a number of times on the merits of the case. Yet, at the death knock, at the final hour, the person who had propped the individual up on the way through pulled the props away and left him floundering. He was floundering, and his application to the RRT failed. He did not go to the tribunal hearing alone. There were people who went along, held his hand and provided him with some support, although they could not support the argument that could have been provided.

I take a pretty hard line on illegal entries to this country. I do not think there is anybody in this chamber who would deny that. But at least my line is honest. I do not stoop to the depths that people like the particular agent I am referring to did when he let that poor unfortunate individual down in the way the individual was let down. I think that is despicable.

I hope that the agent, who undoubtedly will read this speech, will recognise whom I am talking about and will seek to repair the damage they have done. The best thing they could probably do would be to remove themselves completely from this area of migration policy and not to involve themselves in it in any shape or form again. I hope the individual migration agent concerned would do that. If I find that they do not, perhaps I will come into this place and use the privilege of the parliament to protect some of the illegal entrants to this country in a way that would provide proper protection to them, not the sort of protection that that particular agent gave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The parliament is discussing the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). In substance, the bill seeks to retrospectively authorise the detention of asylum seekers and to remove the right of detainees to obtain reasonable compensation for unlawful detention by limiting compensation to $1 per day, which could almost be classified as contemptuous compensation. I and the Australian Democrats believe that this bill should be rejected by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: When the government first introduced this bill, it was obviously a reaction to the then likely determination of the High Court that the government's attempt to limit compensation to $1 per day for unlawful detention was neither fair, just nor reasonable. The bill, at that stage, certainly offended the principle of separation of powers, which requires that the executive government should not intervene in the judicial process.

The bill was also examined by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The committee heard evidence, amongst other points that were placed before it, that the legislation could contravene section 31 of the constitution as an acquisition of property through the denial of compensation following a tort.

Apart from concerns with its constitutional validity, the attempts by the Commonwealth to remove itself from the jurisdiction of the courts is, in the Democrats' view, an inappropriate use of the privilege it has as part of the legislative process. If the Commonwealth believes that it is not liable it should defend the matter in the courts, not change the law. The removal of the common law right through retrospective legislation is simply not acceptable. The dicta of the High Court in previous instances in which retrospective legislation has been acceptable are those in which no parties were disadvantaged, their liberties undermined or their rights abused.

Given the broad-ranging consensus in evidence before the committee that the bill may be unconstitutional, it does not achieve the government's stated desire of limiting costly court proceedings. I would venture to guess that a High Court challenge is almost inevitable should the bill be passed and that therefore this bill does not provide an adequate resolution of the situation. I know the statement has been made that the government will now be able to pursue a settlement out of court, but it seems to me that the people at the other end of that negotiation process do not have a lot of leverage when the government has been able to get through this parliament a bill which limits the damages to a contemptuous $1 a day.

That brings me to the point that the bill this time around will only be passed because the coalition parties have decided that they will now support it. I think it might be instructive if we look at some of the pronouncements that were made by coalition representatives at a time when they had decided on legal, moral, and constitutional grounds that this bill should be opposed. I quote from Hansard of 9 November 1994 where Senator Short said the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also breaches several basic principles of law. It condones the proposition that, wherever unlawful administrative action has been taken, the parliament may retrospectively act to cure it. If we accept that proposition, that would, as the Law Council of Australia has said, `destroy or at least significantly diminish the Commonwealth administrative law system'.
A little further down the page he said:
It is quite certain that, if this bill were passed, it would be challenged in the High Court. Legal advice indicates that such a challenge would very likely be successful.
Again a little further down in the same speech Senator Short said:
The coalition does not believe, however, that considerations of this nature, unfortunate though they may be—
and that refers to the High Court challenge—

should be permitted to override the fundamental objections to this flawed bill, with its breaches of basic principles of law and with all its damaging implications for the future processes of and confidence in our legal system.
There is more. On the same day, at page 2715 of Hansard, Senator O'Chee said the following:

. . . the government comes before this parliament and asks it to rubber stamp its illegal and unprincipled actions, but when Australians are unlawfully detained in another country this same government seeks a different standard from that country.

Isn't it somewhat surprising that, having said all those things based on legal advice and based on evidence before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the coalition now says, `Well, there is a lot of money involved. We must ensure that the budget deficit does not grow. We must save money. So we will throw out all those principles that protect our legal system; all those principles that go to the separation of powers; all those principles that go to the basic argument that a government in a court should be no better off than a citizen; that it should not go away from the court when it receives or fears an unfavourable judgment and say, "Well, I think I am going to lose so I will quickly run into parliament and get the law changed."'

PARA.TAB: That very basic principle is being contravened by the government and now, I am sad to say, by the coalition. I hope that they can live with their consciences. The Australian Democrats strongly oppose this bill and will be voting against it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I need to speak at length, save in response to the earlier sniping from some members of the opposition. I am used to it. We will get on with the policy and then we might have some more constructiveness in this place.

PARA.TAB: In essence, the government has acted on advice. This has been a difficult issue for the parliament to grapple with, but it is symptomatic of issues in migration. Anyone who comes into this area thinking that there will not be a continuing demand for bills to amend legislation has no appreciation of the area. This area is very much influenced by events which are not in the control of Australia, in many respects, and also events which are not within the control of the parliament. The courts have a very innovative way of interpreting the law.

All these factors will ensure that for the foreseeable future there will also be a number of migration bills going through this parliament every year. That has been the nature of it since the legislation was codified some six or seven years ago.

Having said that, this issue has been difficult. From the start the government has been keen to ensure that the people involved do not get a windfall benefit. As a consequence, we took the initial measure and the second measure. In respect of the second measure, the opposition has gone from one side to the other. We are glad that they are now back onside.
Question put:
That the bill be read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hope that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) is not going to treat this particular measure in a cavalier fashion. What these amendments are proposing, as I understand it, is to prevent repeat applications. It is a matter that has exercised the minds of quite a number of people, and the minister owes it, surely, to the chamber to give some sort of explanation.

PARA.TAB: I know there is an explanatory memorandum being circulated, but I think he also owes an explanation as to why the legislation is required to be amended in this fashion. Why, indeed, did not the minister come back to the chamber—and I want him to answer this—with a bill which incorporated those measures that he now attempts to have tacked onto this piece of legislation as amendments? I do ask the minister that, and I think we are entitled to a response to that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very simple response. The amendments that have been moved by the government to this bill are, in fact, parts of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995, a bill which Senator Harradine knows has not been given priority by the government in the way that it was before in respect of the one-child policy aspects of it.

PARA.TAB: As the parliament knows, I think, the government moved such legislation and the matter went to the full bench of the Federal Court. Whilst that resolution of the Federal Court stands—and I do note that it has been appealed against—the government does not see as much need to proceed with the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995 as there was before. We do see a need to proceed with the repeat applications part of that legislation and that is why we have brought those amendments out of that bill and put them in this one. We do see them as separate to the one-child policy aspect of the other bill, but we also see them as important enough to proceed with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I understand the point he is making. But what I am saying is: why were those amendments not incorporated into this legislation? Correct me if I am wrong, but did the bulk of the $1 a day legislation go through the House of Representatives prior to the full court decision in re Sackville?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it did. But the important part from the government's perspective is to separate these amendments from the other bill and to have them treated and passed, hopefully, by the parliament. We chose to put them in this bill. I suppose we could have put them in the bill that has already been through the parliament, recognising that migration bills do consistently cover different areas and different subjects of migration legislation. But we put them in this one. I do not really understand what inference Senator Harradine is drawing from that. They are important measures and measures which have bipartisan support, although obviously not yours, Senator.

—Could I indicate my opposition to the amendments that are being proposed. I will not delay the committee on the matter because I think the matter has been canvassed thoroughly before. But I do express my opposition to the amendments.
