TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly but I think this is a very serious matter indeed. I think the Senate will regret having taken this decision. I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that this is retrospective legislation that will place a disadvantage on certain people. For many years prior to this occasion I have stood in this chamber opposing retrospective legislation and I was kicked up hill and down dale for it. I oppose this retrospective legislation again. I believe that retrospective legislation has no place in the legislative program of the parliament if it is going to seriously disadvantage persons by taking away from those persons the rights that they previously had.

PARA.TAB: The other point I wish to make is that what we are doing here now is, in effect, saying that the perpetrator of the crime can be the arbitrator of the compensation for that crime. That is what you are doing here. This legislation virtually says that, where a court finds that asylum seekers have been illegally detained and that they are entitled to just compensation, that compensation will be at the rate of $1 per day. As I have said, that makes the perpetrator of the crime—the Commonwealth—the arbitrator of the amount of compensation. That is just untenable.

I very strongly oppose this legislation on those grounds. I fully expect that, if these measures are taken to the courts, the courts may well have something to say, which will be an embarrassment to the activities of this particular parliament in the passage of this bill. Obviously, one cannot guess what the courts might say, but I guess we have not heard the end of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just rise to put on the public record what the Greens have said all along in relation to migration matters that are considered in this bill. What we have before us is wrong upon wrong upon wrong. Initially, the government started wrongly by trying to prevent access to the High Court by a group of asylum seekers who were claiming to have been illegally detained. My first venture into the debate in this chamber was to put on the public record some kind of protest against the action of both the government and the opposition. That wrong, which happened to prevent access to the court by certain asylum seekers, left a tiny window of opportunity—where the court found that those who had been detained before we made that unforgivable and indefensible law part of this parliament—for those people who had been found by the court to have been illegally detained to obtain some compensation.

PARA.TAB: The next wrong was in December 1992—on the 17th, as I remember it—when, in order to reduce that window of opportunity for those people who had already had their rights denied by this parliament, the government decided to reduce the compensation they could claim for their illegal detention to $1 a day. We had one chink of light last year when the opposition expressed its repugnance of retrospectivity in the way in which it voted against this measure. Certainly, many of us felt that a progressive stance was being demonstrated—instead of what we have been experiencing now for as many years as I have been in this place, of bipartisan inhumanity or a political monoculture that refuses to look at the human rights violations that we are perpetrating by legislation in this place.

I very much regret that the opposition has decided for, presumably, political reasons that it cannot oppose this bill to the very end. I know that there are many opposition senators who feel extremely uncomfortable about that, so I am not going to rub it in. I just want to put on the public record that we should not be passing this bill at this point in time.

I have not spent a long time in my speech on the third reading because the Hansard contains numerous numbers of my words about this matter. I simply want to let the Senate know at this point that not only is this bill an indictment of proper and fair debate or approach to decision making in the Senate, it is also likely to come unravelled. As Senator Spindler said so clearly in his speech on the second reading, `It is neither fair, just nor reasonable.' Neither is it likely to be held to be constitutional.

We are in very grave danger of breaching our constitutional requirements and of violating the principle of separation of powers by trying to patch a wrong which is based on a wrong which is based on a wrong. I am afraid there is no positive way forward when people act in that way. I want to distance myself, as I am sure those who have spoken on this before me also want to, from this bill and express extreme sorrow and distress that I have to have anything to do with its passage in the chamber today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1994MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION (APPLICATION) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION (RENEWAL) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994IMMIGRATION (EDUCATION) CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994 contains four main amendments and consequential amendments related to the indexation provisions proposed in the three other bills. The main provisions of this bill are, firstly, to restructure the Refugee Review Tribunal by creating positions of deputy principal member and senior members from within the existing prescribed establishment; secondly, to amend the arrangements for the cancellation of certain business skills visas; thirdly, to provide for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of all members of the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal; and, fourthly, to grant additional entitlements to applicants engaged in the Immigration Review Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: The three bills, other than the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill, are solely designed to enable the automatic indexation of migration agents registration levies and the English language charge payable under the Migration Act. The indexation of user fees and charges is designed to maintain, in real terms, the relative contributions of service users and the taxpayer in accordance with budget policy. As such, they seem to the coalition to be relatively uncontroversial in nature, although some aspects in terms of the relationship between the Senate and the other place may need to be looked at later in the debate.

I want to deal with the more substantive parts of the bill. I turn first of all to the restructuring of the Refugee Review Tribunal. The creation of the new positions of deputy principal member and senior members of the Refugee Review Tribunal from within the existing prescribed establishment, which is up to 100 members, is apparently designed to create a more hierarchical structure for the RRT and to spread some of the current leadership and administrative responsibilities of the principal member. The new hierarchical structure proposed is more in line with that of the Immigration Review Tribunal, which basically has similar positions to the ones now being created.

The government has provided scant justification for the need for the restructuring of positions on the Refugee Review Tribunal. The only argument that has been brought forward is that they enhance the hierarchical structure of the body. The changes are said to have no financial impact. However, following furthering questioning of the department on this point—and this was also raised in estimates committee hearings—it came out that the phrase `no financial impact' refers to forward estimate projections which are already quoted to account for more members than the RRT actually has. In the committee stage, I will seek further clarification from the minister on exactly what structure he is proposing for the RRT, how many members in total it will have and what it actually means in terms of dollars and cents this year. To say that it has no financial impact I think is misleading.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: We have before the Senate tonight a report from the Australian Research Council and the Higher Education Council which have developed a number of recommendations relating to the benefits of Australia's research effort. I want to put this report in some context. Australia has one of the best records in the OECD of coming up with innovative ideas and leading world research. One of the problems that we have tended to have over the years is moving this research through to the marketplace, where we can gain maximum economic benefit from the outcome. We seem to have had a history of failing to turn innovations into products. Part of the thrust of this report in this changing information age is to bring about a situation where Australia gets a higher level of benefit from what is happening in the marketplace. This is particularly crucial because, as we open up our economy and as the information superhighway develops, it will be very easy for Australian intellectual property to move out of the country and into other countries and for them to benefit economically rather than us.

PARA.TAB: The report makes four recommendations to address this matter. The first one is for the Australian Research Council—the ARC—to commission a study to examine the innovative progression gap. That is a problem for researchers. This basically means moving the idea from the stage of a piece of intellectual property through to its further development into the marketplace. I think that move is most welcome. This is of course a preliminary report, and such a study as proposed in recommendation one will set a good foundation for policy in future.

The second recommendation is that the ARC and HEC sponsor a forum for industry researchers and higher education institutions to discuss intellectual property issues. This is very much needed. When I was in America last year, they were discussing a number of the implications of the superhighway, and they saw the real danger that people could lose control of their intellectual property. Not only have trade barriers opened up but also with the new information superhighway intellectual property can move very rapidly across boundaries. People can access databases a lot more easily, and whole loads of information can be moved in the blink of an eye from Australia to some other country. It is very important that we have a very informed discussion on this issue.

The third recommendation is that the ARC and HEC encourage institutions to offer intellectual property training courses to postgraduate students. Many students, when focusing on getting a higher degree, often do not realise the value commercially of what they are dealing with. In their eagerness to publish papers and establish a recommendation, they often give away things that are of great benefit to this country. We should treat intellectual property like we would treat gold and silver because, in the end, it can have the effect of helping develop our economy further if the rights of the individual doing the research and if the rights of the institution are protected. Research students need to be trained properly to manage this intellectual property. So recommendation No. 3 is most welcome.

The fourth recommendation is to encourage institutions to promote and develop academic staff programs on intellectual property, production, management and exploitation in the business context. That is most welcome. But what we need in addition to that is some backup and foundation in this parliament for these intellectual property rights.

The issue has not been discussed enough in the parliament. We do not have a proper legislative base to protect this matter. We have protection for things such as paper copy, but in the information age we do not have proper protection for material that is on computers. As I mentioned before, we must not allow people from overseas to profit from our innovations. Australian academics and Australian companies should reap the benefits of our expertise and intellectual property.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was originally intending to reserve my remarks on this document. But I want to make a few points as well reserve my right to speak at a time when I have had a chance to more thoroughly examine the nature of this report. I take issue with a few points that Senator Tierney made and those of a lot of people who may have partially looked at the arguments.

PARA.TAB: I am beginning to speak to a growing number of those people working in research or postgraduate areas who are deeply concerned about the current implications of our intellectual property rules, especially as they have resulted under our commitments under the Uruguay Round of GATT. They are deeply concerned because the current intellectual property rules do not serve to protect individuals or, in particular, the institutions from which they come.

The way this parliament and other parliaments in the world seem to have been required to respond to rules from the Uruguay Round of GATT has protected the rights of corporations that have funded research. As we push our educational structures to be more and more commercial, even though the general public pays back a 150 per cent tax deduction to corporations that require universities to conduct research for them, the corporations become the owners of the intellectual property. So we are not protecting the rights of those people who have developed the ideas. We have certainly not protected the rights of those people who may have come up with the ideas when in another country a corporation has patented a similar idea at an earlier stage. Therefore, all the outcome from thereon comes from the development of that idea.

What we are doing, in most cases unknowingly, is developing a system which mitigates against the transfer of ideas and science. Science requires the intellectual exercise of moving, checking and having your papers checked. It is very difficult these days to even get your academic papers checked interstate or sometimes even within your own state, let alone overseas. It is because of the intellectual property rights. We are stifling creativity. We have turned ideas into a commodity that has a dollar value.

In reality, it means that we are saying, first of all, that our universities have to be as commercially oriented as possible. We are more and more giving that right to control the type of research to corporate hands. By the kind of legislation and agreements to which we have signed under the Uruguay Round of GATT, we are giving the control of those ideas at an international level to corporate interests. There is a whole level of this debate which we have not really considered in Australia.

If we really want to stifle creativity in Australia and elsewhere, this is exactly the way to do it. Talk to scientists and postgraduates. Initially, they did not know what the implications would be. But they are experiencing it right now. Try to find out. Talk to people involved in science and social science and find how difficult it is now for them to get their papers refereed. Talk to them about how easy it is to communicate ideas from one person to another. Talk about the implications of the information superhighway becoming an information supertollway in more ways than one.

I would like to talk about this from the report in more detail in the future. I would like to get these points on the record. We should be concerned and we should have had this debate in much greater depth. In future, I would like the opportunity to do that. In the meantime, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report deals with a collision between a Malaysian air force aircraft and an aircraft of the Royal Australian Air Force at Butterworth on 13 October at the end of last year. The board of inquiry and the accident investigation team of the Royal Australian Air Force both agreed that the action was due to an error of judgment. Both pilots failed to take avoiding action early enough to avoid collision. It was determined that the pilots were appropriately qualified, that the mission had been well briefed and conducted in accordance with relevant orders and instructions, and that all manoeuvres flown by both pilots before impact had been conducted in a professional and competent manner.

PARA.TAB: This is not the first time we have had mid-air collisions between aircraft in the air force. Unfortunately, we will go on having them. The nature of the training regime in air combat manoeuvring is really quite violent and very realistic. The tolerance for error is absolutely minimal. When there are aircraft at closing speeds of probably up to 1,200 miles per hour, things happen with great rapidity. In recent years, we have had the odd unfortunate collision in this country, particularly since the introduction of the FA18, with its far higher manoeuvrability than the Mirage, which it replaced. Careful planning and good training will reduce the number of those incidents, but it will never entirely eliminate them.
The final paragraph—paragraph 4—talks about the actions arising from the investigation. I will quote the first sentence of it:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the recommendations resulting from the investigation and the executive review process, a number of measures related to improved training programs and currency requirements for pilots engaging in air combat training are to be implemented.

That does not sit well with the conclusion in paragraph 3 in relation to the investigation, which is that the mission had been well briefed and conducted in accordance with relevant orders and that all manoeuvres, et cetera, had been conducted in a professional and competent manner.

PARA.TAB: My concern is the inclusion in the fourth paragraph that currency requirements for pilots engaging in air combat training are to be implemented. They found that the accident was due to an error of judgment. Judgment is something that has to be exercised constantly. Anyone who has learnt to fly can fly an aeroplane as long as they are physically able to. To fly to the degree of precision and anticipation that is required in air combat manoeuvring exercises does require constant practice and frequency.

It has been a concern for quite a number of years that reducing the defence budget year after year has meant that training has been curtailed in all three services. It is particularly acute in the case of the air force. I do not know for what number of hours pilots are flying in the FA18 or the F111 fleets, but it is probably in the order of about 17 or 18 hours per month. Arguably, it probably should be around 24 or even 26 hours per month. While it might seem that an hour or two does not make much difference, it really does when you are asking people to fly at the limits.

My mind goes back to a report tabled in this parliament a few months ago which dealt with the loss of an F111 at the Guyra bombing range. The aircraft flew into the ground. The aircraft was destroyed and both crew members were killed. It turned out that the crew of that aircraft were tasked for what was the most difficult operation you could ask an F111 crew to do, which is a low-level night strike in appallingly bad weather. It turned out that they had not flown on a similar operation at night for two or four months. I wonder whether the currency requirements were fully met in that case.

The Senate could well get the full report. All we have here is one page, which is a very abridged precis of the report of the board of inquiry and the accident investigation team. There are no security elements in this. The entire report in these circumstances ought to be available to the parliament for those who are interested in pursuing the matter. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! The consideration of government documents having now concluded, I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a heavy heart that tonight I stand to address the Senate because tomorrow there will take place the funeral of young Peter Savage. Peter, you will recall, was the Trinity schoolboy who was stabbed as he walked home from football practice last week. I did not know him personally but I am part of the same family, part of the Trinity school family. All I have heard from that family is that Peter was a very decent, pleasant, easygoing and popular young man. His death was a great loss to the school and to the community but most particularly, of course, to his own family.

PARA.TAB: Peter was described by the headmaster of Trinity as `a gentle giant'. My son Matthew is a student of Trinity. We all feel part of the extended Trinity family. It will be, I know, of some comfort to the Savage family to know that they have the support and prayers of that family.

Most murders are senseless, but probably none more so than this—a fine young man who was struck down in his prime, with no apparent motive. There was some doubt about robbery or jealousy but certainly there was a strong element of thuggery. It clearly is not safe to walk on our streets any more. The criminologists tell us that the statistics show that crime rates are down. I think that just confirms the old saying that there are lies, damned lies and statistics.

In the real world there is real concern, even fright and in some cases terror, about our society. The academic criminologists should come down from their ivory towers and listen to the people in the real world. It is one of the great sadnesses in our society that we are no longer safe in our own houses or in our streets. Peter was attacked just 500 metres from his own home at 6.30 in the evening.

What is the solution that we must face to stop fine, decent young men like this from being attacked? It may be that heavier punishments are needed, but surely the most important thing is the certainty that the perpetrators will be caught. The most stringent punishment is no use by itself; we need to be fairly certain that we will catch the criminals. That means more resources for police, it means more police on the front line and more police on the beat—genuine policemen rather than those who are pen pushing and paper writing. I have to say at this point that in spite of the royal commission in New South Wales I have a high regard for the majority of police in New South Wales. They do a very good job under very difficult circumstances.

Contrary to many views, I believe we should start with the minor crimes and vandalisms, which are the breeding ground for the thugs and criminals in our society. We must ensure that there is a high probability of these thugs and criminals being caught. The problem is so real and so worrying that Rod West, the headmaster of Trinity Grammar School, for whom I have the highest regard, had even before this incident issued a warning in the headmaster's monthly bulletin regarding just this sort of situation—boys being attacked on their way home from school. Surely nobody except those living in ivory towers would have doubted the problem before this incident. Certainly after the events of the last week there can be no doubt at all about the magnitude and seriousness of this problem.

The problem was emphasised for me last Saturday night when my 21-year-old nephew was beaten by thugs to within an inch of his life—again pure thuggery. There was no robbery as a motive. His jaw was fractured, his nose was fractured and his eyesight was damaged, hopefully only temporarily. Joel Campbell, my nephew, is one of the most fine and decent young men I know. His family I hold in the highest possible regard. They represent everything that is good and decent in our society.

Where did this vicious attack take place? In the back streets or alleys of Sydney or Melbourne? This took place in Sale in Gippsland, not a place you would think of in terms of this sort of violent assault. It shows how far this senseless violence has penetrated our society when this sort of country town is affected in this way by this sort of violent attack.

Our job here in parliament is to ensure that the senseless waste of the lives of fine young men like Peter Savage does not happen again. I know that Meryl, Peter's mother, has the view that if as a result of Peter's death our streets are made safer, then the senselessness of it may have been reduced just a little. That is what we in this place and others around Australia must seek to achieve. My heart goes out to Peter's family, to his mother Meryl and father Reg, to his brother Leon—who, in particular, has been a great source of strength to his family and friends—and to his brothers Jonathon and Benjamin. My prayers are with you all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I began a speech, which I want to continue tonight, in relation to the protection of the headwaters of the Great Australian Bight as a Great Australian Bight marine park. I was making the point that this necessarily involves both the state of South Australia, which has control of the waters out to the three mile limit, and the Commonwealth, which controls the waters from there out to the 200 nautical mile limit. The importance of this area lies in the fact that it is a very diverse region. It is the breeding ground for the southern right whale, or at least approximately 50 per cent of the southern right whales that breed around the coastline of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I went on to point out that, in addition, South Australia has an extremely poor record with respect to the protection of its marine environment, having only 1.4 per cent of its waters in marine parks, compared with some 20 and 25 per cent in Western Australia and Queensland respectively. I had also pointed out that there was more unique biodiversity in the southern temperate waters of Australia than there was in the tropical regions and that only about 10 per cent of the species in the northern parts of Australia, where most of our marine parks are sited, are unique to Australia, whereas in the case of the southern area, some 80 per cent of those species are unique to Australia. I was also pointing out that this proposed marine park at the head of the bight also had 21 breeding colonies for the rare Australian sea lions and that this was some 10 per cent of the world's population of sea lions.

The Commonwealth of Australia has national and global responsibilities for protecting biodiversity and ensuring the sustainable use of resources and also protecting endangered marine animals such as the endangered southern right whale and the rare Australian sea lion—for instance, the threatened species legislation, the national cetacean action plan and the national seal action plan being drawn up by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency. Under the Commonwealth's Ocean Rescue 2000 program, the National Ecologically Sustainable Development Strategy and the National Strategy for the Conservation of Australia's Biological Diversity, Australia and South Australia through the intergovernmental agreement on the environment are committed to the establishment of a national representative system of marine protected areas.

The point I was making when I broke off last night was that while both the Commonwealth and the state have called for a study to be carried out, and that study has been carried out, for some peculiar and inexplicable reason the minister responsible in the South Australian parliament is keeping the result of that study under wraps—is not revealing it either to the public or to the Commonwealth—yet the Commonwealth was evidently a party to the study. I think it is something that the Commonwealth should be inquiring into very quickly, particularly in view of the fact that it seems that South Australia is moving very deliberately towards an exclusive representation in its marine research area on commercial interests and not on environmental protection interests.

Under the proposal for the marine park at Head of Bight—this is the smaller proposal that the South Australian government seems to be putting—only 552 square kilometres or 6.4 per cent of the total exclusion zone will be excluded all year round from extractive exploitative activities such as fishing and mining. Both these activities have been clearly demonstrated, through research studies, to cause disturbance to whales.

The fishing industry and the Department of Mines and Energy want access to this area for six months of the year for commercial fishing and mineral and petroleum exploration when the whales are not present. The point I was stressing, also, was that this was totally inadequate because this smaller part needed to be totally protected. It also is an area which is recognised as not prospective for oil. Only a very tiny proportion of South Australia's total fishing stocks come from this area. This area, known as the sanctuary zone in the South Australian Research Development Industry draft management plan, represents the key area where the whales congregate, breed and calve at Head of Bight and move along the Nullarbor cliffs. The key issue is that this is their critical habitat and needs to be protected all year round.

The marine park area not only has poor prospectivity for mineral and petroleum activity, but commercial fishing activity is minimal. On average, less than one per cent of the southern rock lobster in the western waters of South Australia is caught within the marine park area. As far as the bluefin tuna, the other species caught in that general area, is concerned, it is migratory and could be caught beyond the limits of the park.

SARDI, the agency contracted by the Commonwealth through the Australian Nature Conservation Agency to produce the management plan for the marine park, was withdrawn from the project by the South Australian Minister for Primary Industries in February 1995 before it had completed its contractual obligations. The original project was funded in 1992 by the Commonwealth on the express condition that South Australia proclaim the multiple use Great Australian Bight Marine Park in the near future. This was agreed to in a letter to the Commonwealth by the then government of South Australia, and namely by the then minister for environment, Susan Lenehan, and the Minister for Fisheries, Lyn Arnold.

That is the point I wanted to stress in my speeches last night and tonight, that this was a clear undertaking on the part of the South Australian government. As a consequence, the Commonwealth, together with the state, funded this study carried out by SARDI. The South Australian government has unilaterally withdrawn SARDI from the study and the result of that study is being kept under wraps by the South Australian minister, and not being released to the parliament or the public.

There has been extensive consultation on this draft management plan with key interest groups. Consultation on the park started in early 1993. The 16-person Great Australian Bight Marine Park Management Plan Advisory Committee was specifically established in February 1994 to facilitate input on the draft plan. Non-government representatives on this committee included people from local tourism, commercial fisheries, recreational fisheries, conservation, local government, Aboriginal communities and people with cetacean expertise.

Government representatives included those from SARDI, the convenor/planning officer, national parks, Mines and Energy and the subdepartment of Fisheries from Primary Industries. The advisory committee has formally met on three occasions to consider, comment and make recommendations on the various drafts of the management plan. Two colour information pamphlets have been produced for public distribution by SARDI on the Great Australian Bight Marine Park proposal. They contain information on what are marine parks, the conservation and economic value of the Great Australian Bight, proposed boundaries of the park and information on the planning process. They contain no information on the proposed zones. The Minister for Primary Industries has requested that these pamphlets not be publicly distributed.

Despite the extensive planning, consultation and preparation of the draft plan, no official reason has ever been given by the Minister for Primary Industries in South Australia or the office of the Premier of Cabinet regarding SARDI's removal from the marine park project. The minister responsible for declaring marine parks is also the Minister for Fisheries and Mines and Energy. This has been a major conflict of interest, which has resulted in his reticence to support the marine park, despite the support from the minister for the environment. I will complete this speech on an another occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw to the attention of the Senate the failure of Labor's road policy in northern New South Wales—a failure that is continuing even to this day. The genesis of most of the problem goes back to a time when the Wran government from 1976 to 1988 showed a total disregard for the need to develop roads. Members of the Senate will remember those famous photos near Darling Harbour where an expressway system was left suspended in mid-air during the period of the Wran government because they did not think they should complete such roads in inner city areas. Fortunately, the Greiner government completed it.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the greatest area of neglect—and Senator Campbell is going to discover this on his northern road tour for youth in northern New South Wales next week—is the Pacific Highway, which is the major link road between Sydney and Brisbane. The Minister for Transport, Laurie Brereton, was in the area recently. He totally neglected in his speeches to mention the lack of progress by his government on this highway over the 13 years that federal Labor has been funding roads. He tried to make out—particularly to the voters in that area, as we are in the process of coming up to an election—what a great job Labor is doing. But you have only to look, particularly in the lower Hunter region, at the neglected roads to see the reality. I am sure the voters who have to travel over those roads will not be fooled.

We have the example of the announcement by Minister Brereton of the link of the F3 Freeway to the Pacific Highway near Hexham. It is interesting that he announced this road project; the project has been under way for 18 months. Why is he up there announcing it? It is under way. What he did then was worse because he went on to make an announcement about the Kurri bypass to link up to the New England Highway west of Branxton. That had also been announced several years ago and the government had put a timetable on it—a timetable which the minister then removed. We believe he removed that because of the costs of completing this link into Hexham. In other words, that road has taken a back priority and the lower Hunter will have to suffer the high demand for the roads from coal trucks that travel through the areas, including my home town of Maitland, until this road is built, which probably will not be for another 15 to 20 years.

He also came up with a number of cheap solutions to some of the problems. One was the announcements of traffic lights and photos of a lady kissing Bob Horne because he had announced this set of traffic lights. This was a cheap and nasty solution to a very major problem that required a flyover. It exemplifies what Labor has done for roads in the lower Hunter and in the electorate of Paterson, because the solutions are cheap and nasty or involve no expenditure at all. I think the member, Bob Horne, should be extremely worried about this. As the people travel over these roads, they are going to remember this Labor government's very poor record in this area. To make matters worse, Mr Horne's record also indicates to us in this parliament that he has voted for higher fuel charges.

Higher fuel charges, one would think, are turned back into roads. But, as I will show in a minute, that does not happen. The motorists in the lower Hunter, as in many other areas of Australia, get the worst of both worlds. They get higher charges on their fuel and the government does not spend the money on the roads. In a speech in the House of Representatives adjournment debate on 7 September 1993, Mr Horne had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The increased fuel excise will add about 2.3 per cent to the cost of running his vehicle. Do not get me wrong, Mr Speaker; I do not want to justify increases at all.

If he did not want to justify the increases, he obviously did not believe in them. If he did not believe in them, why didn't he vote against them? I have the voting record here, which shows Mr Horne voted for those rises in fuel taxes in his area. I would like to point out to the voters of Paterson that they have a member who puts up their road charges and does not match that with the necessary expenditure in the area.

PARA.TAB: The other area in the north that has particularly bad records on roads is the area up around Kempsey. Senators will recall that back in 1989 there was an horrific bus smash at Kempsey. The government, at that point in time, brought in a road black spot program. The government promised $1 billion to take action to prevent such things happening in the future.

If you have a look at what happened in the budget succeeding that crash, the government did spend a lot of money in the first year. The second year after the crash the money dropped substantially. The third year after the crash it dropped even further. The fourth year after the crash it disappeared altogether. In other words, the issue had lost the consciousness of the public and what happened was that spending was cut. What does this government have to wait for before it spends the appropriate amount of money on roads—another Kempsey road smash?

Such a smash is quite possible, because the problems that existed in 1989 still exist on that road today. That road poses some risk to the general public—and next week it will pose some risk to senators on this side of the chamber who will be travelling on that road up the coast. Next week Senator Campbell will see the problems in that area. A number of other members and senators that I took on our black spots road trip of northern New South Wales travelled up many sections of this road and saw how poor the funding was.

It is surprising that we do have such poor funding—surprising because of the amount of money that is raised in this country from motorists to fix the very problems that I have indicated. In 1983-84, there was 6.9c per litre spent on roads. This was money that was taken out of the fuel excise—6.9c per litre—on every litre sold in Australia for expenditure on roads. That was at the start of this Labor government. In 1994-95, 11 years later, 4.3c per litre was spent on the roads. That is a fall of a third in dollar values, but in real terms it is a much more significant drop. Yet the roads are in such terrible condition. It is really up to this government to change its priorities and make sure that it does spend a proper level of funding on roads.

Around 3,000 lives are lost each year on roads in Australia. If 3,000 people are killed in a foreign war, it becomes a major international headline. Imagine if tomorrow, in places like Bosnia, 3,000 civilians were killed. There would be headlines around the world. Yet this happens every year in Australia, and a lot of it happens because of the very poor conditions of our roads.

It behoves the government not only to do something about the roads to save lives but also to make the economy far more efficient. We have a government that claims it believes in micro-economic reforms. Yet probably one of the most significant micro-economic reforms you could make in this country is to improve the road system. It would drop the use of fuel, it would stop vehicles wearing out. People would work more efficiently because they would get to their destinations sooner. If you did a real economic cost benefit study on it, you would find that the money spent on roads repays itself again and again in greater efficiency and in lower health costs.

But we have a short-sighted government that only looks to the next election. It can only see out eight months to another election. It is not taking the long-term view and it is not really implementing proper micro-economic reform. That is not only a tragedy for our economy but also a tragedy for the many families who lose loved ones on Australia's grossly inadequate road system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to the adjournment debate tonight is to make some comments by way of condolences on the passing of Ted Whitten, the great player, coach and administrator of the great game of Australian rules football. Ted Whitten, at the age of 62, lost a very long battle with cancer some 13 days ago. Many millions of people around Australia, including your good self, Mr President, who follow Australian rules football, of course, were very sad at his passing but share the pride of Ted's valiant battle with cancer. No Australian who saw the coverage of Ted's farewell to football at the last state of origin game would be anything but deeply moved and proud of such a great Australian.

PARA.TAB: I have not lived all my life in an Australian rules football state. I spent a lot of my youth in Queensland and grew up with codes such as rugby league and rugby union and, indeed, only ever played one game of Australian rules football at primary school in Brisbane. The fact I only played one game is some comment on my ability to play that game. I achieved slightly higher achievements in the game of rugby union. When I moved to Perth in 1975, I had to learn all about Australian rules football because it got no coverage in Brisbane where I spent most of my youth.

I must say I found it very hard to follow on television and it was not until I went to a derby between South Fremantle and East Fremantle and saw the game played on the paddock, as H.G. and Roy describe it, that I could get the concept of a game that did not seem to have any off-side rule in place. I must admit at the beginning of my contribution that I do not have any deep understanding of Aussie rules as people who would have lived in Victoria would have, such as my colleague Senator Rod Kemp, who sits beside me here; yourself, Mr President; and other people who have lived in Western Australia, Victoria or South Australia where the game has been played for many years.

The game of Australian rules is truly Australian. It was developed just south of the emerging city of Melbourne many decades ago—in fact, over 100 years ago—and reflects, I think it is fair to say, as my leader, John Howard, said at a private dinner the other night, an incredible egalitarian ethos. They were not his words. He said that it is a game that truly crosses all spectra of society. You can go to any ground around Australia on any given Saturday or Sunday afternoon and see multimillionaires, political leaders, heads of the judiciary, heads of the Public Service and people from all walks of life from all sorts of ethnic backgrounds enjoying what is one of the truly great games.

Mr Whitten has been more responsible than virtually any other person in the history of the game for the development of the game, particularly at the state of origin level. I think it is fair to say that his incredible efforts in developing the state of origin game have led to the broadening of the VFL into AFL—a truly national competition. I say `truly' because, I must say, Senator Kemp, a state outside Victoria has won the flag twice in the last few years. I think it is fair to say that Ted Whitten deserves enormous credit for that.

Ted Whitten, of course, came to be known as Mr Football—obviously the ultimate accolade in his generation. He has been variously described by media as the `complete player', `wonderfully skilled' and `as tough as nails'. As a player he rose to fame through his beloved Footscray, a club that he then went on to coach after playing 321 games for that team.

He originally came from the suburban streets of Braybrook in Melbourne, but through all of his success quite clearly never lost the common touch. Many anecdotes surround Ted Whitten; many of them have been referred to in media commentary before and after his sad passing. But one of the ones that touched me is the anecdote about Ted's regular path on foot from his home to the game at the Western oval where he would be dressed in a three-piece suit, doffing his hat to ladies as he passed them on the street—something that would be fascinating to contemplate.

Opponents say that he was a very hard, tough player, uncompromising, the sort of player who would break your nose out on the ground but then after the game take you to hospital and then, after you had been to hospital, go out for a drink with you. It reminds me of some of the attributes of this place from time to time, even though there probably should be a bit more of that.

Ted went on to be a chairman of selectors for the Victorian team and, as I said earlier, was the driving force for state of origin football. I gained an enormous enjoyment from state of origin football, particularly the games I have been to at Subiaco oval. Indeed, many millions of Australians have probably been attracted to the game because of the incredible state rivalry and the intensity of competition on the ground that was developed because of those games. I am sure, like myself, many people have been attracted to the game because of those events that owe so much to Ted and his contribution.

After his role in football he went on to become a very colourful commentator and he was, clearly, a very colourful character away from football. Particularly in the latter few months and years he provided an incredible inspiration for Australians whether they followed Australian rules football or not. He was well known amongst his friends as not only a great lover of the big V and the Bulldogs but also very much as a devoted family man. It is said that no Saturday passed that he did not bring flowers home to his wife, Val, and young Ted or Ted junior, himself a distinguished player for Footscray, put it very succinctly at the state funeral last week when he described his father as his hero.

As someone who did not have the pleasure of meeting Ted Whitten, I made efforts to contact someone who I knew did know him. That was someone from Western Australia in the name of Simon Beasley, a great player for Swan Districts, who then went on to play for Footscray and, indeed in the history of Footscray, having kicked 574 goals, is the leading goal kicker for that team.

I spoke to Simon about his recollections of Ted and the influence that he had on Simon's life so that I could gain a personal insight into Ted. Simon informed me this morning that at his first game against Essendon at Windy Hill he had actually been held goalless. I am sure Simon had gone across for his first big game in the VFL expecting to do better than that. But his next game the weekend after was against Collingwood, I think at the Western oval. Simon's very first goal in the VFL was scored because young Ted kicked him a drop punt which landed on Simon's not unimpressive chest and went through to score the first of those 574 goals in the VFL.

Simon also told me that Ted's influence on Footscray was almost divine. He told me of a slightly more light-hearted incident regarding the post-1985 season trip to America that the team took where, unfortunately, the behaviour of the team on the flight saw Qantas eject them at Honolulu. Ted just happened to be holidaying there with Val at the time. Simon said that Ted's counselling of the younger players particularly in the team had helped them to pull themselves back together and ensure that, sooner or later, they actually did find an airline that would fly them back to Australia which ensured that Footscray was indeed able to compete in the 1986 season.

I conclude by saying that he was truly a great Australian, a great administrator, a great coach, a great inspiration—someone that has been lost at a relatively young age after having made an incredible contribution to Australian sport. On behalf of all senators, it is my pleasure and honour indeed to pass on our condolences to Ted's family—in particular, to Val and young Ted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: The Senate: Rulings by the President

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will be brief in my remarks but, seeing as you are in the chair this evening, I thought the opportunity perhaps should not be missed for me to make a few very brief comments—I hope that you will accept them in a constructive manner—on aspects of rulings in the Senate in recent days.

PARA.TAB: I speak as one who was warned by you, I think, earlier last week. I do not deny, in any sense, that if one makes some robust comments across the chamber the presiding officer does have a role and a duty to bring order. I think you will note that, on the receipt of the warning from you, you did not have cause again to raise that particular issue.

Even allowing for any personal bias one may have about the judgments of one's own behaviour, I have to say that in the debate today on the censure motion of Senator Gareth Evans there were many members on the other side of the chamber who persistently called out, interjected and were spoken to by you on a number of occasions, but none, of course, were warned. That did cause me concern.

I am sure I speak for a number of my colleagues when I say that the warning you were able to proffer to me—and should, I believe, in the sense of ensuring that similar standards are applied, which I am sure you believe there should be—should have been applied to at least two members of the front bench of the government party. I record with you my concern on that matter.

The other issue I wish to raise is one which has interested me for some time. You will have noted that from the points of order I occasionally make. I think it is an important issue. It regards the rulings of relevance. Standing orders are clear that answers have to be relevant. On previous occasions, I have looked very closely at the rulings of speakers and presiding officers in chambers right around Australia. I would say that there was a very big distinction between what happened in this parliament, principally in the lower house, and rulings in other parliaments. I am happy to supply you with copies of this.

Many presiding officers have been able to rule on relevance. I agree that there will always be a grey area. No-one, least of all me, wants to stop robust debate in this chamber, but clearly it is possible to rule on relevance. I would suggest that, from what I have seen from the rulings of presiding officers, particularly in state parliaments but also some of the rulings by former Senator Sibraa, it is possible to rule on relevance. It is also possible to ensure that ministers, at least within a reasonable framework, stick within the ambit of the question.

I have always felt that the problem in the lower house was simply that the Speaker there felt he could not rule on relevance. My understanding and my memory are that he would say, `This is an issue which should be referred to the relevant committee and some attempt made for the parliament to address that.'

It does seem to me that a lot of the behaviour that has occurred in the lower house results from the failure of the Speaker to effectively rule on the relevance of answers. Answers become an opportunity for an open slather attack on the political opponents of the government. It is a pity if a presiding officer finds it difficult to rule on relevance. It does ultimately lead to the sort of behaviour that we see day after day in the lower house. I think the time limit on questions that we have

SPEECH.PARA: in this chamber does impose some restriction. I would be very happy to pull out copies of rulings on relevance that have been made in state parliaments. I would urge you to see whether this particular rule could not be tightened.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister agree with the statement made by the review officer in Child Support Agency case number 427563 that, `as I have said, his salary maintenance insurance is an unnecessary expense, bearing in mind that the priority is the support of the children'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Due to privacy and secrecy provisions, I am unable to comment on the details of individual cases. I am however able to explain when a departure from a child support assessment can be made by a review officer.

There are 9 grounds set out in the child support legislation which allow for a departure from a child support assessment. An applicant will only be successful with the departure if he or she has been able to satisfy one or more of the 9 grounds and is able to show that the departure is just and equitable and otherwise proper. In cases similar to that mentioned by the honourable senator, an applicant may have applied for a review under Ground 3, that is, necessary commitments in supporting themselves.

Under this ground, a review officer would consider whether the capacity of either parent to provide support for a child is significantly reduced because of their commitments in supporting themselves. A review officer would examine the expenses detailed by the applicant and determine what costs are `necessary'. Costs which are `necessary' are those costs which are reasonably needed for the support of the paying parent.

Review officers have to make decisions taking into account the full circumstances of a case and attempt to arrive at a reasonable balance between the primary duty to maintain a child and the necessary commitments of the parents. Rights of appeal to a court with family law jurisdiction are available if a parent is dissatisfied with a decision of a review officer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Will the Attorney-General instruct the Australian Securities Commission as a matter of urgency to fully investigate whether the prospectus for the M2 Motorway has breached section 52 of the Trade Practices Act and the Corporations Law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I am advised by the ASC that it registered the M2 Motorway prospectus dated 7 November 1994 on 17 November 1994 in accordance with section 1020A of the Corporations Law. The ASC is required to register a prospectus within 14 days unless it appears that the prospectus contains a false or misleading statement or omission, or otherwise does not comply with the requirements of the Law.

I am further advised by the ASC that, as part of its normal post registration surveillance, it monitored the M2 Motorway prospectus including reviewing the report entitled `M2 Motorway—A Financial Analysis of Operations After Construction' dated 4 April 1995 by Mr Richard Tanner. The ASC has advised that nothing has come to its attention which has caused it to form a view that there has been any breach of the Corporations Law in relation to the prospectus.

I am advised that the ASC will continue to monitor the performance of the project in light of the information contained in the prospectus and will take any action considered appropriate, should the circumstances arise. In those circumstances, the Attorney-General does not propose to direct the ASC to investigate the matter under the Corporations Law. The application of section 52 of the Trade Practices Act is not a matter for the ASC, so the issue of the ASC investigating any alleged breach of that Act does not arise.

It should, however, be noted that the Corporations Law does provide investors with statutory rights of action to recover any loss or damage against persons involved in the preparation of the prospectus, including directors who signed the prospectus and experts who consented to the inclusion of their reports in the prospectus, where statements in the prospectus prove to be false or misleading, or there is a material omission from the prospectus.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Defence Force: Search and Rescue Operations

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the total area for which Australia has maritime search and rescue responsibilities, described in both geographical terms and as a measurement of area.
(2) How do Australia's maritime search and rescue responsibilities compare with those of other nations in terms of area covered.

(3) Can a description be provided of all maritime search and rescue operations in which Australian Defence Force (ADF) assets have been used since 1 January 1994, including: (a) the purpose of each operation; (b) the country of origin of persons or assets which were the subject of each search and rescue operation; and (c) details of the deployment of ADF assets (including type, hours in use, number of personnel, et cetera).

(4) What bilateral and multilateral arrangements are in place between Australia and other countries concerning maritime search and rescue operations covering issues such as cost recovery, insurance requirements, search and rescue notification and co-ordination, and liability for Australian personnel involved in search and rescue operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia has accepted the responsibility for search and rescue for an area of 47,000,000 square kilometres. The search and rescue region extends from longitude 74 degrees east to 163 degrees east and from Antarctica (to 90 degrees south) to the boundaries with Sri Lanka, Indonesia, PNG, the Solomon Islands and Fiji.

(2) Australia's search and rescue region covers approximately 9 percent of the earth's surface, but this is primarily a consequence of Australia's isolated geographic location. While the area of responsibility is large, it is partially compensated for by the low density of traffic that transits the region. Normally search and rescue regions are allocated by dividing the ocean areas equally between the bordering nations.

(3) To provide a full description of all maritime search and rescue operations that the ADF has been involved in, since 1 January 1994, would involve considerable research and I am not prepared to authorise the time and effort entailed. However, the issue of records and statistics for search and rescue operations was discussed in detail in the recent Joint Review of National Maritime and Civil Aviation Search and Rescue Arrangements. The ADF, Airservices Australia and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority are presently working on the development of a common reporting database which will improve the access to detailed statistical data.

(4) Australia is a signatory to a number of international conventions that result in the provision of search and rescue services. These include the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea 1974, the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue 1979 and the Convention on International Civil Aviation. Under the auspices of these conventions, participating countries accept responsibility for search and rescue operations in their designated areas. In view of the importance the Government places on the safety of human life and its obligations as a signatory to international treaties and conventions, Australia does not pursue cost recovery for humanitarian operations. This is consistent with international practice. Other signatories to the search and rescue conventions not only accept this responsibility but often assist each other in the conduct of search and rescue operations. Australia has in the past regularly received assistance from France, Indonesia, New Zealand and the United States.

(3) What is the term of the contracts.
(4) What limits have been placed on the purchase of furniture.
(5) Is the furniture to be purchased to be Australian made; if not, why not.

(9) What is the cost of non-executive furniture over the same period of time throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Purchasing and Disposals Gazette of 31 May 1995 reflected the gazettal of a standing offer [Common Use Arrangement (CUA)] for executive type desks, chairs, side tables, bookcases etc. for the period 1 March 1995 to 28 February 1998. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 August 1995:

(2) Where will the computers be utilised.
(3) Who will utilise these computers.
(4) What is the expected life expectancy of these computers.
(5)(a) When will they be disposed of; and (b) how will they be disposed of.
(6) What is the expected return from the disposal of these computers.
(7) What is the reason obsolete computers were purchased instead of up-to-date computers.
(8) How obsolete are the computers that have been purchased.
(9) What other obsolete computers have been purchased by the department in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3), (7), (8) The Department did not purchase obsolete computers. It purchased 55 personal computers (PCs) from IBM in providing information technology facilities to Contracted Case Managers (CCMs) under arrangements which are part of the framework announced in Working Nation for delivering services to long-term unemployed people. The PCs were Intel-type 486 machines. They are not `obsolete', but were incorrectly listed as such in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 7 June 1995. The PCs were new machines purchased under common use contract PE 50 and carry the normal 12 month warranty provided by that contract. The machines were relatively cheap because their configuration (in this case their processing speed and the size of the hard disk drives) was lower than DEET's current standard.
(4) The PCs will serve the function for which they were purchased for about three years.

(5)(a) The PCs would normally be disposed of in about three years as part of the Department's rolling replacement program for IT infrastructure. The ongoing arrangements for providing IT support to CCMs are, however, subject to further discussion between DEET and ESRA.
(b) The PCs will be disposed of through the Department's normal IT equipment disposal processes which follow the guidelines set by the Department of Administrative Services.
(6) The expected return from disposal of a PC after three years is about $500 to $700, depending on the configuration.
